[CLS] an oxaziridine is an organic molecule that features a three @ - @ membered heterocycle containing oxygen , nitrogen , and carbon . [SEP] in their largest application , oxazidines are intermediates in the industrial production of hydrazine . [SEP]
[CLS] oxaziridine derivatives are also used as specialized reagents in organic chemistry for a variety of oxidations , including alpha hydroxylation of enolates , epoxidation and aziridination of olefins , and other heteroatom transfer reactions . [SEP] oxaziridines also serve as precursors to amides and participate in [ 3 + 2 ] cycloadditions with various heterocumulenes to form substituted five @ - @ membered heterocycles . [SEP]
[CLS] chiral oxaziridine derivatives effect asymmetric oxygen transfer to prochiral enolates as well as other substrates . [SEP] some oxaziridines also have the property of a high barrier to inversion of the nitrogen , allowing for the possibility of chirality at the nitrogen center . [SEP]
[CLS] oxaziridine derivatives were first reported in the mid @ - @ 1950s by emmons and subsequently by krimm and horner and jurgens . [SEP] whereas oxygen and nitrogen typically act as nucleophiles due to their high electronegativity , oxaziridines allow for electrophilic transfer of both heteroatoms . [SEP]
[CLS] this unusual reactivity is due to the presence of the highly strained three membered ring and the relatively weak n @ - @ o bond . [SEP] nucleophiles tend to attack at the aziridine nitrogen when the nitrogen substituent is small ( r1 = h ) , and at the oxygen atom when the nitrogen substituent has greater steric bulk . [SEP]
[CLS] the unusual electronics of the oxaziridine system may be exploited to perform a number of oxygen and nitrogen transfer reactions including , but not limited to : α @ - @ hydroxylation of enolates , epoxidation of alkenes , selective oxidation of sulfides and selenides , amination of n @ - @ nucleophiles and n @ - @ acylamidation . [SEP] the peroxide process for the industrial production of hydrazine through the oxidation of ammonia with hydrogen peroxide in the presence of ketones was developed in the early 1970s . [SEP]
[CLS] chiral camphorsulfonyloxaziridines proved useful in the syntheses of complex natural product , such as taxol which is marketed as a chemotherapy agent . [SEP] both the holton taxol total synthesis and the wender taxol total synthesis feature asymmetric α @ - @ hydroxylation with camphorsulfonyloxaziridine . [SEP]
[CLS] the two main approaches to synthesis of n @ - @ h , n @ - @ alkyl , and n @ - @ aryloxaziridines are oxidation of imines with peracids ( a ) and amination of carbonyls ( b ) . [SEP] additionally , oxidation of chiral imines and oxidation of imines with chiral peracids may yield enantiopure oxaziridines . [SEP]
[CLS] some oxaziridines have the unique property of configurationally stable nitrogen atoms at room temperature due to an inversion barrier of 24 to 31 kcal / mol . [SEP] enantiopure oxaziridines where stereochemistry is entirely due to configurationally stable nitrogen are reported . [SEP]
[CLS] in the late 1970s and early 1980s franklin a . davis synthesized the first n @ - @ sulfonyloxaziridines , which act exclusively as oxygen transfer reagents , and are the most predominantly used class of oxaziridines today . [SEP] while originally synthesized with mcpba and the phase transfer catalyst benzyltrimethylammonium chloride , an improved synthesis using oxone as the oxidant is now most prevalent . [SEP]
[CLS] many n @ - @ sulfonyloxaziridines are used today , each with slightly different properties and reactivity . [SEP] these reagents are summarized in the table below . [SEP]
[CLS] with highly electron withdrawing perfluoroalkyl substituents , oxaziridines exhibit reactivity more similar to that of dioxiranes than typical oxaziridines . [SEP] notably , perfluoroalkyloxaziridines hydroxylate certain c @ - @ h bonds with high selectivity . [SEP]
[CLS] perfluorinated oxaziridines may be synthesized by subjecting a perfluorinated imine to perfluoromethyl fluorocarbonyl peroxide and a metal fluoride to act as an hf scavenger . [SEP] oxaziridines are intermediates in the peroxide process for the production of hydrazine . [SEP]
[CLS] many millions of kilograms of hydrazine are produced annually by this method that involves a step wherein ammonia is oxidized in the presence of methyl ethyl ketone to give the oxaziridine : [SEP] me ( et ) c = [SEP]
[CLS] o + nh3 + h2o2 → me ( et ) conh + h2o [SEP] in subsequent steps the oxaziridine is converted to the hydrazone , which is the immediate en route to hydrazine : [SEP]
[CLS] me ( et ) conh + nh3 → me ( et ) c = nnh2 + h2o α @ - @ hydroxyketones , or acyloins , are an important synthetic motifs present in many natural products . [SEP] α @ - @ hydroxyketones have been synthesized in many ways , including reduction of α @ - @ diketones , substitution of a hydroxyl for a leaving group and direct oxidation of an enolate . [SEP]
[CLS] oxodiperoxymolybdenum ( pyridine ) - ( hexamethylphosphoric triamide ) ( mooph ) and n @ - @ sulfonyloxaziridines are the most common electrophilic sources of oxygen implemented in this process . [SEP] one advantage of using n @ - @ sulfonyloxaziridines is that higher chiral induction is almost invariably observed relative to mooph and other oxidants . [SEP]
[CLS] high yield ( 77 @ - @ 91 % ) and dr ( 95 : 5 - 99 : 1 ) are reported for α @ - @ hydroxylation with the evans ' chiral auxiliary with n @ - @ sulfonyloxaziridine as the electrophile . [SEP] chiral induction has been demonstrated with many other chiral ketones and ketones with chiral auxiliaries , including samp and ramp . [SEP]
[CLS] extensive work has been reported on asymmetric hydroxylation of prochiral enolates with camphorsulfonyloxaziridine derivatives , achieving moderate to high enantiomeric excess . [SEP] the commonly accepted proposed transition state that justifies this stereochemical outcome involves an open transition state where the steric bulk of r1 determines the face of approach . [SEP]
[CLS] the selectivity of some hydroxylations may be drastically improved in some cases with the addition of coordinating groups alpha to the oxaziridine ring as oxaziridines 3b and 3c in the table above . [SEP] in these instances it is proposed that the reaction proceeds through a closed transition state where the metal oxyanion is stabilized by chelation from the sulfate and coordinating groups on the camphor skeleton . [SEP]
[CLS] α @ - @ hydroxylation with oxaziridines has been widely implemented in total synthesis . [SEP] it is a key step in both the holton taxol total synthesis and the wender taxol total synthesis . [SEP]
[CLS] additionally , forsyth implemented the transformation in his synthesis of the c3 @ - @ c14 ( substituted 1 @ , @ 7 @ - @ dioxaspiro [ 5 @ . @ 5 ] undec @ - @ 3 @ - @ ene ) [SEP] system of okadaic acid . [SEP]
[CLS] epoxidation of alkenes is a common reaction because epoxides can be derivatized in a number of useful ways . [SEP] classically , laboratory epoxidation is carried out with mcpba or other peracids . [SEP]
[CLS] oxaziridines have been found to be useful for the formation of highly acid sensitive epoxides . [SEP] ( − ) - chaetominine was synthesized via oxaziridine epoxidation as a late stage transformation as seen below . [SEP]
[CLS] another transformation of high synthetic utility is asymmetric epoxidation . [SEP] a number of asymmetric epoxidations exist : the sharpless epoxidation , the jacobsen @ - @ katsuki epoxidation , and the julia @ - @ colonna epoxidation . [SEP]
[CLS] these methods require specific functionality in order to achieve selectivity . [SEP] the sharpless epoxidation is specific to allylic alcohols , the jacobsen epoxidation requires cis @ - @ disubstituted aryl alkenes , and the julia epoxidation requires α @ - @ β unsaturated ketones . [SEP]
[CLS] chiral oxaziridines act stereospecifically on many unfunctionalized alkenes . [SEP] it has even possible to effect stereospecific epoxidation catalytically in the oxaziridine chiral unit . [SEP]
[CLS] further investigation into these reactions may be required before levels of enantiometic excess become practical for large scale synthesis . [SEP] lusinichi et al . have investigated asymmetric epoxidation with a chiral oxaziridinium salt using oxone as the stoichiometric oxidant seen below . [SEP]
[CLS] perfluorinated oxaziridines are known to hydroxylate unactivated hydrocarbons with remarkable regio , and diastereospecificity . [SEP] this is a highly coveted transformation , and similar reactivity and specificity is seldom rivaled , especially considering the nonmetallic nature of the oxidant . [SEP]
[CLS] perfluorinated oxaziridines show high selectivity toward tertiary hydrogens . [SEP] hydroxylation of primary carbons and dihydroxylation of a compound with two oxidizable sites have never been observed . [SEP]
[CLS] retention of stereochemistry is very high , often 95 - 98 % . [SEP] ( retenton of stereochemistry may be further enhanced by the addition of a fluoride salt ) . [SEP]
[CLS] oxaziridines with unsubstituted or acylated nitrogens are capable of nitrogen atom transfer , although this reactivity has received considerably less attention . [SEP] amination of nucleophiles with n @ - @ unsubstituted oxaziridines is quite versatile in the breadth of possible nucleophiles and corresponding products . [SEP]
[CLS] hydrazines may be derived from the amination of secondary or tertiary amines , hydroxylamine and thiohydroxamines may be formed from their corresponding alcohols and thiols , sulfimides may be formed from thioethers and α @ - @ aminoketones may be formed by attack of corresponding enolates . [SEP] the transfer of acylated amines is more difficult than that of unsubstituted amines , although , unlike amine transfer by oxaziridines , there are no alternative methods that directly transfer acylated amines . [SEP]
[CLS] acylamine transfer has primarily been performed using amines and hydrazines as nucleophiles . [SEP] very few transfers of acylated nitrogens to carbon nucleophiles have been successfully performed , although some do exist in the literature . [SEP]
[CLS] oxaziridines have been found to undergo rearrangement reactions via a radical mechanism when irradiated with uv light or in the presence of a single electron transfer reagent such as cui . spirocylic oxaziridines undergo ring expansions to the corresponding lactam . [SEP] interestingly , the migrating substituent is determined by a stereoelectronic effect where the group trans to the lone pair on the nitrogen will always be the predominant migration product . [SEP]
[CLS] in light of this effect , it is possible to take advantage of the chiral nitrogen due to high inversion barrier to direct the rearrangement . [SEP] this phenomenon is demonstrated by observed selectivities in the rearrangements below . [SEP]
[CLS] in the rearrangement on the left the thermodynamically unfavorable product is observed exclusively , while in the reaction on the right the product derived from the less stable radical intermediate is favored . [SEP] aube takes advantage of this rearrangement as the key step in his synthesis of ( + ) - yohimbine , a natural medicine classified by the nih as possibly effective in the treatment of erectile dysfunction and the sexual problems caused by selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors . [SEP]
[CLS] it is also notable that oxaziridines will thermally rearrange to nitrones . [SEP] cis @ - @ trans selectivity of the resulting nitrone is poor , however , yields are good to excellent . [SEP]
[CLS] it is thought that some oxaziridines racemize over time through a nitrone intermediate . [SEP] oxaziridines undergo cycloaddition reactions with heterocumulenes to afford a number of unique five membered heterocycles , as depicted in the figure below . [SEP]
[CLS] this reactivity is due to the strained three membered ring and weak n @ - @ [SEP] o bond . [SEP]
[CLS] the battle of durenstein ( also known as the battle of durrenstein , battle of durnstein and battle of diernstein ; german : gefecht bei durrenstein ) , on 11 november 1805 was an engagement in the napoleonic wars during the war of the third coalition . [SEP] durenstein ( modern durnstein ) is located in the wachau valley , on the river danube , 73 kilometers ( 45 mi ) upstream from vienna , austria . [SEP]
[CLS] the river makes a crescent @ - @ shaped curve between durnstein and nearby krems an der donau and the battle was fought in the flood plain between the river and the mountains . [SEP] at durenstein a combined force of russian and austrian troops trapped a french division commanded by theodore maxime gazan . [SEP]
[CLS] the french division was part of the newly created viii corps , the so @ - @ called corps mortier , under command of edouard mortier . [SEP] in pursuing the austrian retreat from bavaria , mortier had over @ - @ extended his three divisions along the north bank of the danube . [SEP]
[CLS] mikhail illarionovich kutuzov , commander of the coalition force , enticed mortier to send gazan ' s division into a trap and french troops were caught in a valley between two russian columns . [SEP] they were rescued by the timely arrival of a second division , under command of pierre dupont de l ' etang . [SEP]
[CLS] the battle extended well into the night . [SEP] both sides claimed victory . [SEP]
[CLS] the french lost more than a third of their participants , and gazan ' s division experienced over 40 percent losses . [SEP] the austrians and russians also had heavy losses - - close to 16 percent - - but perhaps the most significant was the death in action of johann heinrich von schmitt , one of austria ' s most capable chiefs of staff . [SEP]
[CLS] the battle was fought three weeks after the austrian capitulation at ulm and three weeks before the russo @ - @ austrian defeat at the battle of austerlitz . [SEP] after austerlitz austria withdrew from the war . [SEP]
[CLS] the french demanded a high indemnity and francis ii abdicated as holy roman emperor , releasing the german states from their allegiance to the holy roman empire . [SEP] in a series of conflicts from 1803 @ - @ 15 known as the napoleonic wars , various european powers formed five coalitions against the first french empire . [SEP]
[CLS] like the wars sparked by the french revolution ( 1789 ) , these further revolutionized the formation , organization and training of european armies and led to an unprecedented militarization , mainly due to mass conscription . [SEP] under the leadership of napoleon , french power rose quickly as the grande armee conquered most of europe , and collapsed rapidly after the disastrous invasion of russia in 1812 . [SEP]
[CLS] napoleon ' s empire ultimately suffered complete military defeat in the 1813 – 14 campaigns , resulting in the restoration of the bourbon monarchy in france . [SEP] although napoleon made a spectacular return in 1815 , known as the hundred days , his defeat at the battle of waterloo , the pursuit of his army and himself , his abdication and banishment to the island of saint helena concluded the napoleonic wars . [SEP]
[CLS] from 1803 @ - @ 06 the third coalition fought the first french empire and its client states ( see table at right ) . [SEP] although several naval battles determined control of the seas , the outcome of the war was decided on the continent , predominantly in two major land operations in the danube valley : the ulm campaign in the upper danube and the vienna campaign , in the middle danube valley . [SEP]
[CLS] political conflicts in vienna delayed austria ' s entry into the third coalition until 1805 . [SEP] after hostilities of the war of the second coalition ended in 1801 , archduke charles - - the emperor ' s brother - - took advantage of the subsequent years of peace to develop a military restructuring plan . [SEP]
[CLS] he carefully put this plan into effect beginning in 1803 – 04 , but implementation was incomplete in 1805 when karl mack , lieutenant field marshal and quartermaster @ - @ general of the army , implemented his own restructuring . [SEP] mack bypassed charles ' methodical approach . [SEP]
[CLS] occurring in the field , mack ' s plan also undermined the overall command and organizational structure . [SEP] regardless , mack sent an enthusiastic report to vienna on the military ' s readiness . [SEP]
[CLS] furthermore , after misreading napoleon ' s maneuvers in wurttemberg , mack also reported to vienna on the weakness of french dispositions . [SEP] his reports convinced the war party advising the emperor , francis ii , to enter the conflict against france , despite charles ' own advice to the contrary . [SEP]
[CLS] responding to the report and rampant anti @ - @ french fever in vienna , francis dismissed charles from his post as generalissimo and appointed his francophobic brother @ - @ in @ - @ law , archduke ferdinand , as commander . [SEP] the inexperienced ferdinand was a poor choice of replacement for the capable charles , having neither maturity nor aptitude for the assignment . [SEP]
[CLS] although ferdinand retained nominal command , day @ - @ to @ - @ day decisions were placed in the hands of mack , equally ill @ - @ suited for such an important assignment . [SEP] when mack was wounded early in the campaign , he was unable to take full charge of the army . [SEP]
[CLS] consequently , command further devolved to lieutenant field marshal karl philipp , prince of schwarzenberg , an able cavalry officer but inexperienced in the command of such a large army . [SEP] the campaign in the upper danube valley began in october , with several clashes in swabia . [SEP]
[CLS] near the bavarian town of wertingen , 40 kilometers ( 25 mi ) northwest of augsburg , on 8 october the 1st regiment of dragoons , part of murat ' s reserve cavalry corps , and grenadiers of lannes ' v corps surprised an austrian force half its size . [SEP] the austrians were arrayed in a line and unable to form their defensive squares quickly enough to protect themselves from the 4 @ , @ 000 dragoons and 8 @ , @ 000 grenadiers . [SEP]
[CLS] nearly 3 @ , @ 000 austrians were captured and over 400 were killed or wounded . [SEP] a day later , at another small town , gunzburg - - immediately south of the danube river - - the french 59th regiment of the line stormed a bridge over the danube and , humiliatingly , chased two large austrian columns toward ulm . [SEP]
[CLS] the campaign was not entirely bad news for vienna . [SEP] at haslach , johann von klenau arranged his 25 @ , @ 000 infantry and cavalry in a prime defensive position and , on 11 october , the overly confident general of division pierre dupont de l ' etang attacked klenau ' s force with fewer than 8 @ , @ 000 men . [SEP]
[CLS] the french lost 1 @ , @ 500 men killed and wounded . [SEP] aside from taking the imperial eagles and guidons of the 15th and 17th dragoons , klenau ' s force also captured 900 men , 11 guns and 18 ammunition wagons . [SEP]
[CLS] klenau ' s victory was a singular success . [SEP] on 14 october mack sent two columns out of ulm in preparation for a breakout to the north : one under johann sigismund riesch headed toward elchingen to secure the bridge there , and the other under franz von werneck went north with most of the heavy artillery . [SEP]
[CLS] recognizing the opportunity , marshal michel ney hurried the rest of his vi corps forward to re @ - @ establish contact with dupont , who was still north of the danube . [SEP] in a two @ - @ pronged attack ney sent one division to the south of elchingen on the right bank of the danube . [SEP]
[CLS] this division began the assault at elchingen . [SEP] at the same time another division crossed the river to the east and moved west against riesch ' s position . [SEP]
[CLS] after clearing austrian pickets from a bridge , the french attacked and captured a strategically located abbey at the top of the hill at bayonet point . [SEP] the austrian cavalry unsuccessfully tried to fend off the french , but the austrian infantry broke and ran . [SEP]
[CLS] in this engagement alone , the austrians lost more than half their reserve artillery park , 6 @ , @ 000 ( out of 8 @ , @ 000 total participants ) dead , wounded or captured and four colors . [SEP] reisch ' s column also failed to destroy the bridges across the danube . [SEP]
[CLS] napoleon ' s lightning campaign exposed the austrian indecisive command structure and poor supply apparatus . [SEP] mack completely misread the french dispositions and scattered his forces ; as the french defeated each unit separately , the surviving austrians withdrew toward the ulm fortifications . [SEP]
[CLS] napoleon arrived to take personal command of close to 80 @ , @ 000 men . [SEP] at ulm on 16 october karl mack surrendered his encircled army of 20 @ , @ 000 infantry and 3 @ , @ 273 cavalry . [SEP]
[CLS] the officers were released on the condition that they not serve against france until formally exchanged for french officers captured by the austrians , an agreement to which they held . [SEP] the few austrian corps not trapped at ulm withdrew toward vienna , with the french in close pursuit . [SEP]
[CLS] a russian army under gen . mikhail kutuzov also maneuvered away from the french , withdrawing to the east . [SEP] at the ill river on 22 october it joined with the retreating austrian corps commanded by michael von kienmayer . [SEP]
[CLS] on 5 november the coalition forces held a successful rearguard action in amstetten . [SEP] on 7 november the russians arrived in st . polten and crossed the danube river the next day . [SEP]
[CLS] late on 9 november they destroyed the bridges across the danube , holding the last one at the hamlet of stein , near the village krems , until the late afternoon . [SEP] to the east of stein , 2 kilometers ( 1 @ . @ 2 mi ) down an old road , lay krems , with its small population of a few hundred , at the confluence of the stream of that name and the danube . [SEP]
[CLS] to the west of stein the danube made a large curve , creating a crescent @ - @ shaped floodplain between it and the mountains . [SEP] at the far western end of the floodplain , where the mountains came down almost to the river ' s edge , was durenstein with its castle , known as schloss durenstein . [SEP]
[CLS] the castle had served as a prison for richard i of england in 1193 . [SEP] in 1645 – 46 , during the thirty years war , the swedes had fortified the castle and then demolished it when they withdrew . [SEP]
[CLS] it stands at 159 meters ( 522 ft ) , on the highest ridge of a mountain fissured with clefts and pinnacles of granite . [SEP] because the mountain was sparsely vegetated , it was difficult to distinguish the ruins from the rocks . [SEP]
[CLS] narrow canyons cut through the mountain , and widen into the plain below . [SEP] between durenstein and stein , on the flood plain , lay the hamlets of oberloiben and unterloiben . [SEP]
[CLS] near the hamlets , the loiben flood plain was at its widest , extending at the most 762 meters ( 2 @ , @ 500 ft ) from the base of the loibenberg mountain to the bank of the river . [SEP] the region was known for its wine . [SEP]
[CLS] since the 15th century the local inhabitants practiced viticulture and the wine producers formed st . paul vintners ' guild in 1447 , the oldest such guild in the german @ - @ speaking world . [SEP] terraced vineyards extended up the sides of the krems river until it became a mountain stream and terrain was unsuitable for cultivation . [SEP]
[CLS] the loiben plain supported both viticulture and agriculture . [SEP] as the terrain became steeper , the vines grew in terraces built from the dark urgestein , primordial rock . [SEP]
[CLS] from durenstein to krems the river makes its wide curve ; the mountains and the steeply terraced slopes prevent clear line @ - @ of @ - @ sight between the two towns . [SEP] napoleon had calculated that kutuzov would withdraw toward vienna , expecting reinforcements from russia ; he envisioned that the armies would engage in a great battle at vienna , and that this battle would decide the war . [SEP]
[CLS] consequently , napoleon drew divisions from four of the other seven corps of the grande armee to create a new viii corps . [SEP] this corps was to secure the north shore of the danube , block any of the austrian or russian groups from reinforcing one another and , more importantly , prevent kutuzov from crossing the river and escaping to russia . [SEP]
[CLS] the new viii corps , under the overall command of edouard mortier , included three infantry divisions and a division of cavalry ( see order of battle below ) . [SEP] corps mortier , as it was known , crossed the danube at linz and passau in early november 1805 and marched east , on the north bank of the danube . [SEP]
[CLS] operating independently , the corp ' s cavalry conducted reconnaissance ahead of them and on the flanks . [SEP] gen . gazan ' s division ( about 6 @ , @ 000 men ) took the lead ; mortier was with them . [SEP]
[CLS] they were followed by gen . dupont ' s division ( another 4 @ , @ 000 ) about one day ' s march behind . [SEP] jean @ - @ baptiste dumonceau ' s division ( another 4 @ , @ 000 ) , marching another day behind dupont , brought up the rear . [SEP]
[CLS] a flotilla of 50 boats acquired at passau provided communications across the danube . [SEP] before sending mortier on his mission , napoleon instructed him to protect his north flank at all times against possible russian reinforcements , advice he reiterated in subsequent written orders . [SEP]
[CLS] napoleon also advised mortier to secure all crossings of the danube between linz and vienna . [SEP] on 9 november gazan ' s division reached marbach an der donau and covered the 50 kilometers ( 31 mi ) to durenstein by early on the following afternoon . [SEP]
[CLS] here it skirmished with some russian patrols to the east of the town and expelled them . [SEP] feeling confident , the french established a forward post just upstream from stein . [SEP]
[CLS] in durenstein itself mortier set up his command post and directed the establishment of a small field hospital . [SEP] although the position seemed secure , he had ignored napoleon ' s strict instructions and neglected to protect his left ( north ) flank . [SEP]
[CLS] this failure was an important factor when mortier lost his corps ' so @ - @ called " eyes " : after he and gazan had crossed the danube , the french dragoons had veered to the northwest , leaving only three squadrons of the 4th dragoons available for reconnaissance . [SEP] these had left the division and were operating independently of gazan ' s command . [SEP]
[CLS] consequently , mortier and gazan marched blindly through the narrow canyon west of durenstein , not knowing what lay ahead of them . [SEP] kutuzov had led the coalition army across the danube at krems , a short distance past stein , and destroyed the bridge behind him . [SEP]
[CLS] his actions deprived the french commanders of a possible route across the danube , putting the deployment of the entire french division at further risk in the case of retreat . [SEP] in this decision kutuzov abandoned vienna to the french , who were converging on the austrian capital from the north , west and southwest , for the security of uniting with reinforcements from galicia . [SEP]
[CLS] kutuzov chose a military solution over a political one . [SEP] unknown to either gazan or mortier , the coalition had concentrated a force of approximately 24 @ , @ 000 men ( mostly russians and a few austrians ) within a few kilometers of the french position at durenstein . [SEP]
[CLS] in comparison , gazan ' s division had only 6 @ , @ 000 men . [SEP] the austro @ - @ russian force was a mixture of infantry , jagers ( usually deployed as skirmishers ) , russian musketeers and russian and austrian cavalry , accompanied by more than 68 artillery pieces . [SEP]
[CLS] kutuzov , who had learned the military arts under the tutelage of the legendary russian generalissimo suvorov , had overall command . [SEP] the russian cavalry , units of the greatly feared cossacks , were well @ - @ suited for patrolling the river bank ; indeed , on 9 november they had taken 40 french soldiers as prisoners . [SEP]
[CLS] furthermore , reinforcements stood in moravia , less than two weeks ' march away . [SEP] if the main body of the french army crossed the river , they would require time to prepare . [SEP]
[CLS] kutuzov would have ample warning of any large @ - @ scale french movement . [SEP] after the afternoon ' s initial skirmishing with the french , kutuzov held a council of war on the evening of 10 november at melk , at the great abbey there . [SEP]
[CLS] he knew several things . [SEP] first , he knew the positions of the french from prisoners his cossacks had captured . [SEP]
[CLS] he also knew that gazan had crossed at linz and was well ahead of any french reinforcements : dupont had crossed at passau and , by 10 november , stood at marbach , 50 kilometers ( 31 mi ) upstream , and dumonceau was another 7 kilometers ( 4 mi ) further behind him . [SEP] kutuzov knew the size of the french force - - its division strength - - and its positions , and he knew that most of the dragoons were not covering the french flank but had turned north . [SEP]
[CLS] he also knew , or had made a good supposition , about napoleon ' s orders , so he knew what to offer mortier and gazan as bait . [SEP] in addition to the russian generals , the council included austrian commanders lieutenant field marshal johann heinrich von schmitt and friedrich karl wilhelm , furst zu hohenlohe . [SEP]
[CLS] schmitt , who had retired from the military in 1800 , had been recalled into service after the ulm debacle and had come to kutuzov highly recommended by the emperor . [SEP] he was an experienced tactician and strategist and had served in a variety of posts in the habsburg military ; he had been archduke charles ' trusted adviser during the campaigns from 1796 to 1800 and had assisted in planning several of charles ' victories . [SEP]
[CLS] upon his recall , schmitt was appointed chief of the quartermaster general staff of the coalition army . [SEP] the generals had found among the austrian force one capt . christoph freiherr von stiebar ( 1753 – 1824 ) , who had knowledge of the local geography . [SEP]
[CLS] together , schmitt , kutuzov and the other generals , with von stiebar ' s advice on the local terrain , concocted a plan to encircle the french at durenstein . [SEP] russian commander mikhail andreyevich miloradovich would approach gazan ' s division from the east , supported by petr bagration ' s corps , and pin the french in place . [SEP]
[CLS] three additional columns , commanded by dmitry dokhturov ( doctorov ) , maj . gen . strik and schmitt , would outflank the french from the west and the north . [SEP] they would offer , as bait , a rumor : the russian army was retreating into moravia and only a rearguard would be left at krems . [SEP]
[CLS] on the night of 10 – 11 november a russian column under strik ' s command began its passage through the narrow canyons , intent on arriving at durenstein by noon ; two more columns , under dokhtorov and schmitt , moved in wider semicircles , planning to pass through the mountains and attack the french , who were extended along the river bank . [SEP] according to the plan , in late morning strik ' s column would emerge from the mountains first and launch a flanking assault on the french right . [SEP]
[CLS] this flanking attack , combined with miloradovich ' s frontal assault from stein , would force the french into a vise ; encircled , they would have no option but to surrender - - or die . [SEP] to ensure the success of the plan , the second and third columns , under dokhtorov and schmitt , would arrive in early and mid @ - @ afternoon and support the earlier assaults . [SEP]
[CLS] in this way , even if the french tried to retreat west to marbach , they would not escape the vise @ - @ like grip of the coalition army . [SEP] mortier accepted the bait of a rumored russian retreat . [SEP]
[CLS] in the early morning of 11 november he and gazan departed from durenstein to seize stein and krems , presuming the russians had either abandoned the settlements or left only a small rear @ - @ guard behind . [SEP] as they approached stein , a column of miloradovich ' s troops attacked the french forward positions . [SEP]
[CLS] thinking this force was the rumored russian rear guard , mortier ordered gen . gazan to counterattack and push east towards the town of stein . [SEP] fighting spread though the villages of oberloiben , unterloiben and the farm at rothenhof . [SEP]
[CLS] instead of withdrawing , as a rear guard would , more and more russian troops appeared and engaged the french column . [SEP] initially gazan made rapid progress , but he quickly recognized that the opposing force was much stronger than the typical rear guard of a retreating army . [SEP]
[CLS] realizing he had been duped and that gazan ' s troops were tiring rapidly , mortier sent orders to dupont ' s division to hurry forward . [SEP] by mid @ - @ morning the french momentum had stalled ; mortier committed most of his remaining forces to driving miloradovich back , leaving a single battalion - - perhaps 300 troops - - to cover his northern flank , and sent the rest to attack the russian right . [SEP]
[CLS] within 30 minutes he achieved the superiority of numbers he sought . [SEP] his 4 @ , @ 500 french opposed 2 @ , @ 600 russians and forced them back toward stein while pressing an attack along the river . [SEP]
[CLS] miloradovich had no option , for neither strik ' s nor dokhtorov ' s flanking columns were to be seen . [SEP] at this stage of the battle fighting paused . [SEP]
[CLS] mortier and gazan waited for dupont ' s arrival while kutuzov and miloradovich waited for strik ' s and dokhturov ' s . [SEP] schmitt ' s column was expected to be the last to join the fight because it had to march the greatest distance . [SEP]
[CLS] the timing of the respite varies , depending on whose reports are consulted : fighting paused at around 12 : 00 or 14 : 00 . [SEP] strik arrived first and immediately assaulted gazan ' s line with three battalions , pushing the french out of durenstein . [SEP]
[CLS] caught between two strong forces , gazan attempted to push his way back through durenstein , to reach the river where the flotilla could evacuate his exhausted troops . [SEP] withdrawing through the narrow danube canyon and fighting off the russian force at their rear , gazan and his division were trapped when more of strik ' s russians appeared to block their retreat . [SEP]
[CLS] the narrow defiles hampered the russians ; strik ' s men had to march out of the canyons , form ranks and attack in waves . [SEP] despite strik ' s continuous assault in the next two to three hours , mortier and gazan pushed the russians back up the narrow fissure in the hillside . [SEP]
[CLS] at this point , dokhturov ' s column appeared behind the french line and joined the battle . [SEP] the french were outnumbered more than three to one , assaulted in the front by miloradovich ' s column , in the middle by strik ' s and in the rear by dokhturov . [SEP]
[CLS] earlier in the morning dupont had proceeded with his column south and east along the river , from marbach , according to instructions . [SEP] even before the arrival of mortier ' s courier , he heard the sound of artillery in the distance and sent riders ahead to discover the cause . [SEP]
[CLS] they came back to report that a russian column ( dokhturov ' s ) was descending from the mountains to take the road to durenstein . [SEP] realizing this would separate him from the forward division , dupont hustled his troops toward the sound of battle and deployed them to take the russians in the flank . [SEP]
[CLS] the french assault , heralded by cannon fire , caused dokhturov ' s troops to turn their attention from gazan ' s beleaguered force to face these new assailants . [SEP] although superior in numbers , dokhturov ' s column had no supporting artillery , and the narrow space prevented them from taking advantage of their size . [SEP]
[CLS] it was dokhturov ' s turn to face attackers at his front and rear , until the arrival of schmitt ' s column , which had wended its way through the mountains in the west . [SEP] schmitt arrived at dusk , and the action continued well after dark ; in mid @ - @ november night falls at close to 17 : 00 in the upper danube climes . [SEP]
[CLS] despite the darkness , schmitt descended out of the defiles and deployed his troops to assail dupont ' s flank . [SEP] as his russians entered the fray , they came between a battalion of french and another of russians . [SEP]
[CLS] with the additional force , the french were overwhelmed , but most of the shooting subsided when the combatants could not tell apart friend from foe in the dark . [SEP] under the cover of darkness , mortier used the french flotilla to evacuate his exhausted troops to the south bank . [SEP]
[CLS] the french and russians continued to skirmish fitfully into the night as sentries encountered one another in the dark . [SEP] portions of gazan ' s force provided any necessary rear guard action , and the following morning the remaining men were evacuated from the north shore of the danube , while they maintained possession of only spitz and weissenkirchen on the north bank . [SEP]
[CLS] the losses were staggering : gazan lost close to 40 percent of his division to death and wounds . [SEP] aside from losing five guns , 47 officers and 895 men under his command were captured , bringing the loss of effectives closer to 60 percent ; furthermore , he lost the eagles of the 4th infantry regiment ( france ) and the eagle and guidon of the 4th dragoons . [SEP]
[CLS] the russians lost around 4 @ , @ 000 , about 16 percent of their force , and two regimental colors . [SEP] the austrian lieutenant field marshal schmitt was killed as the battle concluded , probably by russian musketry in the confused melee . [SEP]
[CLS] the vineyards and the villages of ober - and unterloiben were destroyed , as was most of durenstein and stein . [SEP] krems was heavily damaged ; the french plundered the town at least twice , and " barbarously handled " its inhabitants . [SEP]
[CLS] both sides claimed victory . [SEP] although losses were fairly equal in terms of numbers - - 4 , 000 wounded or dead on each side - - the coalition forces went into battle with 24 @ , @ 000 men while the french started with gazan ' s division of about 6 @ , @ 000 , which grew close to 8 @ , @ 000 when dupont ' s men joined the fighting in the afternoon . [SEP]
[CLS] regardless , gazan ' s division was nearly destroyed ; the 30 percent losses experienced by the french fell predominantly on his division . [SEP] clearly for both sides , the fighting was hard . [SEP]
[CLS] the weather had been cold ; an early storm had left slick icy mud in the roadways , and icicles " like chandeliers " hung from the trees . [SEP] for the coalition , the russians were secure on the north bank of the danube , awaiting reinforcements from galicia ; the bridges between linz and vienna had been destroyed , making french access to the austrian capital more difficult , but not impossible . [SEP]
[CLS] after six months of fighting in which the austrians had enjoyed little good news , the coalition could claim a difficult and timely victory . [SEP] the french had retreated from the field with a badly mauled division and kutuzov had secured the right flank . [SEP]
[CLS] indeed , francis was so pleased with the outcome at durenstein that he awarded kutuzov the military order of maria theresa . [SEP] for the french , the survival of the corps mortier seemed nothing short of a miracle . [SEP]
[CLS] the remainder of gazan ' s division crossed the river the next morning and eventually recuperated in vienna , which the french acquired by deception later in the month . [SEP] more importantly for them , the french force had performed well over difficult terrain and under terrible combat conditions . [SEP]
[CLS] initially there had been some panic and parts of at least one french battalion had tried to escape on the flotilla craft . [SEP] they had lost control of the boats in the current and smashed into the pillars of the burned bridge at krems , overturning their boats . [SEP]
[CLS] tossed into the icy river , most had drowned . [SEP] despite this initial panic , gazan ' s column retained its cohesion , and responded well to various difficult demands . [SEP]
[CLS] dupont had demonstrated his tactical acumen : when he heard cannon fire , he directed his troops toward it to support the french division . [SEP] in terms of french staffing , mortier ' s failure to guard his flank , especially in the face of napoleon ' s direct advice , adversely influenced his relationship with his commander . [SEP]
[CLS] however , in the immediate weeks ahead , the flamboyant murat did more to annoy napoleon than mortier had . [SEP] in assessing the battle and its aftermath , historians have laid the blame and credit for its outcome not only on mortier and gazan : " napoleon , aware of mortier ' s danger and his own culpability for it , vented his frustration on murat , whom he unjustly accused of abandoning mortier for the empty glory of riding through vienna . " [SEP]
[CLS] after the victory at austerlitz , napoleon dispersed the viii corps and reassigned mortier . [SEP] however disappointed he may have been with mortier , napoleon was pleased with gazan ' s performance . [SEP]
[CLS] as recognition of his conduct in what the french called " the immortal battle of durenstein " , gazan received the officer ' s grand cross of the legion of honor . [SEP] the loss of schmitt was a significant blow to the austrian military organization . [SEP]
[CLS] called out of retirement for this specific task , he was one of their most experienced general staff officers , other than the archduke charles . [SEP] from the summer of 1796 until his retirement in 1800 he had been chief of the quartermaster general staff of the army , the lower rhine , the rhine and the army of germany . [SEP]
[CLS] furthermore , he was a trusted member of archduke charles ' staff . [SEP] he had helped to design several of charles ' more important victories at emmendingen , schliengen , the sieges at kehl and hunigen , the battles at ostrach and stockach , and the northern swiss campaign of 1799 that included battles at winterthur and zurich . [SEP]
[CLS] an experienced officer and excellent tactician , he might well have made a more effective chief of the quartermaster general staff of the coalition army at the battle of austerlitz than his eventual replacement , franz von weyrother . [SEP] in schmitt ' s absence weyrother , the architect of the austrian catastrophe at hohenlinden in 1800 , was chosen to develop the general battle plan of coalition action at austerlitz . [SEP]
[CLS] schmitt , undoubtedly a far better tactician than weyrother , and possessed of superior training and mapping skills , would have developed a more realistic coalition plan for austerlitz . [SEP] schmitt ' s presence would probably not have been enough to turn that defeat into a victory , but it would have mitigated the magnitude of the coalition ' s losses ; austerlitz was considered one of napoleon ' s finest triumphs . [SEP]
[CLS] in the broader picture , despite the important major naval engagements , the outcome of the war of the third coalition was determined on the continent , predominantly in the two major land operations . [SEP] in the ulm campaign , the habsburgs achieved some minor victories , such as klenau ' s at haslach @ - @ jungingen , but ultimately lost an entire army and an officer corps . [SEP]
[CLS] the latter would not resume arms against france until formally exchanged . [SEP] this condition crippled the austrian military leadership and forced the recall of such pensioners as schmitt out of retirement . [SEP]
[CLS] after the capitulation at ulm , isolated portions of the austrian military evaded capture and joined with their russian allies ; michael von kienmayer ' s corps slipped out of the encirclement and joined kutuzov ' s force . [SEP] a few other small forces refused to capitulate and seemingly melted into the bavarian mountains and the thurgingian forests , to reappear in bohemia for austerlitz . [SEP]
[CLS] sixteen hundred cavalry , including archduke ferdinand and prince schwarzenberg , broke out of ulm before its capitulation . [SEP] maximilian , count of merveldt , led his column back through the mountains into austria , fighting rear guard actions against pursuing french forces at the steyer ( steyr ) and mariazell . [SEP]
[CLS] these elusive units were insufficient to balance heavy losses at key battles in which the austrians could not hold their own against the french . [SEP] between the ulm capitulation and the austrian and russian defeat at austerlitz , there were other minor achievements : a successful skirmish between the cavalry that escaped from ulm and the french near the town of nordlingen , the contested victory at durenstein , and another within days at schongrabern . [SEP]
[CLS] the second determining event , the decisive french victory at the battle of austerlitz over the combined russian and austrian armies , forced the austrian withdrawal from the coalition . [SEP] the subsequent peace of pressburg , signed on 26 december 1805 , reinforced the earlier treaties of campo formio and luneville . [SEP]
[CLS] furthermore , austria ceded land to napoleon ' s german allies , and paid an indemnity of 40 million francs . [SEP] victory at austerlitz also gave napoleon the latitude to create a buffer zone of german states between france and the states of prussia , russia , and austria . [SEP]
[CLS] these measures did not establish a lasting peace on the continent . [SEP] prussian worries about growing french influence in central europe sparked the war of the fourth coalition in 1806 , in which austria did not participate . [SEP]
[CLS] until 1805 , durenstein was probably best known as the village in which crusader richard the lionheart was held by leopold v , duke of austria . [SEP] in 1741 , during the war of the austrian succession , several hundred local villagers had held off the french and bavarian armies , intent on capturing vienna , by painting drain pipes to look like cannons , and beating on drums , thus suggesting the presence of a large force . [SEP]
[CLS] after 1805 , the exploits of 40 @ , @ 000 french , russian , and austrian soldiers excited the european imagination . [SEP] general schmitt ' s grave has never been found , but in 1811 a monument for him was erected at the stein tor , the gate leading from the old village of krems to the hamlet of stein . [SEP]
[CLS] the house in which captain von stiebar lived was marked with a bronze plate commemorating his contribution to the battle . [SEP] in 1840 , a spanish lithographer created an image of the battle , which was later expanded by english lithographer john outhwaite . [SEP]
[CLS] the image depicts the evacuation of french troops via the danube flotilla ( see infobox image ) on a moonlit night . [SEP] in fact , the moon was in its last quarter phase 48 hours later , and on 11 november probably did not provide as much light as depicted in the image . [SEP]
[CLS] in 1836 , jean antoine simeon fort ( french , 1793 – 1861 ) , a historical painter , created a watercolor of the battle , combat de durnstein le 11 novembre 1805 ( ( english ) battle of durenstein of 11 november 1805 ) , which is in the trianon collection at versailles . [SEP] in the russian novel war and peace , leo tolstoy devoted several pages to the battle , its prelude , and its aftermath , and the delivery of its news to the tsar by prince andrew . [SEP]
[CLS] between durenstein and rossatz , at the edge of the loiben plain , stands the " little frenchman " memorial ( see image ) erected in 1905 to commemorate the battle ; it bears the names of mortier , gazan , kutuzov , schmitt , and others on a copper @ - @ engraved plate . [CLS] danube fleet of fifty boats , under the command of frigate captain lostange . [SEP] total : fifteen battalions , six squadrons , six guns , approximately 12 @ , @ 000 men , not all of which were involved in the fighting . [SEP]
[CLS] first column , commanded by general of brigade prince pyotr ivanovich bagration , included three battalions of infantry , three grenadier battalions , and three jager battalions , ten squadrons of hussars . [SEP] second column , lieutenant general essen , included six battalions of infantry , three battalions of grenadiers , and five squadrons of hussars . [SEP]
[CLS] third column , commanded by lieutenant general dokhturov , including six battalions of infantry , one battalion from the 8th jager regiment , and ten squadrons of the hussar regiment mariupol . [SEP] fourth column , commanded by lieutenant general schepelev , nine battalions of infantry . [SEP]

[CLS] brock edward lesnar / ˈlɛznər / ( born july 12 , 1977 ) is an american canadian professional wrestler , mixed martial artist , and former amateur wrestler and professional american football player . [SEP] he is currently signed to wwe on the raw brand . [SEP]
[CLS] he is a four @ - @ time wwe ( world heavyweight ) champion , a former ufc heavyweight champion , and an ncaa division [SEP] i heavyweight wrestling champion . [SEP]
[CLS] he is also a one @ - @ time iwgp heavyweight champion , making him a five @ - @ time world champion in professional wrestling . [SEP] as of july 14 , 2016 , he is # 8 in official ufc heavyweight rankings . [SEP]
[CLS] after his successful amateur wrestling career at bismarck state college and the university of minnesota ( 106 wins and 5 losses ) , lesnar signed with wwe ( then the world wrestling federation ) in 2000 . [SEP] he was assigned to its developmental promotion ohio valley wrestling ( ovw ) , where he was a three @ - @ time ovw southern tag team champion with shelton benjamin . [SEP]
[CLS] after debuting on wwe ' s main roster in 2002 , he won the wwe championship on three separate occasions with victories over the rock and kurt angle ( twice ) . [SEP] lesnar won his first wwe undisputed championship five months after his main roster debut at the age of 25 , becoming the youngest champion in the title ' s history . [SEP]
[CLS] he was also the 2002 king of the ring and the 2003 royal rumble winner , making him the youngest king of the ring and royal rumble winner as well . [SEP] following his match with goldberg at wrestlemania xx , lesnar left the wwe and pursued a career in the national football league ( nfl ) . [SEP]

[SEP] in 2005 , lesnar returned to professional wrestling and signed with new japan pro wrestling ( njpw ) , where he won the iwgp heavyweight championship in his first match . [SEP]

[CLS] later in the year , after rollins reunited with the authority , he was added to lesnar and cena ' s championship match at royal rumble , making it a triple threat match , which lesnar won despite suffering a storyline broken rib during the match . [CLS] lesnar would then face randy couture for the ufc heavyweight championship at ufc 91 on november 15 . [SEP] lesnar would beat couture via a technical knockout ( tko ) in the second round to become the new ufc heavyweight champion . [SEP]
[CLS] on december 27 , 2008 , at ufc 92 , frank mir defeated antonio nogueira for the interim heavyweight championship and was to face lesnar for the undisputed ufc heavyweight championship at ufc 98 . [SEP] immediately after winning the interim heavyweight title , mir found lesnar in the crowd and shouted , " you ' ve got my belt " . [SEP]
[CLS] due to a knee injury to mir , the title unification match with lesnar that was originally slated to be the ufc 98 main event was postponed . [SEP] lesnar won the postponed rematch with mir at ufc 100 on july 11 , 2009 , via technical knockout in the second round . [SEP]

[CLS] on july 1 , 2009 , it was reported that the winner of the shane carwin vs . cain velasquez fight at ufc 104 would face lesnar but the match was scrapped and lesnar was scheduled to defend his belt against shane carwin at ufc 106 on november 21 . [SEP] on october 26 , 2009 , it was announced that lesnar pulled out of his carwin bout due to an illness . [SEP]
[CLS] ufc president dana white said lesnar had been ill for three weeks , claiming he had never been this sick in his life and that it would take him a while to recover ; his fight with carwin was rescheduled for ufc 108 on january 2 , 2010 . [SEP] lesnar initially sought treatment in canada , but later told reporters that he had received " third world treatment " at a hospital in brandon , manitoba , and that seeking better treatment in the u . s . saved his life . [SEP]
[CLS] lesnar went on to criticize canadian health care further and stated that he shared his experience in an effort to speak " on the behalf of the doctors in the united states that don ' t want health care reform to happen " . [SEP] on november 4 , it was confirmed that lesnar was suffering from mononucleosis and that his bout with carwin would have to wait a bit longer and the fight for lesnar ' s heavyweight championship was cancelled . [SEP]
[CLS] on november 14 , at the ufc 105 post @ - @ fight conference , dana white stated , " [ lesnar ] ' s not well and he ' s not going to be getting well anytime soon " and that an interim title match might need to be set up . [SEP] in addition to mononucleosis , it was revealed that he was suffering from a serious case of diverticulitis , an intestinal disorder , which required surgery . [SEP]
[CLS] after further diagnosis , lesnar underwent surgery on november 16 to close a perforation in his intestine that had been leaking fecal matter into his abdomen , causing pain , abscesses , and overtaxing his immune system to the point that he contracted mononucleosis . [SEP] from the level of damage to lesnar ' s system , the surgeon estimated that the intestinal condition had been ongoing for around a year . [SEP]
[CLS] in january 2010 , lesnar announced on espn ' s sportscenter that he was scheduled to make a return to the ufc in the summer . [SEP] a match between frank mir and shane carwin took place on march 27 at ufc 111 to determine the interim heavyweight champion , and lesnar ' s next opponent . [SEP]
[CLS] shane carwin defeated mir via knockout in the first round , becoming the new interim champion . [SEP] after the fight , lesnar came into the ring and stated , " it was a good fight but he ' s wearing a belt that ' s a make @ - @ believe belt . [SEP]
[CLS] i ' ve got the real championship belt " . [SEP] lesnar faced carwin at ufc 116 to unify the heavyweight titles . [SEP]
[CLS] early in the first round , carwin knocked lesnar down with punch , gave him a cut above his left eye , and used a ground and pound attack the rest of the round . [SEP] in the next round , lesnar was able to take carwin down , attain a full mount , then move into side @ - @ control and finish the fight with an arm triangle choke . [SEP]
[CLS] with the victory , lesnar became the undisputed ufc heavyweight champion , earning his first submission of the night and giving carwin his first loss . [SEP] the win also tied a ufc record for most consecutive successful heavyweight championship defenses . [SEP]
[CLS] lesnar ' s next defense was against undefeated top contender cain velasquez on october 23 , at the honda center in anaheim , california at ufc 121 . [SEP] dana white announced via sportsnation that the ufc would bring back ufc primetime to hype the fight . [SEP]

[CLS] lesnar then announced his retirement from mma , mentioning his struggles with diverticulitis and saying " tonight was the last time you ' ll see me in the octagon " . [SEP] though lesnar said he was " closing the door on mma " in march 2015 , ufc announced on june 4 , 2016 , that he would return at ufc 200 on july 9 . [SEP]

[CLS] he is a member of the national rifle association , and made an appearance at their annual meeting in may 2011 to discuss his passion for hunting and his role as a spokesman for fusion ammunition . [SEP] during his first run in wwe , lesnar developed addictions to both alcohol and painkillers , allegedly drinking a bottle of vodka per day and taking hundreds of vicodin pills per month to manage the pain caused by wear and tear on his body ; he named his accident at wrestlemania xix as a particular source of pain . [CLS] lesnar claims that , as a result of his addiction and mental exhaustion , he does not remember " an entire two years " of his wwe career . [SEP] in january 2001 , lesnar was arrested by police in louisville , kentucky for suspicion of possessing large amounts of anabolic steroids . [SEP]

[CLS] constant k filters , also k @ - @ type filters , are a type of electronic filter designed using the image method . [SEP] they are the original and simplest filters produced by this methodology and consist of a ladder network of identical sections of passive components . [SEP]
[CLS] historically , they are the first filters that could approach the ideal filter frequency response to within any prescribed limit with the addition of a sufficient number of sections . [SEP] however , they are rarely considered for a modern design , the principles behind them having been superseded by other methodologies which are more accurate in their prediction of filter response . [SEP]
[CLS] constant k filters were invented by george campbell . [SEP] he published his work in 1922 , but had clearly invented the filters some time before , as his colleague at at & t co , otto zobel , was already making improvements to the design at this time . [SEP]
[CLS] campbell ' s filters were far superior to the simpler single element circuits that had been used previously . [SEP] campbell called his filters electric wave filters , but this term later came to mean any filter that passes waves of some frequencies but not others . [SEP]
[CLS] many new forms of wave filter were subsequently invented ; an early ( and important ) variation was the m @ - @ derived filter by zobel who coined the term constant k for the campbell filter in order to distinguish them . [SEP] the great advantage campbell ' s filters had over the rl circuit and other simple filters of the time was that they could be designed for any desired degree of stop band rejection or steepness of transition between pass band and stop band . [SEP]
[CLS] it was only necessary to add more filter sections until the desired response was obtained . [SEP] the filters were designed by campbell for the purpose of separating multiplexed telephone channels on transmission lines , but their subsequent use has been much more widespread than that . [SEP]
[CLS] the design techniques used by campbell have largely been superseded . [SEP] however , the ladder topology used by campbell with the constant k is still in use today with implementations of modern filter designs such as the tchebyscheff filter . [SEP]
[CLS] campbell gave constant k designs for low @ - @ pass , high @ - @ pass and band @ - @ pass filters . [SEP] band @ - @ stop and multiple band filters are also possible . [SEP]
[CLS] some of the impedance terms and section terms used in this article are pictured in the diagram below . [SEP] image theory defines quantities in terms of an infinite cascade of two @ - @ port sections , and in the case of the filters being discussed , an infinite ladder network of l @ - @ sections . [SEP]
[CLS] here " l " should not be confused with the inductance l – in electronic filter topology , " l " refers to the specific filter shape which resembles inverted letter " l " . [SEP] the sections of the hypothetical infinite filter are made of series elements having impedance 2z and shunt elements with admittance 2y . [SEP]
[CLS] the factor of two is introduced for mathematical convenience , since it is usual to work in terms of half @ - @ sections where it disappears . [SEP] the image impedance of the input and output port of a section will generally not be the same . [SEP]
[CLS] however , for a mid @ - @ series section ( that is , a section from halfway through a series element to halfway through the next series element ) will have the same image impedance on both ports due to symmetry . [SEP] this image impedance is designated zit due to the " t " topology of a mid @ - @ series section . [SEP]
[CLS] likewise , the image impedance of a mid @ - @ shunt section is designated ziπ due to the " π " topology . [SEP] half of such a " t " or " π " section is called a half @ - @ section , which is also an l @ - @ section but with half the element values of the full l @ - @ section . [SEP]
[CLS] the image impedance of the half @ - @ section is dissimilar on the input and output ports : on the side presenting the series element it is equal to the mid @ - @ series zit , but on the side presenting the shunt element it is equal to the mid @ - @ shunt ziπ . [SEP] there are thus two variant ways of using a half @ - @ section . [SEP]
[CLS] parts of this article or section rely on the reader ' s knowledge of the complex impedance representation of capacitors and inductors and on knowledge of the frequency domain representation of signals . [SEP] the building block of constant k filters is the half @ - @ section " l " network , composed of a series impedance z , and a shunt admittance y . the " k " in " constant k " is the value given by , < formula > [SEP]
[CLS] thus , k will have units of impedance , that is , ohms . [SEP] it is readily apparent that in order for k to be constant , y must be the dual impedance of z . a physical interpretation of k can be given by observing that k is the limiting value of zi as the size of the section ( in terms of values of its components , such as inductances , capacitances , etc . ) [SEP]
[CLS] approaches zero , while keeping k at its initial value . [SEP] thus , k is the characteristic impedance , z0 , of the transmission line that would be formed by these infinitesimally small sections . [SEP]
[CLS] it is also the image impedance of the section at resonance , in the case of band @ - @ pass filters , or at ω = 0 in the case of low @ - @ pass filters . [SEP] for example , the pictured low @ - @ pass half @ - @ section has < formula > . [SEP]
[CLS] elements l and c can be made arbitrarily small while retaining the same value of k . [SEP] z and y however , are both approaching zero , and from the formulae ( below ) for image impedances , < formula > . [SEP]
