[SEP] bradley kent " brad " stevens ( born october 22 , 1976 ) is an american professional basketball head coach for the boston celtics of the nba . [SEP]
[CLS] he was previously the head coach at butler university in indianapolis . [SEP] a former basketball player , he grew up in zionsville , indiana , where he starred on the zionsville community high school basketball team , setting four school records . [SEP]
[CLS] after high school , he attended depauw university , where he played basketball and earned a degree in economics . [SEP] he made the all @ - @ conference team multiple times and was a three @ - @ time academic all @ - @ america nominee . [SEP]
[CLS] stevens joined the butler basketball program as a volunteer prior to the 2000 – 01 season after quitting his job at eli lilly and company . [SEP] he was promoted to a full @ - @ time assistant coaching position for the 2001 – 02 season . [SEP]
[CLS] on april 4 , 2007 , he became the head coach after todd lickliter left to coach the iowa hawkeyes . [SEP] in his first year , stevens led butler to 30 wins , becoming the third @ - @ youngest head coach in ncaa division i history to have a 30 @ - @ win season . [SEP]
[CLS] in 2010 , his third year as head coach , stevens broke the ncaa record for most wins in a coach ' s first three years , exceeding the previous record by eight . [SEP] in the postseason , stevens coached butler to the first final four in school history . [SEP]
[CLS] at 33 years old , stevens became the second @ - @ youngest head coach to make a ncaa national championship game , losing 61 – 59 to duke . [SEP] shortly after the season ended , he signed a contract extension with butler through the 2011 – 12 season . [SEP]
[CLS] with the 2010 – 11 team making the final four , stevens became the youngest coach to go to two final fours . [SEP] stevens coached the bulldogs in their second consecutive national championship game on april 4 , 2011 , where the team lost to the huskies of the university of connecticut . [SEP]
[CLS] stevens is known for a calm , focused coaching style . [SEP] he spends a lot of time analyzing opponents using statistical analysis , adding new wrinkles to his team ' s play each game . [SEP]
[CLS] he puts a strong emphasis on defensive and team oriented basketball . [SEP] butler ' s success against teams with superior athletes has been attributed to stevens ' coaching style and calm demeanor . [SEP]

[SEP] stevens remains in close touch with the butler basketball family ; he notably took a one @ - @ game leave from the celtics in january 2016 to visit with andrew smith , a player on both of butler ' s final four teams who was dying of cancer ; smith died less than a week later . [SEP]
[CLS] at the request of andrew ' s widow , sam , brad delivered the eulogy at the memorial service on january 17 , 2016 . [SEP] stevens ' father , mark , is an orthopedic surgeon in indianapolis and former indiana hoosiers football player . [SEP]
[CLS] his mother , jan , is a university professor . [SEP] she has previously taught at butler . [SEP]

[CLS] shackleton is an impact crater that lies at the south pole of the moon . [SEP] the peaks along the crater ' s rim are exposed to almost continual sunlight , while the interior is perpetually in shadow ( a crater of eternal darkness ) . [SEP]
[CLS] the low @ - @ temperature interior of this crater functions as a cold trap that may capture and freeze volatiles shed during comet impacts on the moon . [SEP] measurements by the lunar prospector spacecraft showed higher than normal amounts of hydrogen within the crater , which may indicate the presence of water ice . [SEP]
[CLS] the crater is named after antarctic explorer ernest shackleton . [SEP] the rotational axis of the moon lies within shackleton , only a few kilometers from its center . [SEP]
[CLS] the crater is 21 km in diameter and 4 @ . @ 2 km deep . [SEP] from the earth , it is viewed edge @ - @ on in a region of rough , cratered terrain . [SEP]
[CLS] it is located within the south pole @ - @ [SEP] aitken basin on a massif . [SEP]
[CLS] the rim is slightly raised about the surrounding surface and it has an outer rampart that has been only lightly impacted . [SEP] no significant craters intersect the rim , and it is sloped about 1 @ . @ 5 ° toward the direction 50 – 90 ° from the earth . [SEP]
[CLS] the age of the crater is about 3 @ . @ 6 billion years and it has been in the proximity of the south lunar pole for at least the last two billion years . [SEP] because the orbit of the moon is tilted only 5 ° from the ecliptic , the interior of this crater lies in perpetual darkness . [SEP]
[CLS] estimates of the area in permanent shadow were obtained from earth @ - @ based radar studies . [SEP] peaks along the rim of the crater are almost continually illuminated by sunlight , spending about 80 – 90 % of each lunar orbit exposed to the sun . [SEP]
[CLS] continuously illuminated mountains have been termed peaks of eternal light and have been predicted to exist since the 1900s . [SEP] the shadowed portion of the crater was imaged with the terrain camera of the japanese selene spacecraft using the illumination of sunlight reflected off the rim . [SEP]
[CLS] the interior of the crater consists of a symmetrical 30 ° slope that leads down to a 6 @ . @ 6 km diameter floor . [SEP] the handful of craters along the interior span no more than a few hundred meters . [SEP]
[CLS] the bottom is covered by an uneven mound @ - @ like feature that is 300 to 400 m thick . [SEP] the central peak is about 200 m in height . [SEP]
[CLS] the continuous shadows in the south polar craters cause the floors of these formations to maintain a temperature that never exceeds about 100 k . for shackleton , the average temperature was determined to be about 90 k , reaching 88 k at the crater floor . [SEP] under these conditions , the estimated rate of loss from any ice in the interior would be 10 − 26 to 10 − 27 m / s . [SEP]
[CLS] any water vapor that arrives here following a cometary impact on the moon would lie permanently frozen on or below the surface . [SEP] however , the surface albedo of the crater floor matches the lunar far @ - @ side , suggesting that there is no exposed surface ice . [SEP]
[CLS] this crater was named after ernest henry shackleton , an anglo @ - @ irish explorer of antarctica from 1901 until his death in 1922 . [SEP] the name was officially adopted by the international astronomical union in 1994 . [SEP]
[CLS] nearby craters of note include shoemaker , haworth , de gerlache , sverdrup , and faustini . [SEP] somewhat farther away , on the eastern hemisphere of the lunar near side , are the larger craters amundsen and scott , named after two other early explorers of the antarctic continent . [SEP]
[CLS] from the perspective of the earth , this crater lies along the southern limb of the moon , making observation difficult . [SEP] detailed mapping of the polar regions and farside of the moon did not occur until the advent of orbiting spacecraft . [SEP]
[CLS] shackleton lies entirely within the rim of the immense south pole @ - @ aitken basin , which is one of the largest known impact formations in the solar system . [SEP] this basin is over 12 kilometers deep , and an exploration of its properties could provide useful information about the lunar interior . [SEP]
[CLS] a neutron spectrometer on board the lunar prospector spacecraft detected enhanced concentrations of hydrogen close to the northern and southern lunar poles , including the crater shackleton . [SEP] at the end of this mission in july 1999 , the spacecraft was crashed into the nearby crater shoemaker in the hope of detecting from earth @ - @ based telescopes an impact @ - @ generated plume containing water vapor . [SEP]
[CLS] the impact event did not produce any detectable water vapor , and this may be an indication that the hydrogen is not in the form of hydrated minerals , or that the impact site did not contain any ice . [SEP] alternatively , it is possible that the crash did not excavate deeply enough into the regolith to liberate significant quantities of water vapor . [SEP]
[CLS] from earth @ - @ based radar and spacecraft images of the crater edge , shackleton appears to be relatively intact ; much like a young crater that has not been significantly eroded from subsequent impacts . [SEP] this may mean that the inner sides are relatively steep , which may make traversing the sides relatively difficult for a robotic vehicle . [SEP]
[CLS] in addition , it is possible that the interior floor might not have collected a significant quantity of volatiles since its formation . [SEP] however other craters in the vicinity are considerably older , and may contain significant deposits of hydrogen , possibly in the form of water ice . [SEP]
[CLS] ( see shoemaker ( lunar crater ) , for example . ) [SEP] radar studies preceding and following the lunar prospector mission demonstrate that the inner walls of shackleton are similar in reflective characteristics to those of some sunlit craters . [SEP]
[CLS] in particular , the surroundings appear to contain a significant number of blocks in its ejecta blanket , suggesting that its radar properties are a result of surface roughness , and not ice deposits , as was previously suggested from a radar experiment involving the clementine mission . [SEP] this interpretation , however , is not universally agreed upon within the scientific community . [SEP]
[CLS] radar images of the crater at a wavelength of 13 cm show no evidence for water ice deposits . [SEP] optical imaging inside the crater was done for the first time by the japanese lunar orbiter spacecraft kaguya in 2007 . [SEP]
[CLS] it did not have any evidence of significant amount of water ice , down to the image resolution of 10 m per pixel . [SEP] on november 15 , 2008 , a 34 @ - @ kg probe made a hard landing near the crater . [SEP]
[CLS] the moon impact probe ( mip ) was launched from the indian chandrayaan @ - @ i spacecraft and reached the surface 25 minutes later . [SEP] the probe carried a radar altimeter , video imaging system , and a mass spectrometer , which will be used to search for water . [SEP]
[CLS] some sites along shackleton ' s rim receive almost constant illumination . [SEP] at these locales sunlight is almost always available for conversion into electricity using solar panels , potentially making them good locations for future moon landings . [SEP]
[CLS] the temperature at this site is also more favorable than at more equatorial latitudes as it does not experience the daily temperature extremes of 100 ° c when the sun is overhead , to as low as − 150 ° c during the lunar night . [SEP] while scientific experiments performed by clementine and lunar prospector could indicate the presence of water in the polar craters , the current evidence is far from definitive . [SEP]
[CLS] there are doubts among scientists as to whether or not the hydrogen is in the form of ice , as well as to the concentration of this " ore " with depth below the surface . [SEP] resolution of this issue will require future missions to the moon . [SEP]
[CLS] the presence of water suggests that the crater floor could potentially be " mined " for deposits of hydrogen in water form , a commodity that is expensive to deliver directly from the earth . [SEP] this crater has also been proposed as a future site for a large infrared telescope . [SEP]
[CLS] the low temperature of the crater floor makes it ideal for infrared observations , and solar cells placed along the rim could provide near @ - @ continuous power to the observatory . [SEP] about 120 kilometers from the crater lies the 5 @ - @ km tall malapert mountain , a peak that is perpetually visible from the earth , and which could serve as a radio relay station when suitably equipped . [SEP]
[CLS] nasa has named the rim of shackleton as a potential candidate for its lunar outpost , slated to be up and running by 2020 and continuously staffed by a crew by 2024 . [SEP] the location would promote self @ - @ sustainability for lunar residents , as perpetual sunlight on the south pole would provide energy for solar panels . [SEP]
[CLS] furthermore , the shadowed polar regions are believed to contain the frozen water necessary for human consumption and could also be harvested for fuel manufacture . [SEP] american beauty is a 1999 american drama film directed by sam mendes and written by alan ball . [SEP]
[CLS] kevin spacey stars as lester burnham , a 42 @ - @ year @ - @ old advertising executive who has a midlife crisis when he becomes infatuated with his teenaged daughter ' s best friend , angela ( mena suvari ) . [SEP] annette bening co @ - @ stars as lester ' s materialistic wife , carolyn , and thora birch plays their insecure daughter , jane . [SEP]
[CLS] wes bentley , chris cooper , and allison janney also feature . [SEP] the film is described by academics as a satire of american middle @ - @ class notions of beauty and personal satisfaction ; analysis has focused on the film ' s explorations of romantic , and paternal love , sexuality , beauty , materialism , self @ - @ liberation , and redemption . [SEP]
[CLS] ball began writing american beauty as a play in the early 1990s , partly inspired by the media circus around the amy fisher trial in 1992 . [SEP] he shelved the play after realizing the story would not work on stage . [SEP]
[CLS] after several years as a television screenwriter , ball revived the idea in 1997 when attempting to break into the film industry . [SEP] the modified script had a cynical outlook that was influenced by ball ' s frustrating tenures writing for several sitcoms . [SEP]
[CLS] producers dan jinks and bruce cohen took american beauty to dreamworks ; the then @ - @ fledgling film studio bought ball ' s script for $ 250 @ , @ 000 , outbidding several other production bodies . [SEP] dreamworks financed the $ 15 million production and served as its north american distributor . [SEP]
[CLS] american beauty marked acclaimed theater director mendes ' film debut ; courted after his successful productions of the musicals oliver ! [SEP] and cabaret , mendes was , nevertheless , only given the job after 20 others were considered and several " a @ - @ list " directors turned down the opportunity . [SEP]
[CLS] spacey was mendes ' first choice for the role of lester , though dreamworks had urged the director to consider better @ - @ known actors ; similarly , the studio suggested several actors for the role of carolyn until mendes offered the part to bening without dreamworks ' knowledge . [SEP] principal photography took place between december 1998 and february 1999 on soundstages at the warner bros . backlot in burbank , california , and on location in los angeles . [SEP]
[CLS] mendes ' dominant style was deliberate and composed ; he made extensive use of static shots and slow pans and zooms to generate tension . [SEP] cinematographer conrad hall complemented mendes ' style with peaceful shot compositions to contrast with the turbulent on @ - @ screen events . [SEP]
[CLS] during editing , mendes made several changes that gave the film a less cynical tone than the script . [SEP] released in north america on september 17 , 1999 , american beauty was positively received by critics and audiences ; it was the best @ - @ reviewed american film of the year and grossed over $ 356 million worldwide . [SEP]
[CLS] reviewers praised most aspects of the production , with particular emphasis on mendes , spacey , and ball ; criticism focused on the familiarity of the characters and setting . [SEP] dreamworks launched a major campaign to increase the film ' s chances of academy award success ; at the 72nd academy awards the following year , the film won best picture , best director , best actor ( for spacey ) , best original screenplay , and best cinematography . [SEP]
[CLS] it was nominated for and won many other awards and honors , mainly for the direction , writing , and acting . [SEP] lester burnham is a middle @ - @ aged advertising executive and magazine writer who despises his job . [SEP]
[CLS] he is unhappily married to carolyn , a neurotic yet fiercely ambitious real estate broker ; their teenaged daughter , jane , abhors her parents and has low self @ - @ esteem . [SEP] the burnhams ' new neighbors are retired united states marine corps colonel frank fitts and his near @ - @ catatonic wife , barbara . [SEP]
[CLS] their teenaged son , ricky , constantly films his surroundings with a camcorder , collecting hundreds of recordings on videotapes in his bedroom . [SEP] his job as a part @ - @ time bar caterer serves as a front for his secret marijuana dealing . [SEP]
[CLS] col . fitts is a strict disciplinarian who previously sent ricky to a military school and briefly committed him to a psychiatric hospital . [SEP] jim olmeyer and jim berkley , a gay couple who live nearby , welcome the family to the neighborhood ; the homophobic col . fitts angrily asks ricky " why these faggots have to rub it in your face . " [SEP]
[CLS] lester becomes infatuated with jane ' s vain friend , angela hayes , after seeing her perform a half @ - @ time dance routine at a high school basketball game . [SEP] he starts having sexual fantasies about angela , in which red rose petals are a recurring motif . [SEP]
[CLS] carolyn begins an affair with her married business rival , buddy kane . [SEP] when lester ' s boss , brad , tells him that he is to be laid off , lester instead blackmails him for $ 60 @ , @ 000 and quits his job . [SEP]
[CLS] lester takes a minimum @ - @ wage job at a fast @ - @ food restaurant , trades in his toyota camry for his dream car , a 1970 pontiac firebird , and starts working out after he overhears angela tell jane that she would find him sexually attractive if he got in shape . [SEP] he begins smoking marijuana supplied by ricky . [SEP]
[CLS] the girls ' friendship wanes after jane starts a relationship with ricky . [SEP] jane and ricky bond over what ricky considers the most beautiful imagery he has filmed : a plastic bag being blown in the wind . [SEP]
[CLS] lester discovers carolyn ' s infidelity , but reacts indifferently . [SEP] buddy ends the affair , fearing an expensive divorce . [SEP]
[CLS] col . fitts becomes suspicious of lester and ricky ' s friendship when he finds his son ' s footage of lester lifting weights while nude , which ricky captured by chance , leading him to believe that ricky is gay . [SEP] after spying on ricky and lester through lester ' s garage window , the colonel mistakenly concludes the pair is sexually involved . [SEP]
[CLS] he later confronts and beats ricky for the supposed affair and accuses him of being gay . [SEP] ricky falsely admits the charges and goads his father into kicking him out of their home . [SEP]
[CLS] meanwhile , carolyn is sitting in her car in the rain , taking a gun out of the glove box while a voice on the radio talks about not being a victim . [SEP] ricky goes to jane ' s bedroom , finding her arguing with angela about angela ' s flirtation with lester . [SEP]
[CLS] ricky convinces jane to flee with him to new york city and assures angela that she is ugly , boring , and ordinary . [SEP] col . fitts confronts lester and attempts to kiss him ; lester rebuffs the colonel , who tearfully flees . [SEP]
[CLS] carolyn puts the gun in her handbag , shouting , " i refuse to be a victim ! " [SEP] lester finds a distraught angela sitting alone in the dark ; she asks him to tell her she is beautiful . [SEP]
[CLS] he does , and they kiss . [SEP] carolyn drives through the rain , rehearsing a confession to lester . [SEP]
[CLS] just as lester and angela are about to have sex , she admits that she is a virgin , and lester changes his mind . [SEP] he instead comforts her and the pair bond over their shared frustrations . [SEP]
[CLS] angela goes to the bathroom and lester smiles at a family photograph in his kitchen . [SEP] an unseen figure raises a gun to the back of his head , a gunshot sounds , and blood sprays on the wall . [SEP]
[CLS] ricky and jane find lester ' s body , while carolyn breaks down crying in the closet . [SEP] a bloodied col . fitts returns home , where a gun is shown to be missing from his collection . [SEP]
[CLS] lester ' s closing narration describes meaningful experiences during his life ; he says that , despite his death , he is happy because there is " so much beauty " in the world . [SEP] scholars and academics have offered many possible readings of american beauty ; film critics are similarly divided , not so much about the quality of the film , as their interpretations of it . [SEP]
[CLS] described by many as about " the meaning of life " or " the hollow existence of the american suburbs " , the film has defied categorization by even the filmmakers . [SEP] mendes is indecisive , saying the script seemed to be about something different each time he read it : " a mystery story , a kaleidoscopic journey through american suburbia , a series of love stories ; [ . . . ] [SEP]
[CLS] it was about imprisonment , [ . . . ] loneliness , [ and ] beauty . [SEP] it was funny ; it was angry , sad . " [SEP]
[CLS] the literary critic and author wayne c . booth concludes that the film resists any one interpretation : " [ american beauty ] cannot be adequately summarized as ' here is a satire on what ' s wrong with american life ' ; that plays down the celebration of beauty . [SEP] it is more tempting to summarize it as ' a portrait of the beauty underlying american miseries and misdeeds ' , but that plays down the scenes of cruelty and horror , and ball ' s disgust with our mores . [SEP]
[CLS] it cannot be summarized with either lester or ricky ' s philosophical statements about what life is or how one should live . " [SEP] he argues that the problem of interpreting the film is tied with that of finding its center — a controlling voice who " [ unites ] all of the choices " . [SEP]
[CLS] he contends that in american beauty ' s case , it is neither mendes nor ball . [SEP] mendes considers the voice to be ball ' s , but even while the writer was " strongly influential " on set , he often had to accept deviations from his vision , particularly ones that transformed the cynical tone of his script into something more optimistic . [SEP]
[CLS] with " innumerable voices intruding on the original author ' s , " booth says , those who interpret american beauty " have forgotten to probe for the elusive center " . [SEP] according to booth , the film ' s true controller is the creative energy " that hundreds of people put into its production , agreeing and disagreeing , inserting and cutting " . [SEP]
[CLS] mendes called american beauty a rite of passage film about imprisonment and escape from imprisonment . [SEP] the monotony of lester ' s existence is established through his gray , nondescript workplace and characterless clothing . [SEP]
[CLS] in these scenes , he is often framed as if trapped , " reiterating rituals that hardly please him " . [SEP] he masturbates in the confines of his shower ; the shower stall evokes a jail cell and the shot is the first of many where lester is confined behind bars or within frames , such as when he is reflected behind columns of numbers on a computer monitor , " confined [ and ] nearly crossed out " . [SEP]
[CLS] the academic and author jody w . pennington argues that lester ' s journey is the story ' s center . [SEP] his sexual reawakening through meeting angela is the first of several turning points as he begins to " [ throw ] off the responsibilities of the comfortable life he has come to despise " . [SEP]
[CLS] after lester shares a joint with ricky , his spirit is released and he begins to rebel against carolyn . [SEP] changed by ricky ' s " attractive , profound confidence " , lester is convinced that angela is attainable and sees that he must question his " banal , numbingly materialist suburban existence " ; he takes a job at a fast @ - @ food outlet , which allows him to regress to a point when he could " see his whole life ahead of him " . [SEP]
[CLS] when lester is caught masturbating by carolyn , his angry retort about their lack of intimacy is the first time he says aloud what he thinks about her . [SEP] by confronting the issue and carolyn ' s " superficial investments in others " , lester is trying to " regain a voice in a home that [ only respects ] the voices of mother and daughter " . [SEP]
[CLS] his final turning point comes when angela and he almost have sex ; after she confesses her virginity , he no longer thinks of her as a sex object , but as a daughter . [SEP] he holds her close and " wraps her up " . [SEP]
[CLS] mendes called it " the most satisfying end to [ lester ' s ] journey there could possibly have been " . [SEP] with these final scenes , mendes intended to show lester at the conclusion of a " mythical quest " . [SEP]
[CLS] after lester gets a beer from the refrigerator , the camera pushes toward him , then stops facing a hallway down which he walks " to meet his fate " . [SEP] having begun to act his age again , lester achieves closure . [SEP]
[CLS] as he smiles at a family photo , the camera pans slowly from lester to the kitchen wall , onto which blood spatters as a gunshot rings out ; the slow pan reflects the peace of lester ' s death . [SEP] his body is discovered by jane and ricky . [SEP]
[CLS] mendes said that ricky ' s staring into lester ' s dead eyes is " the culmination of the theme " of the film : that beauty is found where it is least expected . [SEP] like other american films of 1999 — such as fight club , bringing out the dead , and magnolia , american beauty instructs its audience to " [ lead ] more meaningful lives " . [SEP]
[CLS] the film argues the case against conformity , but does not deny that people need and want it ; even the gay characters just want to fit in . [SEP] jim and jim , the burnhams ' other neighbors , are a satire of " gay bourgeois coupledom " , who " [ invest ] in the numbing sameness " that the film criticizes in heterosexual couples . [SEP]
[CLS] the feminist academic and author sally r . munt argues that american beauty uses its " art house " trappings to direct its message of nonconformity primarily to the middle classes , and that this approach is a " cliche of bourgeois preoccupation ; [ . . . ] [SEP] the underlying premise being that the luxury of finding an individual ' self ' through denial and renunciation is always open to those wealthy enough to choose , and sly enough to present themselves sympathetically as a rebel . " [SEP]
[CLS] professor roy m . anker argues that the film ' s thematic center is its direction to the audience to " look closer " . [SEP] the opening combines an unfamiliar viewpoint of the burnhams ' neighborhood with lester ' s narrated admission that he will soon die , forcing audiences to consider their own mortality and the beauty around them . [SEP]
[CLS] it also sets a series of mysteries ; anker asks , " from what place exactly , and from what state of being , is he telling this story ? [SEP] if he ' s already dead , why bother with whatever it is he wishes to tell about his last year of being alive ? [SEP]
[CLS] there is also the question of how lester has died — or will die . " [SEP] anker believes the preceding scene — jane ' s discussion with ricky about the possibility of his killing her father — adds further mystery . [SEP]
[CLS] professor ann c . hall disagrees ; she says by presenting an early resolution to the mystery , the film allows the audience to put it aside " to view the film and its philosophical issues " . [SEP] through this examination of lester ' s life , rebirth and death , american beauty satirizes american middle class notions of meaning , beauty and satisfaction . [SEP]
[CLS] even lester ' s transformation only comes about because of the possibility of sex with angela ; he therefore remains a " willing devotee of the popular media ' s exaltation of pubescent male sexuality as a sensible route to personal wholeness " . [SEP] carolyn is similarly driven by conventional views of happiness ; from her belief in " house beautiful " domestic bliss to her car and gardening outfit , carolyn ' s domain is a " fetching american millennial vision of pleasantville , or eden " . [SEP]
[CLS] the burnhams are unaware that they are " materialists philosophically , and devout consumers ethically " who expect the " rudiments of american beauty " to give them happiness . [SEP] anker argues that " they are helpless in the face of the prettified economic and sexual stereotypes [ . . . ] that they and their culture have designated for their salvation . " [SEP]
[CLS] the film presents ricky as its " visionary , [ . . . ] spiritual and mystical center " . [SEP] he sees beauty in the minutiae of everyday life , videoing as much as he can for fear of missing it . [SEP]
[CLS] he shows jane what he considers the most beautiful thing he has filmed : a plastic bag , tossing in the wind in front of a wall . [SEP] he says capturing the moment was when he realized that there was " an entire life behind things " ; he feels that " sometimes there ' s so much beauty in the world i feel like i can ' t take it . . . and my heart is going to cave in . " [SEP]
[CLS] anker argues that ricky , in looking past the " cultural dross " , has " [ grasped ] the radiant splendor of the created world " to see god . [SEP] as the film progresses , the burnhams move closer to ricky ' s view of the world . [SEP]
[CLS] lester only forswears personal satisfaction at the film ' s end . [SEP] on the cusp of having sex with angela , he returns to himself after she admits her virginity . [SEP]
[CLS] suddenly confronted with a child , he begins to treat her as a daughter ; in doing so , lester sees himself , angela , and his family " for the poor and fragile but wondrous creatures they are " . [SEP] he looks at a picture of his family in happier times , and dies having had an epiphany that infuses him with " wonder , joy , and soul @ - @ shaking gratitude " — he has finally seen the world as it is . [SEP]
[CLS] according to patti bellantoni , colors are used symbolically throughout the film , none more so than red , which is an important thematic signature that drives the story and " [ defines ] [SEP] lester ' s arc " . [SEP]
[CLS] first seen in drab colors that reflect his passivity , lester surrounds himself with red as he regains his individuality . [SEP] the american beauty rose is repeatedly used as symbol ; when lester fantasizes about angela , she is usually naked and surrounded by rose petals . [SEP]
[CLS] in these scenes , the rose symbolizes lester ' s desire for her . [SEP] when associated with carolyn , the rose represents a " facade for suburban success " . [SEP]
[CLS] roses are included in almost every shot inside the burnhams ' home , where they signify " a mask covering a bleak , unbeautiful reality " . [SEP] carolyn feels that " as long as there can be roses , all is well " . [SEP]
[CLS] she cuts the roses and puts them in vases , where they adorn her " meretricious vision of what makes for beauty " and begin to die . [SEP] the roses in the vase in the angela – lester seduction scene symbolize lester ' s previous life and carolyn ; the camera pushes in as lester and angela get closer , finally taking the roses — and thus carolyn — out of the shot . [SEP]
[CLS] lester ' s epiphany at the end of the film is expressed by rain and the use of red , building to a crescendo that is a deliberate contrast to the release lester feels . [SEP] the constant use of red " lulls [ the audience ] subliminally " into becoming used to it ; consequently , it leaves the audience unprepared when lester is shot and his blood spatters on the wall . [SEP]
[CLS] pennington argues that american beauty defines its characters through their sexuality . [SEP] lester ' s attempts to relive his youth are a direct result of his lust for angela , and the state of his relationship with carolyn is in part shown through their lack of sexual contact . [SEP]
[CLS] also sexually frustrated , carolyn has an affair that takes her from " cold perfectionist " to a more carefree soul who " [ sings ] happily along with " the music in her car . [SEP] jane and angela constantly reference sex , through angela ' s descriptions of her supposed sexual encounters and the way the girls address each other . [SEP]
[CLS] their nude scenes are used to communicate their vulnerability . [SEP] by the end of the film , angela ' s hold on jane has weakened until the only power she has over her friend is lester ' s attraction to her . [SEP]
[CLS] col . fitts reacts with disgust to meeting jim and jim ; he asks , " how come these faggots always have to rub it in your face ? [SEP] how can they be so shameless ? " [SEP]
[CLS] to which ricky replies , " that ' s the thing , dad — they don ' t feel like it ' s anything to be ashamed of . " [SEP] pennington argues that col . fitts ' reaction is not homophobic , but an " anguished self @ - @ interrogation " . [SEP]
[CLS] with other turn @ - @ of @ - @ the @ - @ millennium films such as fight club , in the company of men ( 1997 ) , american psycho ( 2000 ) , and boys don ' t cry ( 1999 ) , american beauty " raises the broader , widely explored issue of masculinity in crisis " . [SEP] professor vincent hausmann charges that in their reinforcement of masculinity " against threats posed by war , by consumerism , and by feminist and queer challenges " , these films present a need to " focus on , and even to privilege " aspects of maleness " deemed ' deviant ' " . [SEP]
[CLS] lester ' s transformation conveys " that he , and not the woman , has borne the brunt of [ lack of being ] " and he will not stand for being emasculated . [SEP] lester ' s attempts to " strengthen traditional masculinity " conflict with his responsibilities as a father . [SEP]
[CLS] although the film portrays the way lester returns to that role positively , he does not become " the hypermasculine figure implicitly celebrated in films like fight club " . [SEP] hausmann concludes that lester ' s behavior toward angela is " a misguided but nearly necessary step toward his becoming a father again " . [SEP]
[CLS] hausmann says the film " explicitly affirms the importance of upholding the prohibition against incest " ; a recurring theme of ball ' s work is his comparison of the taboos against incest and homosexuality . [SEP] instead of making an overt distinction , american beauty looks at how their repression can lead to violence . [SEP]
[CLS] col . fitts is so ashamed of his homosexuality that it drives him to murder lester . [SEP] ball said , " the movie is in part about how homophobia is based in fear and repression and about what [ they ] can do . " [SEP]
[CLS] the film implies two unfulfilled incestuous desires : lester ' s pursuit of angela is a manifestation of his lust for his own daughter , while col . fitts ' repression is exhibited through the almost sexualized discipline with which he controls ricky . [SEP] consequently , ricky realizes that he can only hurt his father by falsely telling him he is homosexual , while angela ' s vulnerability and submission to lester reminds him of his responsibilities and the limits of his fantasy . [SEP]
[CLS] col . fitts represents ball ' s father , whose repressed homosexual desires led to his own unhappiness . [SEP] ball rewrote col . fitts to delay revealing him as homosexual , which munt reads as a possible " deferment of ball ' s own patriarchal @ - @ incest fantasies " . [SEP]
[CLS] american beauty follows a traditional narrative structure , only deviating with the displaced opening scene of jane and ricky from the middle of the story . [SEP] although the plot spans one year , the film is narrated by lester at the moment of his death . [SEP]
[CLS] jacqueline furby says that the plot " occupies [ . . . ] [SEP] no time [ or ] all time " , citing lester ' s claim that life did not flash before his eyes , but that it " stretches on forever like an ocean of time " . [SEP]
[CLS] furby argues that a " rhythm of repetition " forms the core of the film ' s structure . [SEP] for example , two scenes have the burnhams sitting down to an evening meal , shot from the same angle . [SEP]
[CLS] each image is broadly similar , with minor differences in object placement and body language that reflect the changed dynamic brought on by lester ' s new @ - @ found assertiveness . [SEP] another example is the pair of scenes in which jane and ricky film each other . [SEP]
[CLS] ricky films jane from his bedroom window as she removes her bra , and the image is reversed later for a similarly " voyeuristic and exhibitionist " scene in which jane films ricky at a vulnerable moment . [SEP] lester ' s fantasies are emphasized by slow - and repetitive @ - @ motion shots ; mendes uses double @ - @ and @ - @ triple cutbacks in several sequences , and the score alters to make the audience aware that it is entering a fantasy . [SEP]
[CLS] one example is the gymnasium scene — lester ' s first encounter with angela . [SEP] while the cheerleaders perform their half @ - @ time routine to " on broadway " , lester becomes increasingly fixated on angela . [SEP]
[CLS] time slows to represent his " voyeuristic hypnosis " and lester begins to fantasize that angela ' s performance is for him alone . " [SEP] on broadway " — which provides a conventional underscore to the onscreen action — is replaced by discordant , percussive music that lacks melody or progression . [SEP]
[CLS] this nondiegetic score is important to creating the narrative stasis in the sequence ; it conveys a moment for lester that is stretched to an indeterminate length . [SEP] the effect is one that stan link likens to " vertical time " , described by the composer and music theorist jonathan kramer as music that imparts " a single present stretched out into an enormous duration , a potentially infinite ' now ' that nonetheless feels like an instant " . [SEP]
[CLS] the music is used like a visual cue , so that lester and the score are staring at angela . [SEP] the sequence ends with the sudden reintroduction of " on broadway " and teleological time . [SEP]
[CLS] according to drew miller of stylus , the soundtrack " [ gives ] unconscious voice " to the characters ' psyches and complements the subtext . [SEP] the most obvious use of pop music " accompanies and gives context to " lester ' s attempts to recapture his youth ; reminiscent of how the counterculture of the 1960s combated american repression through music and drugs , lester begins to smoke cannabis and listen to rock music . [SEP]
[CLS] mendes ' song choices " progress through the history of american popular music " . [SEP] miller argues that although some may be over familiar , there is a parodic element at work , " making good on [ the film ' s ] encouragement that viewers look closer " . [SEP]
[CLS] toward the end of the film , thomas newman ' s score features more prominently , creating " a disturbing tempo " that matches the tension of the visuals . [SEP] the exception is " don ' t let it bring you down " , which plays during angela ' s seduction of lester . [SEP]
[CLS] at first appropriate , its tone clashes as the seduction stops . [SEP] the lyrics , which speak of " castles burning " , can be seen as a metaphor for lester ' s view of angela — " the rosy , fantasy @ - @ driven exterior of the ' american beauty ' " — as it burns away to reveal " the timid , small @ - @ breasted girl who , like his wife , has willfully developed a false public self " . [SEP]
[CLS] in 1997 , alan ball resolved to move into the film industry after several frustrating years writing for the television sitcoms grace under fire and cybill . [SEP] he joined the united talent agency , where his representative , andrew cannava , suggested he write a spec script to " reintroduce [ himself ] to the town as a screenwriter " . [SEP]
[CLS] ball pitched three ideas to cannava : two conventional romantic comedies and american beauty , which he had originally conceived as a play in the early 1990s . [SEP] despite the story ' s lack of an easily marketable concept , cannava selected american beauty because he felt it was the one for which ball had the most passion . [SEP]
[CLS] while developing the script , ball created another television sitcom , oh , grow up . [SEP] he channeled his anger and frustration at having to accede to network demands on that show — and during his tenures on grace under fire and cybill — into writing american beauty . [SEP]
[CLS] ball did not expect to sell the script , believing it would act as more of a calling card , but american beauty drew interest from several production bodies . [SEP] cannava passed the script to several producers , including dan jinks and bruce cohen , who took it to dreamworks . [SEP]
[CLS] with the help of executives glenn williamson and bob cooper , and steven spielberg in his capacity as studio partner , ball was convinced to develop the project at dreamworks ; he received assurances from the studio — known at the time for its more conventional fare — that it would not " iron the [ edges ] out " . [SEP] in an unusual move , dreamworks decided not to option the script ; instead , in april 1998 , the studio bought it outright for $ 250 @ , @ 000 , outbidding fox searchlight pictures , october films , metro @ - @ goldwyn @ - @ mayer , and lakeshore entertainment . [SEP]
[CLS] dreamworks planned to make the film for $ 6 – 8 million . [SEP] jinks and cohen involved ball throughout the film ' s development , including casting and director selection . [SEP]
[CLS] the producers met with about 20 interested directors , several of whom were considered " a @ - @ list " at the time . [SEP] ball was not keen on the more well @ - @ known directors because he believed their involvement would increase the budget and lead dreamworks to become " nervous about the content " . [SEP]
[CLS] nevertheless , the studio offered the film to mike nichols and robert zemeckis ; neither accepted . [SEP] in the same year , mendes ( then a theater director ) revived the musical cabaret in new york with fellow director rob marshall . [SEP]
[CLS] beth swofford of the creative artists agency arranged meetings for mendes with studio figures in los angeles to see if film direction was a possibility . [SEP] mendes came across american beauty in a pile of eight scripts at swofford ' s house , and knew immediately that it was the one he wanted to make ; early in his career , he had been inspired by how the film paris , texas ( 1984 ) presented contemporary america as a mythic landscape and he saw the same theme in american beauty , as well as parallels with his own childhood . [SEP]
[CLS] mendes later met with spielberg ; impressed by mendes ' productions of oliver ! and cabaret , spielberg encouraged him to consider american beauty . [SEP] mendes found that he still had to convince dreamworks ' production executives to let him direct . [SEP]
[CLS] he had already discussed the film with jinks and cohen , and felt they supported him . [SEP] ball was also keen ; having seen cabaret , he was impressed with mendes ' " keen visual sense " and thought he did not make obvious choices . [SEP]
[CLS] ball felt that mendes liked to look under the story ' s surface , a talent he felt would be a good fit with the themes of american beauty . [SEP] mendes ' background also reassured him , because of the prominent role the playwright usually has in a theater production . [SEP]
[CLS] over two meetings — the first with cooper , walter parkes , and laurie macdonald , the second with cooper alone — mendes pitched himself to the studio . [SEP] the studio soon approached mendes with a deal to direct for the minimum salary allowed under directors guild of america rules — $ 150 @ , @ 000 . [SEP]
[CLS] mendes accepted , and later recalled that after taxes and his agent ' s commission , he only earned $ 38 @ , @ 000 . [SEP] in june 1998 , dreamworks confirmed that it had contracted mendes to direct the film . [SEP]
[CLS] ball was partly inspired by two encounters he had in the early 1990s . [SEP] in about 1991 – 92 , ball saw a plastic bag blowing in the wind outside the world trade center . [SEP]
[CLS] he watched the bag for 10 minutes , saying later that it provoked an " unexpected emotional response " . [SEP] in 1992 , ball became preoccupied with the media circus around the amy fisher trial . [SEP]
[CLS] discovering a comic book telling of the scandal , he was struck by how quickly it had become commercialized . [SEP] he said he " felt like there was a real story underneath [ that was ] more fascinating and way more tragic " than the story presented to the public , and attempted to turn the idea into a play . [SEP]
[CLS] ball produced around 40 pages , but stopped when he realized it would work better as a film . [SEP] he felt that because of the visual themes , and because each character ' s story was . . " intensely personal " , it could not be done on a stage . [SEP]
[CLS] all the main characters appeared in this version , but carolyn did not feature strongly ; jim and jim instead had much larger roles . [SEP] ball based lester ' s story on aspects of his own life . [SEP]
[CLS] lester ' s re @ - @ examination of his life parallels feelings ball had in his mid @ - @ 30s ; like lester , ball put aside his passions to work in jobs he hated for people he did not respect . [SEP] scenes in ricky ' s household reflect ball ' s own childhood experiences . [SEP]
[CLS] ball suspected his father was homosexual and used the idea to create col . fitts , a man who " gave up his chance to be himself " . [SEP] ball said the script ' s mix of comedy and drama was not intentional , but that it came unconsciously from his own outlook on life . [SEP]
[CLS] he said the juxtaposition produced a starker contrast , giving each trait more impact than if they appeared alone . [SEP] in the script that was sent to prospective actors and directors , lester and angela had sex ; by the time of shooting , ball had rewritten the scene to the final version . [SEP]
[CLS] ball initially rebuffed counsel from others that he change the script , feeling they were being puritanical ; the final impetus to alter the scene came from dreamworks ' then @ - @ president walter parkes . [SEP] he convinced ball by indicating that in greek mythology , the hero " has a moment of epiphany before [ . . . ] tragedy occurs " . [SEP]
[CLS] ball later said his anger when writing the first draft had blinded him to the idea that lester needed to refuse sex with angela to complete his emotional journey — to achieve redemption . [SEP] jinks and cohen asked ball not to alter the scene right away , as they felt it would be inappropriate to make changes to the script before a director had been hired . [SEP]
[CLS] early drafts also included a flashback to col . fitts ' service in the marines , a sequence that unequivocally established his homosexual leanings . [SEP] in love with another marine , col . fitts sees the man die and comes to believe that he is being punished for the " sin " of being gay . [SEP]
[CLS] ball removed the sequence because it did not fit the structure of the rest of the film — col . fitts was the only character to have a flashback — and because it removed the element of surprise from col . fitts ' later pass at lester . [SEP] ball said he had to write it for his own benefit to know what happened to col . fitts , though all that remained in later drafts was subtext . [SEP]
[CLS] ball remained involved throughout production ; he had signed a television show development deal , so had to get permission from his producers to take a year off to be close to american beauty . [SEP] ball was on @ - @ set for rewrites and to help interpret his script for all but two days of filming . [SEP]
[CLS] his original bookend scenes — in which ricky and jane are prosecuted for lester ' s murder after being framed by col . fitts — were excised in post @ - @ production ; the writer later felt the scenes were unnecessary , saying they were a reflection of his " anger and cynicism " at the time of writing ( see " editing " ) . [SEP] ball and mendes revised the script twice before it was sent to the actors , and twice more before the first read @ - @ through . [SEP]
[CLS] the shooting script features a scene in angela ' s car in which ricky and jane talk about death and beauty ; the scene differed from earlier versions , which set it as a " big scene on a freeway " in which the three witness a car crash and see a dead body . [SEP] the change was a practical decision , as the production was behind schedule and they needed to cut costs . [SEP]
[CLS] the schedule called for two days to be spent filming the crash , but only half a day was available . [SEP] ball agreed , but only if the scene could retain a line of ricky ' s where he reflects on having once seen a dead homeless woman : " when you see something like that , it ' s like god is looking right at you , just for a second . [SEP]
[CLS] and if you ' re careful , you can look right back . " [SEP] jane asks : " and what do you see ? " [SEP]
[CLS] ricky : " beauty . " [SEP] ball said , " they wanted to cut that scene . [SEP]
[CLS] they said it ' s not important . [SEP] i said , ' you ' re out of your fucking mind . [SEP]
[CLS] it ' s one of the most important scenes in the movie ! ' [SEP] [ . . . ] [SEP]
[CLS] if any one line is the heart and soul of this movie , that is the line . " [SEP] another scene was rewritten to accommodate the loss of the freeway sequence ; set in a schoolyard , it presents a " turning point " for jane in that she chooses to walk home with ricky instead of going with angela . [SEP]
[CLS] by the end of filming , the script had been through 10 drafts . [SEP] mendes had spacey and bening in mind for the leads from the beginning , but dreamworks executives were unenthusiastic . [SEP]
[CLS] the studio suggested several alternatives , including bruce willis , kevin costner , or john travolta to play lester , and helen hunt or holly hunter to play carolyn . [SEP] mendes did not want a big star " weighing the film down " ; he felt spacey was the right choice based on his performances in the 1995 films the usual suspects and seven , and 1992 ' s glengarry glen ross . [SEP]
[CLS] spacey was surprised ; he said , " i usually play characters who are very quick , very manipulative and smart . [SEP] [ . . . ] i usually wade in dark , sort of treacherous waters . [SEP]
[CLS] this is a man living one step at a time , playing by his instincts . [SEP] this is actually much closer to me , to what i am , than those other parts . " [SEP]
[CLS] mendes offered bening the role of carolyn without the studio ' s consent ; although executives were upset at mendes , by september 1998 , dreamworks had entered negotiations with spacey and bening . [SEP] spacey loosely based lester ' s early " schlubby " deportment on walter matthau . [SEP]
[CLS] during the film , lester ' s physique improves from flabby to toned ; spacey worked out during filming to improve his body , but because mendes shot the scenes out of chronological order , spacey varied postures to portray the stages . [SEP] before filming , mendes and spacey analyzed jack lemmon ' s performance in the apartment ( 1960 ) , because mendes wanted spacey to emulate " the way [ lemmon ] moved , the way he looked , the way he was in that office and the way he was an ordinary man and yet a special man " . [SEP]
[CLS] spacey ' s voiceover is a throwback to sunset boulevard ( 1950 ) , which is also narrated in retrospect by a dead character . [SEP] mendes felt it evoked lester ' s — and the film ' s — loneliness . [SEP]
[CLS] bening recalled women from her youth to inform her performance : " i used to babysit constantly . [SEP] you ' d go to church and see how people present themselves on the outside , and then be inside their house and see the difference . " [SEP]
[CLS] bening and a hair stylist collaborated to create a " pta president coif " hairstyle , and mendes and production designer naomi shohan researched mail @ - @ order catalogs to better establish carolyn ' s environment of a " spotless suburban manor " . [SEP] to help bening get into carolyn ' s mindset , mendes gave her music that he believed carolyn would like . [SEP]
[CLS] he lent bening the bobby darin version of the song " don ' t rain on my parade " , which she enjoyed and persuaded the director to include it for a scene in which carolyn sings in her car . [SEP] for the roles of jane , ricky , and angela , dreamworks gave mendes carte blanche . [SEP]
[CLS] by november 1998 , thora birch , wes bentley , and mena suvari had been cast in the parts — in birch ' s case , despite the fact she was underage for her nude scene . [SEP] as birch was 16 at the time she made the film , and thus classified as a minor in the united states , her parents had to approve her brief topless scene in the movie . [SEP]
[CLS] child labor representatives and they were on the set for the shooting of the scene . [SEP] bentley overcame competition from top actors under the age of 25 to be cast . [SEP]
[CLS] the 2009 documentary my big break followed bentley , and several other young actors , before and after he landed the part . [SEP] to prepare , mendes provided bentley with a video camera , telling the actor to film what ricky would . [SEP]
[CLS] peter gallagher and alison janney were cast ( as buddy kane and barbara fitts ) after filming began in december 1998 . [SEP] mendes gave janney a book of paintings by edvard munch . [SEP]
[CLS] he told her , " your character is in there somewhere . " [SEP] mendes cut much of barbara ' s dialogue , including conversations between colonel fitts and her , as he felt that what needed to be said about the pair — their humanity and vulnerability — was conveyed successfully through their shared moments of silence . [SEP]
[CLS] chris cooper plays colonel fitts , scott bakula plays jim olmeyer , and sam robards plays jim berkley . [SEP] jim and jim were deliberately depicted as the most normal , happy — and boring — couple in the film . [SEP]
[CLS] ball ' s inspiration for the characters came from a thought he had after seeing a " bland , boring , heterosexual couple " who wore matching clothes : " i can ' t wait for the time when a gay couple can be just as boring . " [SEP] ball also included aspects of a gay couple he knew who had the same forename . [SEP]
[CLS] mendes insisted on two weeks of cast rehearsals , although the sessions were not as formal as he was used to in the theater , and the actors could not be present at every one . [SEP] several improvisations and suggestions by the actors were incorporated into the script . [SEP]
[CLS] an early scene showing the burnhams leaving home for work was inserted later on to show the low point that carolyn and lester ' s relationship had reached . [SEP] spacey and bening worked to create a sense of the love that lester and carolyn once had for one another ; for example , the scene in which lester almost seduces carolyn after the pair argues over lester ' s buying a car was originally " strictly contentious " . [SEP]
[CLS] principal photography lasted about 50 days from december 14 , 1998 , to february 1999 . [SEP] american beauty was filmed on soundstages at the warner bros . backlot in burbank , california , and at hancock park and brentwood in los angeles . [SEP]
[CLS] the aerial shots at the beginning and end of the film were captured in sacramento , california , and many of the school scenes were shot at south high school in torrance , california ; several extras in the gym crowd were south high students . [SEP] the film is set in an upper middle @ - @ class neighborhood in an unidentified american town . [SEP]
[CLS] production designer naomi shohan likened the locale to evanston , illinois , but said , " it ' s not about a place , it ' s about an archetype . [SEP] [ . . . ] [SEP]
[CLS] the milieu was pretty much anywhere , usa — upwardly mobile suburbia . " [SEP] the intent was for the setting to reflect the characters , who are also archetypes . [SEP]
[CLS] shohan said , " all of them are very strained , and their lives are constructs . " [SEP] the burnhams ' household was designed as the reverse of the fitts ' — the former a pristine ideal , but graceless and lacking in " inner balance " , leading to carolyn ' s desire to at least give it the appearance of a " perfect all @ - @ american household " ; the fitts ' home is depicted in " exaggerated darkness [ and ] symmetry " . [SEP]
[CLS] the production selected two adjacent properties on the warner backlot ' s " blondie street " for the burnham and fitts ' homes . [SEP] the crew rebuilt the houses to incorporate false rooms that established lines of sight — between ricky and jane ' s bedroom windows , and between ricky ' s bedroom and lester ' s garage . [SEP]
[CLS] the garage windows were designed specifically to obtain the crucial shot toward the end of the film in which col . fitts — watching from ricky ' s bedroom — mistakenly assumes that lester is paying ricky for sex . [SEP] mendes made sure to establish the line of sight early on in the film to make the audience feel a sense of familiarity with the shot . [SEP]
[CLS] the house interiors were filmed on the backlot , on location , and on soundstages when overhead shots were needed . [SEP] the inside of the burnhams ' home was shot at a house close to interstate 405 and sunset boulevard in los angeles ; the inside of the fitts ' home was shot in the city ' s hancock park neighborhood . [SEP]
[CLS] ricky ' s bedroom was designed to be cell @ - @ like to suggest his " monkish " personality , while at the same time blending with the high @ - @ tech equipment to reflect his voyeuristic side . [SEP] the production deliberately minimized the use of red , as it was an important thematic signature elsewhere . [SEP]
[CLS] the burnhams ' home uses cool blues , while the fitts ' is kept in a " depressed military palette " . [SEP] mendes ' dominating visual style was deliberate and composed , with a minimalist design that provided " a sparse , almost surreal feeling — a bright , crisp , hard edged , near magritte @ - @ like take on american suburbia " ; mendes constantly directed his set dressers to empty the frame . [SEP]
[CLS] he made lester ' s fantasy scenes " more fluid and graceful " , and mendes made minimal use of steadicams , feeling that stable shots generated more tension . [SEP] for example , when mendes used a slow push in to the burnhams ' dinner table , he held the shot because his training as a theater director taught him the importance of putting distance between the characters . [SEP]
[CLS] he wanted to keep the tension in the scene , so he only cut away when jane left the table . [SEP] mendes did use a hand @ - @ held camera for the scene in which col . fitts beats ricky . [SEP]
[CLS] mendes said the camera provided the scene with a " kinetic [ . . . ] off @ - @ balance energy " . [SEP] he also went hand @ - @ held for the excerpts of ricky ' s camcorder footage . [SEP]
[CLS] mendes took a long time to get the quality of ricky ' s footage to the level he wanted . [SEP] for the plastic @ - @ bag footage , mendes used wind machines to move the bag in the air . [SEP]
[CLS] the scene took four takes ; two by the second unit did not satisfy mendes , so he shot the scene himself . [SEP] he felt his first take lacked grace , but for the last attempt , he changed the location to the front of a brick wall and added leaves on the ground . [SEP]
[CLS] mendes was satisfied by the way the wall gave definition to the outline of the bag . [SEP] mendes avoided using close @ - @ ups , as he believed the technique was overused ; he also cited spielberg ' s advice that he should imagine an audience silhouetted at the bottom of the camera monitor , to keep in mind that he was shooting for display on a 40 @ - @ foot ( 10 m ) screen . [SEP]
[CLS] spielberg — who visited the set a few times — also advised mendes not to worry about costs if he had a " great idea " toward the end of a long working day . [SEP] mendes said , " that happened three or four times , and they are all in the movie . " [SEP]
[CLS] despite spielberg ' s support , dreamworks and mendes fought constantly over the schedule and budget , although the studio interfered little with the film ' s content . [SEP] spacey , bening and hall worked for significantly less than their usual rates . [SEP]
[CLS] american beauty cost dreamworks $ 15 million to produce , slightly above their projected sum . [SEP] mendes was so dissatisfied with his first three days ' filming that he obtained permission from dreamworks to reshoot the scenes . [SEP]
[CLS] he said , " i started with a wrong scene , actually , a comedy scene . [SEP] and the actors played it way too big : [ . . . ] it was badly shot , my fault , badly composed , my fault , bad costumes , my fault [ . . . ] ; and everybody was doing what i was asking . [SEP]
[CLS] it was all my fault . " [SEP] aware that he was a novice , mendes drew on the experience of hall : " i made a very conscious decision early on , if i didn ' t understand something technically , to say , without embarrassment , ' i don ' t understand what you ' re talking about , please explain it . ' [SEP]
[CLS] " mendes encouraged some improvisation ; for example , when lester masturbates in bed beside carolyn , the director asked spacey to improvise several euphemisms for the act in each take . [SEP] mendes said , " i wanted that not just because it was funny [ . . . ] [SEP]
[CLS] but because i didn ' t want it to seem rehearsed . [SEP] i wanted it to seem like he was blurting it out of his mouth without thinking . [SEP]
[CLS] [ spacey ] is so in control — i wanted him to break through . " [SEP] spacey obliged , eventually coming up with 35 phrases , but bening could not always keep a straight face , which meant the scene had to be shot 10 times . [SEP]
[CLS] the production used small amounts of computer @ - @ generated imagery . [SEP] most of the rose petals in lester ' s fantasies were added in post @ - @ production , although some were real and had the wires holding them digitally removed . [SEP]
[CLS] when lester fantasizes about angela in a rose @ - @ petal bath , the steam was real , save for in the overhead shot . [SEP] to position the camera , a hole had to be cut in the ceiling , through which the steam escaped ; it was instead added digitally . [SEP]
[CLS] american beauty was edited by christopher greenbury and tariq anwar ; greenbury began in the position , but had to leave halfway through post @ - @ production because of a scheduling conflict with me , myself and irene ( 2000 ) [SEP] ( in which chris cooper also starred ) . [SEP]
[CLS] mendes and an assistant edited the film for 10 days between the appointments . [SEP] mendes realized during editing that the film was different from the one he had envisioned . [SEP]
[CLS] he believed he had been making a " much more whimsical , [ . . . ] kaleidoscopic " film than what came together in the edit suite . [SEP] instead , mendes was drawn to the emotion and darkness ; he began to use the score and shots he had intended to discard to craft the film along these lines . [SEP]
[CLS] in total , he cut about 30 minutes from his original edit . [SEP] the opening included a dream in which lester imagines himself flying above the town . [SEP]
[CLS] mendes spent two days filming spacey against bluescreen , but removed the sequence as he believed it to be too whimsical — " like a coen brothers movie " — and therefore inappropriate for the tone he was trying to set . [SEP] the opening in the final cut reused a scene from the middle of the film where jane tells ricky to kill her father . [SEP]
[CLS] this scene was to be the revelation to the audience that the pair was not responsible for lester ' s death , as the way it was scored and acted made it clear that jane ' s request was not serious . [SEP] however , in the portion he used in the opening — and when the full scene plays out later — mendes used the score and a reaction shot of ricky to leave a lingering ambiguity as to his guilt . [SEP]
[CLS] the subsequent shot — an aerial view of the neighborhood — was originally intended as the plate shot for the bluescreen effects in the dream sequence . [SEP] mendes spent more time recutting the first 10 minutes than the rest of the film taken together . [SEP]
[CLS] he trialled several versions of the opening ; the first edit included bookend scenes in which jane and ricky are convicted of lester ' s murder , but mendes excised these in the last week of editing because he felt they made the film lose its mystery , and because they did not fit with the theme of redemption that had emerged during production . [SEP] mendes believed the trial drew focus away from the characters and turned the film " into an episode of nypd blue " . [SEP]
[CLS] instead , he wanted the ending to be " a poetic mixture of dream and memory and narrative resolution " . [SEP] when ball first saw a completed edit , it was a version with truncated versions of these scenes . [SEP]
[CLS] he felt that they were so short that they " didn ' t really register " . [SEP] mendes and he argued , but ball was more accepting after mendes cut the sequences completely ; ball felt that without the scenes , the film was more optimistic and had evolved into something that " for all its darkness had a really romantic heart " . [SEP]
[CLS] conrad hall was not the first choice for director of photography ; mendes believed he was " too old and too experienced " to want the job , and he had been told that hall was difficult to work with . [SEP] instead , mendes asked fred elmes , who turned the job down because he did not like the script . [SEP]
[CLS] hall was recommended to mendes by tom cruise , because of hall ' s work on without limits ( 1998 ) , which cruise had executive produced . [SEP] mendes was directing cruise ' s then @ - @ wife nicole kidman in the play the blue room during preproduction on american beauty , and had already storyboarded the whole film . [SEP]
[CLS] hall was involved for one month during preproduction ; his ideas for lighting the film began with his first reading of the script , and further passes allowed him to refine his approach before meeting mendes . [SEP] hall was initially concerned that audiences would not like the characters ; he only felt able to identify with them during cast rehearsals , which gave him fresh ideas on his approach to the visuals . [SEP]
[CLS] hall ' s approach was to create peaceful compositions that evoked classicism , to contrast with the turbulent on @ - @ screen events and allow audiences to take in the action . [SEP] hall and mendes first discussed the intended mood of a scene , but he was allowed to light the shot in any way he felt necessary . [SEP]
[CLS] in most cases , hall first lit the scene ' s subject by " painting in " the blacks and whites , before adding fill light , which he reflected from beadboard or white card on the ceiling . [SEP] this approach gave hall more control over the shadows while keeping the fill light unobtrusive and the dark areas free of spill . [SEP]
[CLS] hall shot american beauty in a 2 @ . @ 39 : 1 aspect ratio in the super 35 format , using kodak vision 500t 5279 35 mm film stock . [SEP] he used super 35 partly because its larger scope allowed him to capture elements such as the corners of the petal @ - @ filled pool in its overhead shot , creating a frame around angela within . [SEP]
[CLS] he shot the whole film at the same t @ - @ stop ( t1 . 9 ) ; given his preference for shooting that wide , hall favored high @ - @ speed stocks to allow for more subtle lighting effects . [SEP] he used panavision platinum cameras with the company ' s primo series of prime and zoom lenses . [SEP]
[CLS] hall employed kodak vision 200t 5274 and exr 5248 stock for scenes with daylight effects . [SEP] he had difficulty adjusting to kodak ' s newly introduced vision release print stock , which , combined with his contrast @ - @ heavy lighting style , created a look with too much contrast . [SEP]
[CLS] hall contacted kodak , who sent him a batch of 5279 that was 5 % lower in contrast . [SEP] hall used a 1 / 8 inch tiffen black promist filter for almost every scene , which he said in retrospect may not have been the best choice , as the optical steps required to blow super 35 up for its anamorphic release print led to a slight amount of degradation ; therefore , the diffusion from the filter was not required . [SEP]
[CLS] when he saw the film in a theater , hall felt that the image was slightly unclear and that had he not used the filter , the diffusion from the super 35 – anamorphic conversion would have generated an image closer to what he originally intended . [SEP] a shot where lester and ricky share a cannabis joint behind a building came from a misunderstanding between hall and mendes . [SEP]
[CLS] mendes asked hall to prepare the shot in his absence ; hall assumed the characters would look for privacy , so he placed them in a narrow passage between a truck and the building , intending to light from the top of the truck . [SEP] when mendes returned , he explained that the characters did not care if they were seen . [SEP]
[CLS] he removed the truck and hall had to rethink the lighting ; he lit it from the left , with a large light crossing the actors , and with a soft light behind the camera . [SEP] hall felt the consequent wide shot " worked perfectly for the tone of the scene " . [SEP]
[CLS] hall made sure to keep rain , or the suggestion of it , in every shot near the end of the film . [SEP] in one shot during lester ' s encounter with angela at the burnhams ' home , hall created rain effects on the foreground cross lights ; in another , he partly lit the pair through french windows to which he had added material to make the rain run slower , intensifying the light ( although the strength of the outside light was unrealistic for a night scene , hall felt it justified because of the strong contrasts it produced ) . [SEP]
[CLS] for the close @ - @ ups when lester and angela move to the couch , hall tried to keep rain in the frame , lighting through the window onto the ceiling behind lester . [SEP] he also used rain boxes to produce rain patterns where he wanted without lighting the entire room . [SEP]
[CLS] thomas newman ' s score was recorded in santa monica , california . [SEP] he mainly used percussion instruments to create the mood and rhythm , the inspiration for which was provided by mendes . [SEP]
[CLS] newman " favored pulse , rhythm , and color over melody " , making for a more minimalist score than he had previously created . [SEP] he built each cue around " small , endlessly repeating phrases " — often , the only variety through a " thinning of the texture for eight bars " . [SEP]
[CLS] the percussion instruments included tablas , bongos , cymbals , piano , xylophones , and marimbas ; also featured were guitars , flute , and world music instruments . [SEP] newman also used electronic music and on " quirkier " tracks employed more unorthodox methods , such as tapping metal mixing bowls with a finger and using a detuned mandolin . [SEP]
[CLS] newman believed the score helped move the film along without disturbing the " moral ambiguity " of the script : " it was a real delicate balancing act in terms of what music worked to preserve [ that ] . [SEP] jackson said mendes ' theatrical roots rarely showed , and that the " most remarkable " aspect was that spacey ' s performance did not overshadow the film . [SEP]

[CLS] he said mendes ' " sure hand " was " as precise and controlled " as his theater work . [SEP] mccarthy cited hall ' s involvement as fortunate for mendes , as the cinematographer was " unsurpassed " at conveying the themes of a work . [SEP]

[CLS] turan felt that mendes ' accomplishment was to " capture and enhance [ the ] duality " of ball ' s script — the simultaneously " caricatured [ . . . ] and painfully real " characters . [SEP] hentzi , while critical of many of mendes and ball ' s choices , admitted the film showed off their " considerable talents " . [SEP]
[CLS] turan cited ball ' s lack of constraint when writing the film as the reason for its uniqueness , in particular the script ' s subtle changes in tone . [SEP] mccarthy said the script was " as fresh and distinctive " as any of its american film contemporaries , and praised how it analyzed the characters while not compromising narrative pace . [SEP]
[CLS] he called ball ' s dialogue " tart " and said the characters — carolyn excepted — were " deeply drawn " . [SEP] one other flaw , mccarthy said , was the revelation of col . fitts ' homosexuality , which he said evoked " hoary freudianism " . [SEP]
[CLS] jackson said the film transcended its cliched setup to become a " wonderfully resourceful and sombre comedy " . [SEP] he said that even when the film played for sitcom laughs , it did so with " unexpected nuance " . [SEP]

[SEP] hentzi concluded that american beauty was " vital but uneven " ; he felt the film ' s examination of " the ways which teenagers and adults imagine each other ' s lives " was its best point , and that although lester and angela ' s dynamic was familiar , its romantic irony stood beside " the most enduring literary treatments " of the theme , such as lolita . [SEP]
[CLS] nevertheless , hentzi believed that the film ' s themes of materialism and conformity in american suburbia were " hackneyed " . [SEP] mccarthy conceded that the setting was familiar , but said it merely provided the film with a " starting point " from which to tell its " subtle and acutely judged tale " . [SEP]
[CLS] maslin agreed ; she said that while it " takes aim at targets that are none too fresh " , and that the theme of nonconformity did not surprise , the film had its own " corrosive novelty " . [SEP] ebert awarded american beauty four stars out of four , and turan said it was layered , subversive , complex , and surprising , concluding it was " a hell of a picture " . [SEP]
[CLS] a few months after the film ' s release , reports of a backlash appeared in the american press , and the years since have seen its critical regard wane . [SEP] in 2005 , premiere named american beauty as one of 20 " most overrated movies of all time " ; [SEP]
[CLS] mendes accepted the inevitability of the critical reappraisal , saying , " i thought some of it was entirely justified — it was a little overpraised at the time . " [SEP] currently , the film holds an 88 % score on rotten tomatoes based on 180 reviews , with an average rating of 8 @ . @ 2 / 10 ; the critical consensus reads , " flawlessly cast and brimming with dark , acid wit , american beauty is a smart , provocative high point of late ' 90s mainstream hollywood film . " [SEP]
[CLS] metacritic gives the film a score of 86 , based on 33 reviews , indicating " universal acclaim . " [SEP] american beauty was not considered an immediate favorite to dominate the american awards season . [SEP]
[CLS] several other contenders opened at the end of 1999 , and us critics spread their honors among them when compiling their end @ - @ of @ - @ year lists . [SEP] the chicago film critics association and the broadcast film critics association named the film the best of 1999 , but while the new york film critics circle , the national society of film critics and the los angeles film critics association recognized american beauty , they gave their top awards to other films . [CLS] by the end of the year , reports of a critical backlash suggested american beauty was the underdog in the race for best picture ; however , at the golden globe awards in january 2000 , american beauty won best film , best director and best screenplay . [SEP] as the nominations for the 72nd academy awards approached , a frontrunner had not emerged . [SEP]
[CLS] dreamworks had launched a major campaign for american beauty five weeks before ballots were due to be sent to the 5 @ , @ 600 academy award voters . [SEP] its campaign combined traditional advertising and publicity with more focused strategies . [SEP]
[CLS] although direct mail campaigning was prohibited , dreamworks reached voters by promoting the film in " casual , comfortable settings " in voters ' communities . [SEP] the studio ' s candidate for best picture the previous year , saving private ryan , lost to shakespeare in love , so the studio took a new approach by hiring outsiders to provide input for the campaign . [SEP] in february 2000 , american beauty was nominated for eight academy awards ; its closest rivals , the cider house rules and the insider , received seven nominations each . [SEP]
[CLS] in march 2000 , the major industry labor organizations all awarded their top honors to american beauty ; perceptions had shifted — the film was now the favorite to dominate the academy awards . [SEP] american beauty ' s closest rival for best picture was still the cider house rules , from miramax . [SEP]

[SEP] on march 26 , 2000 , american beauty won five academy awards : best picture , best director , best actor ( spacey ) , best original screenplay and best cinematography . [SEP]
[CLS] at the 53rd british academy film awards , american beauty won six of the 14 awards for which it was nominated : best film , best actor , best actress ( bening ) , best cinematography , best film music and best editing . [SEP] in 2000 , the publicists guild of america recognized dreamworks for the best film publicity campaign . [SEP]
[CLS] in september 2008 , empire named american beauty the 96th " greatest movie of all time " after a poll of 10 @ , @ 000 readers , 150 filmmakers , and 50 film critics , the fourth @ - @ highest ranked movie from 1999 ( behind fight club , the matrix , and magnolia ) . [SEP] in 2013 , the writers guild of america ranked the screenplay number 38 on its list of 101 greatest screenplays . [SEP]
[CLS] the film was nominated for afi ' s 100 years . . . 100 movies ( 10th anniversary edition ) in 2007 . [SEP] christopher gore ( september 21 , 1758 – march 1 , 1827 ) was a prominent massachusetts lawyer , federalist politician , and u . s . diplomat . [SEP]
[CLS] born into a family divided by the american revolution , gore sided with the victorious patriots , established a successful law practice in boston , and built a fortune by purchasing revolutionary government debts at a discount and receiving full value for them from the government . [SEP] gore entered politics in 1788 , serving briefly in the massachusetts legislature before being appointed u . s . district attorney for massachusetts . [SEP]
[CLS] he was then appointed by president george washington to a diplomatic commission dealing with maritime claims in great britain . [SEP] he returned to massachusetts in 1804 and reentered state politics , running unsuccessfully for governor several times before winning in 1809 . [SEP]
[CLS] he served one term , losing to democratic @ - @ republican elbridge gerry in 1810 . [SEP] he was appointed to the us senate by governor caleb strong in 1813 , where he led opposition to the war of 1812 . [SEP]
[CLS] gore invested his fortune in a variety of businesses , including important infrastructure projects such as the middlesex canal and a bridge across the charles river . [SEP] he was a major investor in the early textile industry , funding the boston manufacturing company and the merrimack manufacturing company , whose business established the city of lowell , massachusetts . [SEP]
