[CLS] gore was involved in a variety of charitable causes , and was a major benefactor of harvard college , where the first library was named in his honor . [SEP] his palatial mansion in waltham , massachusetts , now known as gore place , is one of the finest extant examples of federalist architecture , and has been declared a national historic landmark . [SEP]
[CLS] christopher gore was born in boston on september 21 , 1758 , one of many children of frances and john gore , a successful merchant and artisan . [SEP] he was the youngest of their three sons to survive to adulthood . [SEP]
[CLS] he attended boston latin school , and entered harvard college at the young ( even for the time ) age of thirteen . [SEP] at the outset of the american revolutionary war and the siege of boston in 1775 , harvard ' s buildings were occupied by the continental army , and gore temporarily continued his studies in bradford until harvard could resume operations in concord . [SEP]
[CLS] while at harvard gore participated in a speaking club , and formed significant lifelong friendships with rufus king and john trumbull . [SEP] gore graduated in 1776 , and promptly enlisted in the continental artillery regiment of his brother @ - @ in @ - @ law thomas crafts , where he served as a clerk until 1778 . [SEP]
[CLS] the gore family was divided by the war : gore ' s father was a loyalist who left boston when the british army evacuated the city in march 1776 . [SEP] gore was consequently called upon to support his mother and three sisters , who remained in boston . [SEP]
[CLS] in 1779 gore successfully petitioned the state for the remaining family ' s share of his father ' s seized assets . [SEP] after his military service gore studied law with john lowell , and was admitted to the bar in 1778 after a comparatively brief tutelage . [SEP]
[CLS] gore ' s law practice flourished , in part because many loyalist lawyers had fled massachusetts . [SEP] gore ' s clients included loyalists seeking to recover some of their assets , as well as london @ - @ based british merchants with claims to pursue . [SEP]
[CLS] his briefs were generally well @ - @ reasoned , and he was seen as a successful trial lawyer . [SEP] gore grew his fortune by investing carefully in revolutionary currency and bonds . [SEP]
[CLS] the securities he purchased were paper that had been given to continental army soldiers in lieu of pay , which they often sold at a steep discount . [SEP] one batch of securities he purchased , for instance , cost him about $ 3 @ , @ 700 but had a face value of $ 25 @ , @ 000 . [SEP]
[CLS] in 1785 he married rebecca amory payne , daughter of a wealthy merchant , maritime insurer , and director of the bank of massachusetts . [SEP] the couple were known for their social graces and became prominent members of boston society . [SEP]
[CLS] in 1786 gore became concerned about a rise in anti @ - @ lawyer sentiment in massachusetts . [SEP] grievances over harsh policies pursued by governor james bowdoin blossomed into shays ' rebellion , which required militia action to crush in 1787 . [SEP]
[CLS] gore was one of several high @ - @ profile lawyers assigned to defend participants in the rebellion ( included in this group were theodore sedgwick , caleb strong , james sullivan , levi lincoln , sr . , and thomas dawes ) . [SEP] although many rebels were ultimately convicted , a large number received amnesty . [SEP]
[CLS] in 1788 , gore was elected a delegate to the 1789 massachusetts convention that ratified the united states constitution . [SEP] his election was contested because boston , where he lived , was at the time more inclined toward state power . [SEP]
[CLS] gore nonetheless was strongly federalist , urging support of the new constitution . [SEP] in 1788 gore was elected to the massachusetts house of representatives . [SEP]
[CLS] he took a leading role in adopting the state ' s rules for actions required of it by the new federal constitution . [SEP] by his proposal the legislature decided that presidential electors would be chosen by a joint session . [SEP]
[CLS] he also proposed that the state house and senate agree by separate votes on choices for the united states senate , a process that would significantly reduce popular input to the choice . [SEP] his choice was ultimately rejected in favor of a process whereby the house selected a slate of candidates , from which the senate would choose one . [SEP]
[CLS] in 1789 gore decided to stand for reelection , but lost , owing to strong anti @ - @ nationalist fervor in boston at the time . [SEP] he managed to win a seat later , when a special election was held after resignations opened several seats . [SEP]
[CLS] gore ' s financial speculations in the late 1780s significantly multiplied his wealth . [SEP] in 1788 he and andrew craigie , a boston businessman who had retained gore for legal services , entered into a secret agreement to purchase continental securities with a face value of $ 100 @ , @ 000 in a speculative bid that their value would rise . [SEP]
[CLS] by late october of that year , the pair had met this goal : gore had purchased $ 90 @ , @ 000 worth of paper for about $ 20 @ , @ 000 , and encouraged craigie to purchase more than the $ 11 @ , @ 000 he had acquired if his funding would allow for it . [SEP] gore also purchased massachusetts war @ - @ related debts , and lobbied massachusetts congressmen for the u . s . government to assume those as well . [SEP]
[CLS] gore ' s windfall was realized when in 1790 the united states congress , acting on a proposal made by alexander hamilton and supported by gore ' s friend rufus king , passed legislation that exchanged continental and state paper for new u . s . paper at face value . [SEP] not only did gore win on this exchange , but the paper he received appreciated in value before he sold it . [SEP]
[CLS] the exact amount he made is unclear from the surviving documents : john quincy adams wrote that gore ' s speculations made him the wealthiest lawyer in the country . [SEP] the success of gore ' s speculations prompted him to enter a partnership with craigie , william duer and daniel parker in an attempt to acquire u . s . foreign debt obligations on favorable terms . [SEP]
[CLS] parker was a business partner of craigie ' s , and duer was an influential new york businessman and treasury department official whose lavish lifestyle impressed gore . [SEP] the partnership promoted sales of u . s . lands in europe , and sought to acquire u . s . obligations to france . [SEP]
[CLS] although gore sank $ 10 @ , @ 000 into this venture , it failed : more powerful and experienced dutch bankers outmaneuvered the americans . [SEP] gore also engaged in other ventures with these partners , but apparently carefully stayed with financial speculations , and avoided the partners ' less successful land ventures . [SEP]
[CLS] much of gore ' s financial activity was mediated through the bank of massachusetts , where his father @ - @ in @ - @ law was a director . [SEP] gore himself was elected to its board in 1785 , when he also became a shareholder . [SEP]
[CLS] during his time on the board the bank tightened its regulations on loan repayments , a move that improved the stability of its capital . [SEP] gore used the bank for most of his personal deposits , but also drew on lines of credit for as much as several thousand dollars . [SEP]
[CLS] the bank shares he held paid relatively high dividends until 1791 , when the bank received serious competition from the first bank of the united states . [SEP] the bank of the united states was established by alexander hamilton to provide stable banking services on a national scale , and sought to open a branch in boston . [SEP]
[CLS] hamilton recruited heavily in the bank of massachusetts , and gore decided to make the move . [SEP] he sold his shares in the massachusetts bank , and became a director of the boston branch of the u . s . bank . [SEP]
[CLS] he also purchased 200 shares in the new bank , a relatively large investment . [SEP] gore was influential in making hiring decisions for the branch , and sought to merge state @ - @ chartered banks into the organization , arguing that only a nationally chartered bank could provide consistent and stable service . [SEP]
[CLS] gore resigned from the board in 1794 , citing the demands of his law practice . [SEP] gore ' s financial successes enabled him to join the elite society of boston . [SEP]
[CLS] in 1789 he purchased a large mansion on fashionable bowdoin square , and also bought a country estate in waltham that grew over time to 300 acres ( 120 ha ) . [SEP] he had a house built on the estate , most of which he operated as a gentleman farmer . [SEP]
[CLS] he and other similarly @ - @ situated federalists formed the massachusetts society for promoting agriculture , of which he served as a trustee for several years ; the organization was not seen as significantly contributing to advances in agriculture . [SEP] in 1789 president george washington appointed gore the first united states attorney for massachusetts as a reward for his support . [SEP]
[CLS] gore controversially refused to resign from the state legislature , arguing that the state constitution ' s prohibitions against holding multiple offices did not apply to federal posts . [SEP] he eventually resigned the legislative seat under protest because of pressure from his fellow legislators . [SEP]
[CLS] gore served as district attorney until 1796 . [SEP] his principal matter of concern was the enforcement of u . s . neutrality with respect to the french revolutionary wars . [SEP]
[CLS] he attempted several times to prosecute the french consul in boston , antoine duplaine , for arming and operating privateers out of the port of boston , but he was stymied by local juries that sympathized with the french . [SEP] duplaine was eventually expelled on orders from president george washington based on evidence provided by gore . [SEP]
[CLS] gore also promoted anti @ - @ french sentiment with political writings in massachusetts newspapers . [SEP] writing under the pseudonym " manlius " , he denounced the formation of " democratic societies " formed to oppose federalist policy and support pro @ - @ french positions . [SEP]
[CLS] he suggested to president washington that someone be sent to england to negotiate with the british . [SEP] john jay traveled to london in 1794 and negotiated the jay treaty , whose ratification gore vocally supported . [SEP]
[CLS] although gore was hostile to french policy , he was on friendly terms with individual frenchmen : he hosted the future french statesman talleyrand when he visited the u . s . [SEP] in 1796 washington appointed him as a commissioner representing the united states to handle maritime claims under the terms the jay treaty . [SEP]
[CLS] as a result the gores moved to england that year , establishing a residence in the fashionable hyde park area . [SEP] the commission was established to arbitrate claims emanating from british seizures of american vessels and cargoes , and from british claims relating to violations of american neutrality in the ongoing french revolutionary wars . [SEP]
[CLS] it consisted of three americans ( gore , william pinkney , and john trumbull ) and two british commissioners ( john nicoll and nicholas astley ) ; trumbull was chosen by the other four because he was deemed to sufficiently " fair @ - @ minded " to cast deciding votes in the event of disagreements . [SEP] that year he was also elected a fellow of the american academy of arts and sciences . [SEP]
[CLS] although gore was well received by the british establishment , the work suffered from what gore called a " tediousness of process " , and he considered requesting a transfer in 1798 . [SEP] in 1800 it ground to a halt because another board established by the treaty to resolve outstanding revolutionary war claims against the united states had not yet met , and the british stopped the claims processing until resolution of the other issues got underway . [SEP]
[CLS] gore used this break to briefly return to america and assess the condition of his waltham estate , where the house had been largely destroyed by fire in 1799 . [SEP] after his return to london , with the commission work still stopped , he and rebecca embarked on a tour of europe . [SEP]
[CLS] they visited holland , belgium , and switzerland , and spent six months in paris . [SEP] during this trip , and later ones in england and scotland , they took note of the architecture of country estates , and began planning a new house for their waltham property . [SEP]
[CLS] the commission resumed its work in early 1802 , and had resolved all outstanding claims by august 1803 . [SEP] it awarded $ 110 @ , @ 000 to british claimants and over $ 6 million to american claimants . [SEP]
[CLS] the lopsided result is due to the vastly larger number of american claims , but also to some key early decisions that favored american interpretations in the processing of the claims , and by a british administration that sought to remain in america ' s good graces . [SEP] the gore ' s social circle in england revolved around his good friend rufus king , who was appointed ambassador to great britain in 1796 , along with other massachusetts expatriates . [SEP]
[CLS] when king left his post in may 1803 he named gore to head the london embassy as charge d ' affaires . [SEP] although president thomas jefferson never issued a formal appointment , the british government accepted his role for the two @ - @ month interval between king ' s departure and the arrival of james monroe as king ' s replacement . [SEP]
[CLS] the gores sailed for boston in the spring of 1804 . [SEP] rebecca gore used their exposure to european country estates to design a lavish new building for their waltham estate during their english sojourn . [SEP]
[CLS] designed with the assistance of french architect joseph @ - @ guillaume legrand and probably also influenced by the works of english architect sir john soane , the house that was built upon their return to the united states in 1804 ( now known as gore place ) is one of the finest extant examples of federalist architecture . [SEP] soon after his return to the united states , gore reentered state politics , winning election to the massachusetts senate . [SEP]
[CLS] he was active in the state federalist party organization , sitting on its secret central committee . [SEP] he resumed his law practice , in which he took on as a student daniel webster . [SEP]
[CLS] one of the highest profile cases he took on was the 1807 defense of thomas selfridge , accused of murdering charles austin . [SEP] selfridge , an older federalist attorney , had been retained to assist in the collection of a debt from austin ' s republican father . [SEP]
[CLS] in the politically charged atmosphere of the day in boston , selfridge , fearing for his own safety , had armed himself with a dueling pistol . [SEP] the younger austin had , apparently on his own initiative , sought to beat selfridge with a cane , and selfridge fatally shot him in the encounter . [SEP]
[CLS] selfridge was prosecuted by attorney general ( and future gore gubernatorial opponent ) [SEP] james sullivan , and the defense also included arch @ - @ federalist harrison gray otis . [SEP]
[CLS] gore argued selfridge acted in self @ - @ defense ; selfridge was acquitted of murder by a jury whose foreman was patriot and federalist paul [SEP] revere after fifteen minutes ' deliberation . [SEP]
[CLS] gore also resumed business activities upon his return . [SEP] he invested in a wide variety of businesses and infrastructure , spurring economic activity in the state . [SEP]
[CLS] his investments ranged widely , including maritime insurance ( where is father @ - @ in @ - @ law had made his fortune ) , bridges , locks , canals , and textiles . [SEP] he was a major investor in the middlesex canal , the craigie bridge ( the first to connect boston to cambridge ) , and the boston manufacturing company , whose factory proving the single @ - @ site production of textiles was in waltham near his estate . [SEP]
[CLS] not all of his ventures panned out : the canal was in the long run a financial failure , as were efforts with other collaborators to develop lechmere point , the cambridge side of the craigie bridge . [SEP] the textile mill , however , was a success , and gore invested in the merrimack manufacturing company . [SEP]
[CLS] when it decided to locate in what is now lowell , massachusetts , gore purchased shares in the proprietors of locks and canals , which operated ( and still owns today ) [SEP] the lowell canals . [SEP]
[CLS] in 1806 gore won election to the state senate . [SEP] that year the republicans were in the majority , and the election for governor was close enough to require a recount . [SEP]
[CLS] the legislature scrutinized the ballots in a partisan manner ( for example , retaining ballots containing misspelled versions of republican james sullivan ' s name and discarding similar ballots marked for federalist caleb strong ) . [SEP] gore and other federalists raised a public outcry , and the legislature relented , eventually certifying strong as the winner . [SEP]
[CLS] gore ran unsuccessfully for governor of massachusetts in 1807 and 1808 against a rising tide of republicanism in the state , losing both times to moderate republican james sullivan . [SEP] the federalists gained control of the state legislature in 1808 in a backlash against republican economic policies , but gore was criticized for his failure to aggressively support state protests against the embargo act of 1807 , which had a major negative effect on the state ' s large merchant fleet . [SEP]
[CLS] gore was in 1808 elected to the massachusetts house of representatives , where he successfully led federalist efforts to ensure the selection of a federalist slate of presidential electors . [SEP] he also spearheaded actions to drive senator john quincy adams from the federalist party over his support of thomas jefferson ' s foreign policy . [SEP]
[CLS] the legislature elected adams ' successor nine months early , and gave adams sufficiently distasteful instructions that he resigned the post and joined with the republicans . [SEP] gore led the federalists to victory in 1809 against sullivan ' s successor , levi lincoln , sr . , who had taken over as acting governor upon sullivan ' s death late in 1808 . [SEP]
[CLS] during gore ' s term the principal domestic issue occupying state politics was a banking crisis stimulated by the federal policy of embargoing trade with great britain and france , then embroiled in the napoleonic wars . [SEP] although the crisis caused a number of bank failures in new england , massachusetts banks largely escaped unscathed . [SEP]
[CLS] foreign policy played a major role in gore ' s administration . [SEP] the legislature passed resolves opposing the federal government ' s hardline policy against trade and diplomatic relations with the united kingdom ( then embroiled in the napoleonic wars ) , and gore in early 1810 invited francis james jackson , who had been rejected as the uk ' s ambassador to the us , to visit the state . [SEP]
[CLS] this pressure may have played a role in president james madison ' s decision to renew relations with the uk and accept jackson ' s credentials . [SEP] the lessening of the war threat , and the choice by the republicans of the popular elbridge gerry as their candidate brought a challenge to federalist control of massachusetts in the 1810 elections . [SEP]
[CLS] the unostentatious gerry and republican partisans criticized gore for his lavish lifestyle , including his palatial waltham residence and pompous activities he organized as governor , and highlighted his loyalist family connections while emphasizing gerry ' s unimpeachable patriotism . [SEP] gerry won the election . [SEP]
[CLS] jackson did visit boston , but he was greeted not by gore , but gerry . [SEP] gore ran against gerry again in 1811 , but lost in another acrimonious campaign . [SEP]
[CLS] gore was granted an honorary law degree from harvard in 1809 . [SEP] he served on the college ' s board of overseers from 1810 to 1815 and as a fellow from 1816 to 1820 . [SEP]
[CLS] harvard ' s first library building , a gothic structure built in 1838 of quincy granite , was named in his honor , but was demolished when widener library was built in its place in 1915 . [SEP] ( this structure is found on the seal of the city of cambridge . ) [SEP]
[CLS] one of the residential winthrop house ' s buildings is called gore hall in his honor . [SEP] in the spring of 1813 , he was appointed by governor caleb strong to fill the u . s . senate seat vacated by the resignation of senator james lloyd . [SEP]
[CLS] he served from may 5 , 1813 to may 30 , 1816 , winning reelection to the seat in 1814 . [SEP] he opposed the ongoing war of 1812 in these years , with his earlier diplomatic experience providing valuable knowledge to federalist interests . [SEP]
[CLS] he expressed approval of the 1814 hartford convention in which the new england states aired grievances concerning republican governance of the country and the conduct of the war . [SEP] gore assented to the treaty of ghent that ended the war , but was unhappy that the nation had not gained anything from the war . [SEP]
[CLS] he resigned in june 1816 , unhappy with the politics of washington and suffering from poor health . [SEP] although he was no longer active in politics , he continued to express opinions on the subjects of the day , opposing the 1820 missouri compromise and bemoaning the " great moderation & mediocrity " of federalist governor john brooks . [SEP]
[CLS] gore remained active in the administration of harvard , and was active in a number of organizations , including the american academy of arts and sciences and the massachusetts historical society ( whose president he was from 1806 to 1818 ) . [SEP] he was also elected a member of the american antiquarian society in 1814 . [SEP]
[CLS] gore spent most of his later years at his country estate in waltham , suffering from worsening rheumatoid arthritis that made walking increasingly difficult . [SEP] his declining health and lack of social scene in waltham led him in 1822 to return to boston in the winters . [SEP]
[CLS] he died on march 1 , 1827 in boston and is buried in its granary burying ground . [SEP] gore ' s wife died in 1834 ; the couple had no children . [SEP]
[CLS] the major beneficiary of the gore estate was harvard ( which received an estimated $ 100 @ , @ 000 ) , although bequests were also made to the american academy of arts and sciences and the massachusetts historical society . [SEP] the waltham estate passed through several hands and was subdivided over time . [SEP]
[CLS] the mansion was saved from demolition by the gore place society ( established for the purpose of preserving it ) , which now operates it as a museum . [SEP] it was declared a national historic landmark in 1970 . [SEP]
[CLS] nero ( / ˈnɪəroʊ / ; latin : [SEP] nero claudius caesar augustus germanicus ; 15 december 37 ad – 9 june 68 ad ) was roman emperor from 54 to 68 , and the last in the julio @ - @ claudian dynasty . [SEP]
[CLS] nero was adopted by his grand @ - @ uncle claudius to become his heir and successor , and succeeded to the throne in 54 following claudius ' death . [SEP] nero focused much of his attention on diplomacy , trade and enhancing the cultural life of the empire , but according to the historian tacitus he was viewed by the roman people as compulsive and corrupt . [SEP]
[CLS] he ordered theatres built and promoted athletic games . [SEP] during his reign , the redoubtable general corbulo conducted a successful war and negotiated peace with the parthian empire . [SEP]
[CLS] his general suetonius paulinus crushed a revolt in britain . [SEP] nero annexed the bosporan kingdom to the empire and began the first jewish – roman war . [SEP]
[CLS] in 64 ad , most of rome was destroyed in the great fire of rome , which many romans believed nero himself had started in order to clear land for his planned palatial complex , the domus aurea . [SEP] in 68 , the rebellion of vindex in gaul and later the acclamation of galba in hispania drove nero from the throne . [SEP]
[CLS] facing a false report of being denounced as a public enemy who was to be executed , he committed suicide on 9 june 68 ( the first roman emperor to do so ) . [SEP] his death ended the julio @ - @ claudian dynasty , sparking a brief period of civil wars known as the year of the four emperors . [SEP]
[CLS] nero ' s rule is often associated with tyranny and extravagance . [SEP] he is known for many executions , including that of his mother , and the probable murder by poison of his stepbrother britannicus . [SEP]
[CLS] nero was rumored to have had captured christians dipped in oil and set on fire in his garden at night as a source of light . [SEP] this view is based on the writings of tacitus , suetonius and cassius dio , the main surviving sources for nero ' s reign , but a few surviving sources paint nero in a more favourable light . [SEP]
[CLS] some sources , including some mentioned above , portray him as an emperor who was popular with the common roman people , especially in the east . [SEP] some modern historians question the reliability of ancient sources when reporting on nero ' s tyrannical acts . [SEP]
[CLS] lucius domitius ahenobarbus , nero , was born on 15 december 37 in antium ( modern anzio and nettuno ) , near rome . [SEP] he was the only son of gnaeus domitius ahenobarbus and agrippina the younger , sister of emperor caligula . [SEP]
[CLS] nero ' s father , gnaeus , was the son of lucius domitius ahenobarbus ( consul 16 bc ) and antonia major . [SEP] gnaeus was thus the grandson of gnaeus domitius ahenobarbus ( consul 32 bc ) and probably aemilia lepida on his father ' s side , and the grandson of mark antony and octavia minor on his mother ' s side . [SEP]
[CLS] thus , nero had as his paternal grandmother antonia major , and also claimed more remote descent from antonia minor as a great @ - @ grandson — later grandson after claudius adopted him . [SEP] through octavia , nero was the great @ - @ nephew of caesar augustus . [SEP]
[CLS] nero ' s father had been employed as a praetor and was a member of caligula ' s staff when the latter travelled to the east ( some apparently think suetonius refers to augustus ' s adopted son gaius caesar here , but this is not likely ) . [SEP] nero ' s father was described by suetonius as a murderer and a cheat who was charged by emperor tiberius with treason , adultery and incest . [SEP]
[CLS] tiberius died , allowing him to escape these charges . [SEP] nero ' s father died of edema ( " dropsy " ) in 39 when nero was two . [SEP]
[CLS] nero ' s mother was agrippina the younger , a great @ - @ granddaughter of caesar augustus and his wife scribonia through their daughter julia the elder and her husband marcus vipsanius agrippa . [SEP] agrippina ' s father , germanicus , was a grandson of augustus ' s wife , livia , on one side and to mark antony and octavia on the other . [SEP]
[CLS] germanicus ' mother antonia minor , was a daughter of octavia minor and mark antony . [SEP] octavia was augustus ' elder sister . [SEP]
[CLS] germanicus was also the adopted son of tiberius . [SEP] agrippina poisoned her second husband passienus crispus , so many ancient historians also accuse her of murdering her third husband , the emperor claudius . [SEP]
[CLS] nero was not expected to become emperor because his maternal uncle , caligula , had begun his reign at the age of 24 with enough time to produce his own heir . [SEP] nero ' s mother , agrippina , lost favour with caligula and was exiled in 39 after her husband ' s death . [SEP]
[CLS] caligula seized nero ' s inheritance and sent him to be brought up by his less wealthy aunt , domitia lepida , who was the mother of valeria messalina , claudius ' s third wife . [SEP] caligula , his wife caesonia and their infant daughter julia drusilla were murdered on 24 january 41 . [SEP]
[CLS] these events led claudius , caligula ' s uncle , to become emperor . [SEP] claudius allowed agrippina to return from exile . [SEP]
[CLS] claudius had married twice before marrying valeria messalina . [SEP] his previous marriages produced three children including a son , drusus , who died at a young age . [SEP]
[CLS] he had two children with messalina – claudia octavia ( born 40 ) and britannicus ( born 41 ) . [SEP] messalina was executed by claudius in the year 48 . [SEP]
[CLS] in 49 ad , claudius married a fourth time , to nero ' s mother agrippina , despite her being his niece . [SEP] to aid claudius politically , young nero was adopted in 50 and took the name nero claudius caesar drusus germanicus ( see adoption in rome ) . [SEP]
[CLS] nero was older than his stepbrother britannicus , and thus became heir to the throne . [SEP] nero was proclaimed an adult in 51 at the age of 14 . [SEP]
[CLS] he was appointed proconsul , entered and first addressed the senate , made joint public appearances with claudius , and was featured in coinage . [SEP] in 53 , he married his stepsister claudia octavia . [SEP]
[CLS] claudius died in 54 and nero , taking the name nero claudius caesar augustus germanicus , was established as emperor . [SEP] though accounts vary , many ancient historians state agrippina poisoned claudius . [SEP]
[CLS] according to pliny the elder , she used poison mushrooms . [SEP] it is not known how much nero knew or if he was even involved in the death of claudius . [SEP]
[CLS] suetonius wrote " . . . for even if he was not the instigator of the emperor ' s death , he was at least privy to it , as he openly admitted ; for he used afterwards to laud mushrooms , the vehicle in which the poison was administered to claudius , as " the food of the gods , " as the greek proverb has it . [SEP] at any rate , after claudius ' death he vented on him every kind of insult , in act and word , charging him now with folly and now with cruelty ; for it was a favourite joke of his to say that claudius had ceased " to play the fool " among mortals , lengthening the first syllable of the word morari , and he disregarded many of his decrees and acts as the work of a madman and a dotard . [SEP]
[CLS] finally , he neglected to enclose the place where his body was burned except with a low and mean wall . " [SEP] according to suetonius ; nero became emperor at the age of 17 when the news of claudius ' death was made known , making him the youngest emperor at that time although , what suetonius may have meant is that he was in his seventeenth year as his date of birth , also listed by suetonius , would have made him 16 at the time of claudius ' death . [SEP]
[CLS] tacitus , in book xiii of his annals , describes nero as being ' scarcely out of his boyhood ' at the time he became emperor . [SEP] ancient historians describe nero ' s early reign as being strongly influenced by his mother , agrippina , his tutor lucius annaeus seneca , and the praetorian prefect sextus afranius burrus , especially in the first year . [SEP]
[CLS] other tutors were less often mentioned , such as alexander of aegae . [SEP] very early in nero ' s rule , problems arose from competition for influence between agrippina and nero ' s two main advisers , seneca and burrus . [SEP]
[CLS] agrippina also attempted to influence the young nero . [SEP] agrippina also is mentioned by ancient sources as " scheming for her son ( nero ) " . [SEP]
[CLS] this scheming continued as is evidenced by the coin of the both of them . [SEP] it is extremely unusual to see a women ' s face on a coin in the ancient world . [SEP]
[CLS] it is because of this position of power agrippina felt jealous as seneca in particular rose up in nero ' s court as he offered the advice nero wanted to hear unlike his mother . [SEP] in 54 , agrippina tried to sit down next to nero while he met with an armenian envoy , but seneca stopped her and prevented a scandalous scene ( as it was unimaginable at that time for a woman to be in the same room as men doing official business ) . [SEP]
[CLS] nero ' s friends also mistrusted agrippina and told nero to beware of his mother . [SEP] nero was reportedly unsatisfied with his marriage to octavia and entered into an affair with claudia acte , a former slave . [SEP]
[CLS] in 55 , agrippina attempted to intervene in favor of octavia and demanded that her son dismiss acte . [SEP] nero , with the support of seneca , resisted the intervention of his mother in his personal affairs . [SEP]
[CLS] with agrippina ' s influence over her son severed , she reportedly began pushing for britannicus , nero ' s stepbrother , to become emperor . [SEP] nearly fourteen @ - @ year @ - @ old britannicus , heir @ - @ designate prior to nero ' s adoption , was still legally a minor , but was approaching legal adulthood . [SEP]
[CLS] according to tacitus , agrippina hoped that with her support , britannicus , being the blood son of claudius , would be seen as the true heir to the throne by the state over nero . [SEP] however , the youth died suddenly and suspiciously on 12 february 55 , the very day before his proclamation as an adult had been set . [SEP]
[CLS] nero claimed that britannicus died from an epileptic seizure , but ancient historians all claim britannicus ' death came from nero ' s poisoning him . [SEP] supposedly , he enlisted the services of locusta , a woman who specialized in the manufacture of poisons . [SEP]
[CLS] she devised a mixture to kill britannicus , but after testing it unsuccessfully on a slave , nero angrily threatened to have her put to death if she did not come up with something usable . [SEP] locusta then devised a new concoction that she promised would " kill swifter than a viper . " [SEP]
[CLS] her promise was fulfilled after britannicus consumed it at a dinner party from water used to cool his wine , which had already been tasted , and succumbed within minutes . [SEP] after the death of britannicus , agrippina was accused of slandering octavia and nero ordered her out of the imperial residence . [SEP]
[CLS] over time , nero became progressively more powerful , freeing himself of his advisers and eliminating rivals to the throne . [SEP] in 55 , he removed marcus antonius pallas , an ally of agrippina , from his position in the treasury . [SEP]
[CLS] pallas , along with burrus , was accused of conspiring against the emperor to bring faustus sulla to the throne . [SEP] seneca was accused of having relations with agrippina and embezzlement . [SEP]
[CLS] seneca succeeded in having himself , pallas and burrus acquitted . [SEP] according to cassius dio , at this time , seneca and burrus reduced their role in governing from careful management to mere moderation of nero . [SEP]
[CLS] in 58 , nero became romantically involved with poppaea sabina , the wife of his friend and future emperor otho . [SEP] reportedly because a marriage to poppaea and a divorce from octavia did not seem politically feasible with agrippina alive , nero ordered the murder of his mother in 59 . [SEP]
[CLS] a number of modern historians find this an unlikely motive as nero did not marry poppaea until 62 . [SEP] additionally , according to suetonius , poppaea did not divorce her husband until after agrippina ' s death , making it unlikely that the already married poppaea would be pressing nero for marriage . [SEP]
[CLS] some modern historians theorize that nero ' s execution of agrippina was prompted by her plotting to set rubellius plautus on the throne . [SEP] according to suetonius , nero tried to kill his mother through a shipwreck planned by his freedman tutor anicetus . [SEP]
[CLS] instead , it took the life of agrippina ' s friend , acerronia polla . [SEP] when agrippina survived , he had her executed by anicetus and framed it as a suicide . [SEP]
[CLS] the incident is also recorded by tacitus . [SEP] in 62 , nero ' s adviser , burrus , died . [SEP]
[CLS] additionally , seneca was again faced with embezzlement charges . [SEP] seneca asked nero for permission to retire from public affairs . [SEP]
[CLS] nero divorced and banished octavia on grounds of infertility , leaving him free to marry the pregnant poppaea . [SEP] after public protests , nero was forced to allow octavia to return from exile , but she was executed shortly after her return . [SEP]
[CLS] nero also was reported to have kicked poppaea to death in 65 before she could have his second child . [SEP] however , modern historians , noting suetonius , tacitus and cassius dio ' s possible bias against nero and the likelihood that they did not have eyewitness accounts of private events , postulate that poppaea may have died because of complications of miscarriage or childbirth . [SEP]
[CLS] accusations of treason being plotted against nero and the senate first appeared in 62 . [SEP] the senate ruled that antistius , a praetor , should be put to death for speaking ill of nero at a party . [SEP]
[CLS] later , nero ordered the exile of fabricius veiento who slandered the senate in a book . [SEP] tacitus writes that the roots of the conspiracy led by gaius calpurnius piso began in this year . [SEP]
[CLS] to consolidate power , nero executed a number of people in 62 and 63 including his rivals pallas , rubellius plautus and faustus sulla . [SEP] according to suetonius , nero " showed neither discrimination nor moderation in putting to death whomsoever he pleased " during this period . [SEP]
[CLS] nero ' s consolidation of power also included a slow usurping of authority from the senate . [SEP] in 54 , nero promised to give the senate powers equivalent to those under republican rule . [SEP]
[CLS] by 65 , senators complained that they had no power left and this led to the pisonian conspiracy . [SEP] when nero ' s wife poppaea sabina died in 65 , nero went into deep mourning . [SEP]
[CLS] her body was not cremated , it was stuffed with spices , embalmed and put in the mausoleum of augustus . [SEP] she was given a state funeral . [SEP]
[CLS] nero praised her during the funeral eulogy and gave her divine honors . [SEP] it is said that nero " burned ten years ' worth of arabia ' s incense production at her funeral . [SEP]
[CLS] in the beginning of 66 , he married statilia messalina . [SEP] she was already married when she became nero ' s mistress in 65 ad , with statilia ' s husband being driven to suicide in 66 , so nero could marry statilia . [SEP]
[CLS] she was one of the few of nero ' s courtiers who survived the fall of his reign . [SEP] in 67 , nero ordered a young freedman , sporus , to be castrated and then married him . [SEP]
[CLS] according to dion cassius , sporus bore an uncanny resemblance to sabina , and nero even called him by his dead wife ' s name . [SEP] over the course of his reign , nero often made rulings that pleased the lower class . [SEP]
[CLS] nero was criticized as being obsessed with personal popularity . [SEP] nero began his reign in 54 by promising the senate more autonomy . [SEP]
[CLS] in this first year , he forbade others to refer to him with regard to enactments , for which he was praised by the senate . [SEP] nero was known for spending his time visiting brothels and taverns during this period . [SEP]
[CLS] in 55 , nero began taking on a more active role as an administrator . [SEP] he was consul four times between 55 and 60 . [SEP]
[CLS] during this period , some ancient historians speak fairly well of nero and contrast it with his later rule . [SEP] under nero , restrictions were put on the amount of bail and fines . [SEP]
[CLS] also , fees for lawyers were limited . [SEP] there was a discussion in the senate on the misconduct of the freedmen class , and a strong demand was made that patrons should have the right of revoking freedom . [SEP]
[CLS] nero supported the freedmen and ruled that patrons had no such right . [SEP] the senate tried to pass a law in which the crimes of one slave applied to all slaves within a household . [SEP]
[CLS] despite riots from the people , nero supported the senate on their measure , and deployed troops to organise the execution of 400 slaves affected by the law . [SEP] however , he vetoed strong measures against the freedmen affected by the case . [SEP]
[CLS] after tax collectors were accused of being too harsh to the poor , nero transferred collection authority to lower commissioners . [SEP] nero banned any magistrate or procurator from exhibiting public entertainment for fear that the venue was being used as a method to sway the populace . [SEP]
[CLS] additionally , there were many impeachments and removals of government officials along with arrests for extortion and corruption . [SEP] when further complaints arose that the poor were being overly taxed , nero attempted to repeal all indirect taxes . [SEP]
[CLS] the senate convinced him this action would bankrupt the public treasury . [SEP] as a compromise , taxes were cut from 4 @ . @ 5 % to 2 @ . @ 5 % . [SEP]
[CLS] additionally , secret government tax records were ordered to become public . [SEP] to lower the cost of food imports , merchant ships were declared tax @ - @ exempt . [SEP]
[CLS] in imitation of the greeks , nero built a number of gymnasiums and theatres . [SEP] enormous gladiatorial shows were also held . [SEP]
[CLS] nero also established the quinquennial neronia . [SEP] the festival included games , poetry , and theater . [SEP]
[CLS] historians indicate that there was a belief that theatre led to immorality . [SEP] others considered that to have performers dressed in greek clothing was old fashioned . [SEP]
[CLS] some questioned the large public expenditure on entertainment . [SEP] in 64 , rome burned . [SEP]
[CLS] nero enacted a public relief effort as well as significant reconstruction . [SEP] a number of other major construction projects occurred in nero ' s late reign . [SEP]
[CLS] nero had the marshes of ostia filled with rubble from the fire . [SEP] he erected the large domus aurea . [SEP]
[CLS] in 67 , nero attempted to have a canal dug at the isthmus of corinth . [SEP] ancient historians state that these projects and others exacerbated the drain on the state ' s budget . [SEP]
[CLS] the cost to rebuild rome was immense , requiring funds the state treasury did not have . [SEP] nero devalued the roman currency for the first time in the empire ' s history . [SEP]
[CLS] he reduced the weight of the denarius from 84 per roman pound to 96 ( 3 @ . @ 85 grams to 3 @ . @ 35 grams ) . [SEP] he also reduced the silver purity from 99 @ . @ 5 % to 93 @ . @ 5 % — the silver weight dropping from 3 @ . @ 83 grams to 3 @ . @ 4 grams . [SEP]
[CLS] furthermore , nero reduced the weight of the aureus from 40 per roman pound to 45 ( 8 grams to 7 @ . @ 2 grams ) . [SEP] between 62 and 67 , according to plinius the elder and seneca , nero promoted an expedition to discover the sources of the nile river . [SEP]
[CLS] it was the first exploration of equatorial africa from europe in history . [SEP] however , nero ' s expedition up the nile failed upon reaching the impenetrable sudd of present @ - @ day south sudan . [SEP]
[CLS] the economic policy of nero is a point of debate among scholars . [SEP] according to ancient historians , nero ' s construction projects were overly extravagant and the large number of expenditures under nero left italy " thoroughly exhausted by contributions of money " with " the provinces ruined . [SEP]
[CLS] " [SEP] modern historians , though , note that the period was riddled with deflation and that it is likely that nero ' s spending came in the form of public works projects and charity intended to ease economic troubles . [SEP]
[CLS] the great fire of rome erupted on the night of 18 july to 19 july 64 . [SEP] the fire started at the southeastern end of the circus maximus in shops selling flammable goods . [SEP]
[CLS] the extent of the fire is uncertain . [SEP] according to tacitus , who was nine at the time of the fire , it spread quickly and burned for over five days . [SEP]
[CLS] it destroyed three of fourteen roman districts and severely damaged seven . [SEP] the only other historian who lived through the period and mentioned the fire is pliny the elder , who wrote about it in passing . [SEP]
[CLS] other historians who lived through the period ( including josephus , dio chrysostom , plutarch and epictetus ) make no mention of it in what remains of their work . [SEP] it is uncertain who or what actually caused the fire — whether accident or arson . [SEP]
[CLS] suetonius and cassius dio favor nero as the arsonist , so he could build a palatial complex . [SEP] tacitus mentions that christians confessed to the crime , but it is not known whether these confessions were induced by torture . [SEP]
[CLS] however , accidental fires were common in ancient rome . [SEP] in fact , rome suffered other large fires in 69 and in 80 . [SEP]
[CLS] it was said by suetonius and cassius dio that nero sang the " sack of ilium " in stage costume while the city burned . [SEP] popular legend claims that nero played the fiddle at the time of the fire , an anachronism based merely on the concept of the lyre , a stringed instrument associated with nero and his performances . [SEP]
[CLS] ( the fiddle was not invented until the 10th century . ) [SEP] tacitus ' s account , however , has nero in antium at the time of the fire . [SEP]
[CLS] tacitus also said that nero playing his lyre and singing while the city burned was only rumor . [SEP] according to tacitus , upon hearing news of the fire , nero returned to rome to organize a relief effort , which he paid for from his own funds . [SEP]
[CLS] nero ' s contributions to the relief extended to personally taking part in the search for and rescue of victims of the blaze , spending days searching the debris without even his bodyguards . [SEP] after the fire , nero opened his palaces to provide shelter for the homeless , and arranged for food supplies to be delivered in order to prevent starvation among the survivors . [SEP]
[CLS] in the wake of the fire , he made a new urban development plan . [SEP] houses after the fire were spaced out , built in brick , and faced by porticos on wide roads . [SEP]
[CLS] nero also built a new palace complex known as the domus aurea in an area cleared by the fire . [SEP] this included lush artificial landscapes and a 30 @ - @ meter @ - @ tall statue of himself , the colossus of nero . [SEP]
[CLS] the size of this complex is debated ( from 100 to 300 acres ) . [SEP] to find the necessary funds for the reconstruction , tributes were imposed on the provinces of the empire . [SEP]
[CLS] tacitus , in one of the earliest non @ - @ christian references to the origins of christianity , notes that the population searched for a scapegoat and rumors held nero responsible . [SEP] to deflect blame , nero targeted christians . [SEP]
[CLS] he ordered christians to be thrown to dogs , while others were crucified and burned . [SEP] nero enjoyed driving a one @ - @ horse chariot , singing to the lyre and poetry . [SEP]
[CLS] he even composed songs that were performed by other entertainers throughout the empire . [SEP] at first , nero only performed for a private audience . [SEP]
[CLS] in 64 ad . [SEP] , nero began singing in public in neapolis in order to improve his popularity . [SEP]
[CLS] he also sang at the second quinquennial neronia in 65 . [SEP] it was said that nero craved the attention , but historians also write that nero was encouraged to sing and perform in public by the senate , his inner circle and the people . [SEP]
[CLS] ancient historians strongly criticize his choice to perform , calling it shameful . [SEP] nero was persuaded to participate in the olympic games of 67 in order to improve relations with greece and display roman dominance . [SEP]
[CLS] as a competitor , nero raced a ten @ - @ horse chariot and nearly died after being thrown from it . [SEP] he also performed as an actor and a singer . [SEP]
[CLS] though nero faltered in his racing ( in one case , dropping out entirely before the end ) and acting competitions , he won these crowns nevertheless and paraded them when he returned to rome . [SEP] the victories are attributed to nero bribing the judges and his status as emperor . [SEP]
[CLS] shortly after nero ' s accession to the throne in 54 , the roman vassal kingdom of armenia overthrew their iberian prince rhadamistus and he was replaced with the parthian prince tiridates . [SEP] this was seen as a parthian invasion of roman territory . [SEP]
[CLS] there was concern in rome over how the young emperor would handle the situation . [SEP] nero reacted by immediately sending the military to the region under the command of gnaeus domitius corbulo . [SEP]
[CLS] the parthians temporarily relinquished control of armenia to rome . [SEP] the peace did not last and full @ - @ scale war broke out in 58 . [SEP]
[CLS] the parthian king vologases i refused to remove his brother tiridates from armenia . [SEP] the parthians began a full @ - @ scale invasion of the armenian kingdom . [SEP]
[CLS] commander corbulo responded and repelled most of the parthian army that same year . [SEP] tiridates retreated and rome again controlled most of armenia . [SEP]
[CLS] nero was acclaimed in public for this initial victory . [SEP] tigranes , a cappadocian noble raised in rome , was installed by nero as the new ruler of armenia . [SEP]
[CLS] corbulo was appointed governor of syria as a reward . [SEP] in 62 , tigranes invaded the parthian province of adiabene . [SEP]
[CLS] again , rome and parthia were at war and this continued until 63 . [SEP] parthia began building up for a strike against the roman province of syria . [SEP]
[CLS] corbulo tried to convince nero to continue the war , but nero opted for a peace deal instead . [SEP] there was anxiety in rome about eastern grain supplies and a budget deficit . [SEP]
[CLS] the result was a deal where tiridates again became the armenian king , but was crowned in rome by emperor nero . [SEP] in the future , the king of armenia was to be a parthian prince , but his appointment required approval from the romans . [SEP]
[CLS] tiridates was forced to come to rome and partake in ceremonies meant to display roman dominance . [SEP] this peace deal of 63 was a considerable victory for nero politically . [SEP]
[CLS] nero became very popular in the eastern provinces of rome and with the parthians as well . [SEP] the peace between parthia and rome lasted 50 years until emperor trajan of rome invaded armenia in 114 . [SEP]
[CLS] the war with parthia was not nero ' s only major war but he was both criticized and praised for an aversion to battle . [SEP] like many emperors , nero faced a number of rebellions and power struggles within the empire . [SEP]
[CLS] british revolt of 60 – 61 ( boudica ' s uprising ) [SEP] in 60 , a major rebellion broke out in the province of britannia . [SEP]
[CLS] while the governor gaius suetonius paulinus and his troops were busy capturing the island of mona ( anglesey ) from the druids , the tribes of the southeast staged a revolt led by queen boudica of the iceni . [SEP] boudica and her troops destroyed three cities before the army of paulinus could return , receive reinforcements , and quell the rebellion in 61 . [SEP]
[CLS] fearing paulinus himself would provoke further rebellion , nero replaced him with the more passive publius petronius turpilianus . [SEP] the pisonian conspiracy of 65 in 65 , gaius calpurnius piso , a roman statesman , organized a conspiracy against nero with the help of subrius flavus and sulpicius asper , a tribune and a centurion of the praetorian guard . [SEP]
[CLS] according to tacitus , many conspirators wished to " rescue the state " from the emperor and restore the republic . [SEP] the freedman milichus discovered the conspiracy and reported it to nero ' s secretary , epaphroditos . [SEP]
[CLS] as a result , the conspiracy failed and its members were executed including lucan , the poet . [SEP] nero ' s previous advisor , seneca was ordered to commit suicide after admitting he discussed the plot with the conspirators . [SEP]
[CLS] the first jewish war of 66 – 70 in 66 , there was a jewish revolt in judea stemming from greek and jewish religious tension . [SEP] in 67 , nero dispatched vespasian to restore order . [SEP]
[CLS] this revolt was eventually put down in 70 , after nero ' s death . [SEP] this revolt is famous for romans breaching the walls of jerusalem and destroying the second temple of jerusalem . [SEP]
[CLS] in march 68 , gaius julius vindex , the governor of gallia lugdunensis , rebelled against nero ' s tax policies . [SEP] lucius verginius rufus , the governor of germania superior , was ordered to put down vindex ' s rebellion . [SEP]
[CLS] in an attempt to gain support from outside his own province , vindex called upon servius sulpicius galba , the governor of hispania tarraconensis , to join the rebellion and further , to declare himself emperor in opposition to nero . [SEP] at the battle of vesontio in may 68 , verginius ' forces easily defeated those of vindex and the latter committed suicide . [SEP]
[CLS] however , after putting down this one rebel , verginius ' legions attempted to proclaim their own commander as emperor . [SEP] verginius refused to act against nero , but the discontent of the legions of germany and the continued opposition of galba in spain did not bode well for him . [SEP]
[CLS] while nero had retained some control of the situation , support for galba increased despite his being officially declared a public enemy . [SEP] the prefect of the praetorian guard , gaius nymphidius sabinus , also abandoned his allegiance to the emperor and came out in support for galba . [SEP]
[CLS] in response , nero fled rome with the intention of going to the port of ostia and , from there , to take a fleet to one of the still @ - @ loyal eastern provinces . [SEP] according to suetonius , nero abandoned the idea when some army officers openly refused to obey his commands , responding with a line from vergil ' s aeneid : " is it so dreadful a thing then to die ? " [SEP]
[CLS] nero then toyed with the idea of fleeing to parthia , throwing himself upon the mercy of galba , or to appeal to the people and beg them to pardon him for his past offences " and if he could not soften their hearts , to entreat them at least to allow him the prefecture of egypt " . [SEP] suetonius reports that the text of this speech was later found in nero ' s writing desk , but that he dared not give it from fear of being torn to pieces before he could reach the forum . [SEP]
[CLS] nero returned to rome and spent the evening in the palace . [SEP] after sleeping , he awoke at about midnight to find the palace guard had left . [SEP]
[CLS] dispatching messages to his friends ' palace chambers for them to come , he received no answers . [SEP] upon going to their chambers personally , he found them all abandoned . [SEP]
[CLS] when he called for a gladiator or anyone else adept with a sword to kill him , no one appeared . [SEP] he cried , " have i neither friend nor foe ? " and ran out as if to throw himself into the tiber . [SEP]
[CLS] returning , nero sought for some place where he could hide and collect his thoughts . [SEP] an imperial freedman , phaon , offered his villa , located 4 miles outside the city . [SEP]
[CLS] travelling in disguise , nero and four loyal freedmen , epaphroditos , phaon , neophytus , and sporus , reached the villa , where nero ordered them to dig a grave for him . [SEP] at this time , a courier arrived with a report that the senate had declared nero a public enemy and that it was their intention to execute him by beating him to death and that armed men had been sent to apprehend him for the act to take place in the forum . [SEP]
[CLS] the senate actually was still reluctant and deliberating on the right course of action as nero was the last member of the julio @ - @ claudian family . [SEP] indeed , most of the senators had served the imperial family all their lives and felt a sense of loyalty to the deified bloodline , if not to nero himself . [SEP]
[CLS] the men actually had the goal of returning nero back to the senate , where the senate hoped to work out a compromise with the rebelling governors that would preserve nero ' s life , so that at least a future heir to the dynasty could be produced . [SEP] nero , however , did not know this , and at the news brought by the courier , he prepared himself for suicide , pacing up and down muttering " qualis artifex pereo " which translates to english as " what an artist dies in me . [SEP]
[CLS] " [SEP] losing his nerve , he first begged for one of his companions to set an example by first killing himself . [SEP]
[CLS] at last , the sound of approaching horsemen drove nero to face the end . [SEP] however , he still could not bring himself to take his own life but instead he forced his private secretary , epaphroditos , to perform the task . [SEP]
[CLS] when one of the horsemen entered , upon his seeing nero all but dead he attempted to stop the bleeding in vain . [SEP] nero ' s final words were " too late ! [SEP]
[CLS] this is fidelity ! " [SEP] he died on 9 june 68 , the anniversary of the death of octavia , and was buried in the mausoleum of the domitii ahenobarbi , in what is now the villa borghese ( pincian hill ) area of rome . [SEP]
[CLS] with his death , the julio @ - @ claudian dynasty ended . [SEP] the senate , when news of his death reached rome , posthumously declared nero a public enemy to appease the coming galba ( as the senate had initially declared galba as a public enemy ) and proclaimed galba the new emperor . [SEP]
[CLS] chaos would ensue in the year of the four emperors . [SEP] according to suetonius and cassius dio , the people of rome celebrated the death of nero . [SEP]
[CLS] tacitus , though , describes a more complicated political environment . [SEP] tacitus mentions that nero ' s death was welcomed by senators , nobility and the upper class . [SEP]
[CLS] the lower @ - @ class , slaves , frequenters of the arena and the theater , and " those who were supported by the famous excesses of nero " , on the other hand , were upset with the news . [SEP] members of the military were said to have mixed feelings , as they had allegiance to nero , but were bribed to overthrow him . [SEP]
[CLS] eastern sources , namely philostratus ii and apollonius of tyana , mention that nero ' s death was mourned as he " restored the liberties of hellas with a wisdom and moderation quite alien to his character " and that he " held our liberties in his hand and respected them . " [SEP] modern scholarship generally holds that , while the senate and more well @ - @ off individuals welcomed nero ' s death , the general populace was " loyal to the end and beyond , for otho and vitellius both thought it worthwhile to appeal to their nostalgia . " [SEP]
[CLS] nero ' s name was erased from some monuments , in what edward champlin regards as an " outburst of private zeal " . [SEP] many portraits of nero were reworked to represent other figures ; according to eric r . varner , over fifty such images survive . [SEP]
[CLS] this reworking of images is often explained as part of the way in which the memory of disgraced emperors was condemned posthumously ( see damnatio memoriae ) . [SEP] champlin , however , doubts that the practice is necessarily negative and notes that some continued to create images of nero long after his death . [SEP]
[CLS] the civil war during the year of the four emperors was described by ancient historians as a troubling period . [SEP] according to tacitus , this instability was rooted in the fact that emperors could no longer rely on the perceived legitimacy of the imperial bloodline , as nero and those before him could . [SEP]
[CLS] galba began his short reign with the execution of many allies of nero and possible future enemies . [SEP] one such notable enemy included nymphidius sabinus , who claimed to be the son of emperor caligula . [SEP]
[CLS] otho overthrew galba . [SEP] otho was said to be liked by many soldiers because he had been a friend of nero ' s and resembled him somewhat in temperament . [SEP]
[CLS] it was said that the common roman hailed otho as nero himself . [SEP] otho used " nero " as a surname and reerected many statues to nero . [SEP]
[CLS] vitellius overthrew otho . [SEP] vitellius began his reign with a large funeral for nero complete with songs written by nero . [SEP]
[CLS] after nero ' s suicide in 68 , there was a widespread belief , especially in the eastern provinces , that he was not dead and somehow would return . [SEP] this belief came to be known as the nero redivivus legend . [SEP]
[CLS] the legend of nero ' s return lasted for hundreds of years after nero ' s death . [SEP] augustine of hippo wrote of the legend as a popular belief in 422 . [SEP]
[CLS] at least three nero imposters emerged leading rebellions . [SEP] the first , who sang and played the cithara or lyre and whose face was similar to that of the dead emperor , appeared in 69 during the reign of vitellius . [SEP]
[CLS] after persuading some to recognize him , he was captured and executed . [SEP] sometime during the reign of titus ( 79 – 81 ) , another impostor appeared in asia and sang to the accompaniment of the lyre and looked like nero but he , too , was killed . [SEP]
[CLS] twenty years after nero ' s death , during the reign of domitian , there was a third pretender . [SEP] he was supported by the parthians , who only reluctantly gave him up , and the matter almost came to war . [SEP]
[CLS] in his book the lives of the twelve caesars , suetonius describes nero as " about the average height , his body marked with spots and malodorous , his hair light blonde , his features regular rather than attractive , his eyes blue and somewhat weak , his neck over thick , his belly prominent , and his legs very slender . " [SEP] the history of nero ' s reign is problematic in that no historical sources survived that were contemporary with nero . [SEP]
[CLS] these first histories at one time did exist and were described as biased and fantastical , either overly critical or praising of nero . [SEP] the original sources were also said to contradict on a number of events . [SEP]
[CLS] nonetheless , these lost primary sources were the basis of surviving secondary and tertiary histories on nero written by the next generations of historians . [SEP] a few of the contemporary historians are known by name . [SEP]
[CLS] fabius rusticus , cluvius rufus and pliny the elder all wrote condemning histories on nero that are now lost . [SEP] there were also pro @ - @ nero histories , but it is unknown who wrote them or for what deeds nero was praised . [SEP]
[CLS] the bulk of what is known of nero comes from tacitus , suetonius and cassius dio , who were all of the senatorial class . [SEP] tacitus and suetonius wrote their histories on nero over fifty years after his death , while cassius dio wrote his history over 150 years after nero ' s death . [SEP]
[CLS] these sources contradict on a number of events in nero ' s life including the death of claudius , the death of agrippina , and the roman fire of 64 , but they are consistent in their condemnation of nero . [SEP] a handful of other sources also add a limited and varying perspective on nero . [SEP]
[CLS] few surviving sources paint nero in a favourable light . [SEP] some sources , though , portray him as a competent emperor who was popular with the roman people , especially in the east . [SEP]
[CLS] cassius dio cassius dio ( c . [SEP] 155 – 229 ) was the son of cassius apronianus , a roman senator . [SEP]
[CLS] he passed the greater part of his life in public service . [SEP] he was a senator under commodus and governor of smyrna after the death of septimius severus ; and afterwards suffect consul around 205 , and also proconsul in africa and pannonia . [SEP]
[CLS] books 61 – 63 of dio ' s roman history describe the reign of nero . [SEP] only fragments of these books remain and what does remain was abridged and altered by john xiphilinus , an 11th @ - @ century monk . [SEP]
[CLS] dio chrysostom dio chrysostom ( c . [SEP] 40 – 120 ) , a greek philosopher and historian , wrote the roman people were very happy with nero and would have allowed him to rule indefinitely . [SEP]
[CLS] they longed for his rule once he was gone and embraced imposters when they appeared : indeed the truth about this has not come out even yet ; for so far as the rest of his subjects were concerned , there was nothing to prevent his continuing to be emperor for all time , seeing that even now everybody wishes he were still alive . [SEP] and the great majority do believe that he still is , although in a certain sense he has died not once but often along with those who had been firmly convinced that he was still alive . [SEP]
[CLS] epictetus epictetus ( c . [SEP] 55 – 135 ) was the slave to nero ' s scribe epaphroditos . [SEP]
[CLS] he makes a few passing negative comments on nero ' s character in his work , but makes no remarks on the nature of his rule . [SEP] he describes nero as a spoiled , angry and unhappy man . [SEP]
[CLS] josephus the historian josephus ( c . [SEP] 37 – 100 ) , while calling nero a tyrant , was also the first to mention bias against nero . [SEP]
[CLS] of other historians , he said : [SEP] but i omit any further discourse about these affairs ; for there have been a great many who have composed the history of nero ; some of which have departed from the truth of facts out of favour , as having received benefits from him ; while others , out of hatred to him , and the great ill @ - @ will which they bore him , have so impudently raved against him with their lies , that they justly deserve to be condemned . [SEP]
[CLS] nor do i wonder at such as have told lies of nero , since they have not in their writings preserved the truth of history as to those facts that were earlier than his time , even when the actors could have no way incurred their hatred , since those writers lived a long time after them . [SEP] lucan though more of a poet than historian , lucanus ( c . [SEP]
[CLS] 39 – 65 ) has one of the kindest accounts of nero ' s rule . [SEP] he writes of peace and prosperity under nero in contrast to previous war and strife . [SEP]
[CLS] ironically , he was later involved in a conspiracy to overthrow nero and was executed . [SEP] philostratus philostratus ii " the athenian " ( c . [SEP]
[CLS] 172 – 250 ) spoke of nero in the life of apollonius tyana ( books 4 – 5 ) . [SEP] though he has a generally bad or dim view of nero , he speaks of others ' positive reception of nero in the east . [SEP]
[CLS] pliny the elder the history of nero by pliny the elder ( c . [SEP] 24 – 79 ) did not survive . [SEP]
[CLS] still , there are several references to nero in pliny ' s natural histories . [SEP] pliny has one of the worst opinions of nero and calls him an " enemy of mankind . " [SEP]
[CLS] plutarch plutarch ( c . 46 – 127 ) mentions nero indirectly in his account of the life of galba and the life of otho . [SEP] nero is portrayed as a tyrant , but those that replace him are not described as better . [SEP]
[CLS] seneca the younger [SEP] it is not surprising that seneca ( c . 4 bc – 65 ) , nero ' s teacher and advisor , writes very well of nero . [SEP]
[CLS] suetonius suetonius ( c . 69 – 130 ) was a member of the equestrian order , and he was the head of the department of the imperial correspondence . [SEP] while in this position , suetonius started writing biographies of the emperors , accentuating the anecdotal and sensational aspects . [SEP]
[CLS] tacitus the annals by tacitus ( c . [SEP] 56 – 117 ) is the most detailed and comprehensive history on the rule of nero , despite being incomplete after the year 66 . [SEP]
[CLS] tacitus described the rule of the julio @ - @ claudian emperors as generally unjust . [SEP] he also thought that existing writing on them was unbalanced : the histories of tiberius , caius , claudius and nero , while they were in power , were falsified through terror , and after their death were written under the irritation of a recent hatred . [SEP]
[CLS] tacitus was the son of a procurator , who married into the elite family of agricola . [SEP] he entered his political life as a senator after nero ' s death and , by tacitus ' own admission , owed much to nero ' s rivals . [SEP]
[CLS] realising that this bias may be apparent to others , tacitus protests that his writing is true . [SEP] girolamo cardano [SEP]
[CLS] in 1562 girolamo cardano published in basel his encomium neronis , which was one of the first historical references of the modern era to portray nero in a positive light . [SEP] at the end of 66 , conflict broke out between greeks and jews in jerusalem and caesarea . [SEP]
[CLS] according to the talmud , nero went to jerusalem and shot arrows in all four directions . [SEP] all the arrows landed in the city . [SEP]
[CLS] he then asked a passing child to repeat the verse he had learned that day . [SEP] the child responded , " i will lay my vengeance upon edom by the hand of my people israel " ( ez . 25 @ , @ 14 ) . [SEP]
[CLS] nero became terrified , believing that god wanted the temple in jerusalem to be destroyed , but would punish the one to carry it out . [SEP] nero said , " he desires to lay waste his house and to lay the blame on me , " whereupon he fled and converted to judaism to avoid such retribution . [SEP]
[CLS] vespasian was then dispatched to put down the rebellion . [SEP] the talmud adds that the sage reb meir baal haness , rabbi meir or rabbi meir baal hanes ( rabbi meir the miracle maker ) was a jewish sage who lived in the time of the mishna a prominent supporter of the bar kokhba rebellion against roman rule . [SEP]
[CLS] he was considered one of the greatest of the tannaim of the third generation ( 139 @ - @ 163 ) . [SEP] according to the talmud , his father was a descendant of the roman emperor nero who had converted to judaism . [SEP]
[CLS] his wife bruriah is one of the few women cited in the gemara . [SEP] he is the third most frequently mentioned sage in the mishnah . [SEP]
[CLS] roman and greek sources nowhere report nero ' s alleged trip to jerusalem or his alleged conversion to judaism . [SEP] there is also no record of nero having any offspring who survived infancy : his only recorded child , claudia augusta , died aged 4 months . [SEP]
[CLS] non @ - @ christian historian tacitus describes nero extensively torturing and executing christians after the fire of 64 . [SEP] suetonius also mentions nero punishing christians , though he does so because they are " given to a new and mischievous superstition " and does not connect it with the fire . [SEP]
[CLS] christian writer tertullian ( c . 155 – 230 ) was the first to call nero the first persecutor of christians . [SEP] he wrote , " examine your records . [SEP]
[CLS] there you will find that nero was the first that persecuted this doctrine " . [SEP] lactantius ( c . [SEP]
[CLS] 240 [SEP] – 320 ) also said that nero " first persecuted the servants of god " . [SEP]
[CLS] as does sulpicius severus . [SEP] however , suetonius writes that , " since the jews constantly made disturbances at the instigation of chrestus , he [ emperor claudius ] expelled them from rome " ( " iudaeos impulsore chresto assidue tumultuantis roma expulit " ) . [SEP]
[CLS] these expelled " jews " may have been early christians , although suetonius is not explicit . [SEP] nor is the bible explicit , calling aquila of pontus and his wife , priscilla , both expelled from italy at the time , " jews " . [SEP]
[CLS] the first text to suggest that nero ordered the execution of an apostle is a letter by clement to the corinthians traditional dated to around 96 a . d . [SEP] the apocryphal ascension of isaiah , a christian writing from the 2nd century says , " the slayer of his mother , who himself ( even ) this king , will persecute the plant which the twelve apostles of the beloved have planted . [SEP]
[CLS] of the twelve one will be delivered into his hands " was interpreted to mean nero . [SEP] bishop eusebius of caesarea ( c . [SEP]
[CLS] 275 – 339 ) was the first to write explicitly that paul was beheaded in rome during the reign of nero . [SEP] he states that nero ' s persecution led to peter and paul ' s deaths , but that nero did not give any specific orders . [SEP]
[CLS] however , several other accounts going back to the 1st century have paul surviving his two years in rome and travelling to hispania , before facing trial in rome again prior to his death . [SEP] peter is first said to have been crucified upside @ - @ down in rome during nero ' s reign ( but not by nero ) in the apocryphal acts of peter ( c . 200 ) . [SEP]
[CLS] the account ends with paul still alive and nero abiding by god ' s command not to persecute any more christians . [SEP] by the 4th century , a number of writers were stating that nero killed peter and paul . [SEP]
[CLS] the sibylline oracles , book 5 and 8 , written in the 2nd century , speak of nero returning and bringing destruction . [SEP] within christian communities , these writings , along with others , fueled the belief that nero would return as the antichrist . [SEP]
[CLS] in 310 , lactantius wrote that nero " suddenly disappeared , and even the burial place of that noxious wild beast was nowhere to be seen . [SEP] this has led some persons of extravagant imagination to suppose that , having been conveyed to a distant region , he is still reserved alive ; and to him they apply the sibylline verses " , lactantius maintains that it is not right to believe this . [SEP]
[CLS] in 422 , augustine of hippo wrote about 2 thessalonians 2 : 1 – 11 , where he believed paul mentioned the coming of the antichrist . [SEP] though he rejects the theory , augustine mentions that many christians believed that nero was the antichrist or would return as the antichrist . [SEP]
[CLS] he wrote , " so that in saying , ' for the mystery of iniquity doth already work , ' he alluded to nero , whose deeds already seemed to be as the deeds of antichrist . " [SEP] some modern biblical scholars such as delbert hillers ( johns hopkins university ) of the american schools of oriental research and the editors of the oxford & harper collins study bibles , contend that the number 666 in the book of revelation is a code for nero , a view that is also supported in roman catholic biblical commentaries . [SEP]
[CLS] the concept of nero as the antichrist is often a central belief of preterist eschatology . [SEP] manila ( / məˈnɪl . ə / ) is the capital city of the philippines , founded on june 24 , 1571 by spanish conquistador miguel lopez de legazpi . [SEP]
[CLS] it is one of the oldest cities in the country and was the seat of power for most of the colonial rules of the philippines . [SEP] it is situated on the eastern shore of manila bay and contains a multitude of landmarks , some of which date back to the 16th century , such as the spanish colonial era walled city of intramuros . [SEP]
[CLS] manila is the second most populous city in the philippines after the former capital quezon city with a population of 1 @ , @ 780 @ , @ 148 in 2015 . [SEP] because of its small land area and huge population , manila is regarded as one of the most densely populated cities in the world with 42 @ , @ 857 people per square kilometer . [SEP]
[CLS] manila is one of the sixteen cities and a municipality that make up metro manila , the national capital region of the philippines . [SEP] in 2012 , globalization and world cities research network listed manila as a global city . [SEP]
[CLS] manila has six representative districts for the lower house of the philippine congress . [SEP] furthermore , the city is composed of 16 districts , namely : binondo , ermita , intramuros , malate , paco , pandacan , port area , quiapo , sampaloc , san andres , san miguel , san nicolas , santa ana , santa cruz , santa mesa and tondo . [SEP]
[CLS] the kingdom of tondo once ruled in the vicinity of manila before it briefly became a province of the hindu majapahit empire . [SEP] during the brunei invasion of the philippines , sultan bolkiah of brunei captured seludong ( a village in modern @ - @ day manila ) and renamed it maynila , a tagalog term referring to the presence of the nila shrub . [SEP]
[CLS] maynila was a vassal state of brunei , established to overpower tondo . [SEP] maynila had been indianized since the sixth century ce and earlier . [SEP]
[CLS] it had become partly islamic and hindu @ - @ animist by the 15th century ce . [SEP] in 1571 spanish conquistadors arrived from mexico , from across the pacific , and founded present @ - @ day manila in what today is intramuros . [SEP]
[CLS] spanish missionaries soon christianized the city and incorporated tondo under manila and then built some of the oldest churches in the country , including san agustin church . [SEP] the conquistadors renamed the area nuevo reino de castilla ( new kingdom of castille ) and shortened the name to manila . [SEP]
[CLS] manila became the center of spanish activity in the far east and one end of the manila @ - @ acapulco galleon trade route , linking spanish america with asia , one of the earliest examples of globalization . [SEP] due to the central location in the pacific sea trade routes , manila received the moniker of the " pearl of the orient " . [SEP]
[CLS] spanish rule of manila and the entire philippine archipelago lasted for over three centuries , until 1898 . [SEP] at different times during the long spanish period there were local revolts , chinese insurrections , massive pirate attacks , great earthquakes , dutch raids and invasion attempts , and a british occupation of the city during their unsuccessful attempt to conquer the philippines . [SEP]
[CLS] order was usually quickly restored and the city returned to the business of trade . [SEP] in the 19th century manila was one of the most modern cities in asia . [SEP]
[CLS] before the spanish – american war , manila saw the rise of the philippine revolution . [SEP] under the american rule following the spanish – american war , the united states changed the official language from spanish to english and made some changes in education , local laws and urban planning . [SEP]
[CLS] towards the end of world war ii , during the battle of manila most of the city was flattened by intensive aerial bombardment by the united states air force . [SEP] as a result , relatively little remains of manila ' s prewar and colonial architecture , although there are ongoing restoration projects , especially within the old walled city , intramuros . [SEP]
[CLS] the earliest evidence of human life in and around the area of manila is the nearby angono petroglyphs dated to around 3000 bc . [SEP] furthermore , negritos , a class of australoid peoples , became the aboriginal inhabitants of the philippines . [SEP]
[CLS] they were found across luzon before the malayo @ - @ polynesians migrated in and assimilated them . [SEP] the kingdom of tondo flourished during the latter half of the ming dynasty as a result of direct trade relations with china . [SEP]
[CLS] tondo district was maintained as the traditional capital of the empire , with its rulers as sovereign kings and not mere chieftains , and were addressed variously as panginuan ln meranau or panginoon in tagalog ( " lords " ) ; anak banwa ( " son of heaven " ) ; or lakandula ( " lord of the palace " ) , the emperor of china considered the lakans ( rulers of ancient manila ) " 王 " ( kings ) .
