[CLS] the film was the final production and release of the thanhouser company and it was to be released through pathe . [SEP] numerous factors would play into the winding down and eventual closing of the thanhouser film corporation with much advance notice by edwin thanhouser . [SEP]
[CLS] q . david bowers writes that it was easy to understand thanhouser ' s decision to retire due to numerous aspects including that releases through pathe were based on their decision to release or discard the work , the new rochelle studio was 2 @ , @ 500 miles from the center of the trade activity and the slump in industry tied to world war i . weeks before the film was released , variety told of the winding down of the thanhouser with the studio ' s staff consisting of edwin thanhouser and the bookkeeper , jessie b . bishop . [SEP] the article concluded with the announcement that lloyd f . lonergan , the scenario writer of the company , had retired from the company . [SEP]
[CLS] as it wound down , the thanhouser company was announced to have no liabilities would close with a positive bank balance . [SEP] little is known of the production of this final film , but it was directed by emile chautard from a scenario written by lloyd f . lonergan . [SEP]
[CLS] the cameraman was jacques bizeul . [SEP] the five reel film was released through the pathe exchange as a pathe gold rooster play on october 7 , 1917 . [SEP]
[CLS] charles e . wagner of the exhibitor ' s trade review found it to be a good film with great direction and photography , but was concerned that the stunt in which the baby appeared to be involved in the accident was too real . [SEP] wagner stated the film had sufficient action and pathos without sexual suggestiveness ; which should prove a strong program for the pathe program . [SEP]
[CLS] frances agnew of the morning telegraph found it to be an average picture that was not exceptional for audiences , but it would hold sentimental appeal for the average viewer . [SEP] a reviewer for the the new york dramatic mirror found the film ' s excessive use of coincidental meetings to be highly improbable , but found warde ' s performance to be excellent and the rest of the cast give good performances . [SEP]
[CLS] the reviewer said that emile chautard had made the improbable story more plausible . [SEP] like many american films of the time , the heart of ezra greer was subject to cuts by city and state film censorship boards . [SEP]
[CLS] the chicago board of censors required the cutting in reel 2 of a letter stating , " i cannot face my father , " etc . [SEP] , and two closeups of gambling scenes ; and in reel 5 a change of the intertitle " because it means her whole future " to " because she is his wife " . [SEP]
[CLS] free derry ( irish : saor dhoire ) was a self @ - @ declared autonomous nationalist area of derry , northern ireland , that existed between 1969 and 1972 . [SEP] its name was taken from a sign painted on a gable wall in the bogside in january 1969 which read , " you are now entering free derry " . [SEP]
[CLS] the area , which included the bogside and creggan neighbourhoods , was secured by community activists for the first time on 5 january 1969 following an incursion into the bogside by members of the royal ulster constabulary ( ruc ) . [SEP] residents built barricades and carried clubs and similar arms to prevent the ruc from entering . [SEP]
[CLS] after six days the residents took down the barricades and ruc patrols resumed , but tensions remained high over the following months . [SEP] violence reached a peak on 12 august 1969 , culminating in the battle of the bogside — a three @ - @ day pitched battle between residents and the ruc . [SEP]
[CLS] on 14 august units of the british army were deployed at the edge of the bogside and the ruc were withdrawn . [SEP] the derry citizens defence association ( dcda ) declared their intention to hold the area against both the ruc and the british army until their demands were met . [SEP]
[CLS] the british army made no attempt to enter the area . [SEP] the situation continued until october 1969 when , following publication of the hunt report , military police were allowed in . [SEP]
[CLS] the irish republican army ( ira ) began to re @ - @ arm and recruit after august 1969 . [SEP] in december 1969 it split into the official ira and the provisional ira . [SEP]
[CLS] both were supported by the people of the free derry area . [SEP] meanwhile , relations between the british army and the nationalist community , which were initially good , deteriorated . [SEP]
[CLS] in july 1971 there was a surge of recruitment into the ira after two young men were shot and killed by british troops . [SEP] the government introduced internment on 9 august 1971 , and in response , barricades went up once more in the bogside and creggan . [SEP]
[CLS] this time , free derry was a no @ - @ go area , defended by armed members of both the official and provisional ira . [SEP] from within the area they launched attacks on the british army , and the provisionals began a bombing campaign in the city centre . [SEP]
[CLS] as before , unarmed ' auxiliaries ' manned the barricades , and crime was dealt with by a voluntary body known as the free derry police . [SEP] support for the ira increased further after bloody sunday in january 1972 , when thirteen unarmed men and boys were shot dead by the british army ' s parachute regiment at a march in the bogside ( a 14th man was wounded and died 4 ½ months later ) . [SEP]
[CLS] the support began to wane after the killing by the official ira of a local youth who was home on leave from the british army . [SEP] after a provisional ira ceasefire , during which it entered talks with the british government , broke down , the british took the decision to move against the " no @ - @ go " areas . [SEP]
[CLS] free derry came to an end on 31 july 1972 , when thousands of british troops moved in with armoured cars and bulldozers to occupy the area . [SEP] derry city lies near the border between northern ireland and the republic of ireland . [SEP]
[CLS] it has a majority nationalist population , and nationalists won a majority of seats in the 1920 local elections . [SEP] despite this , the ulster unionist party controlled the local council , londonderry corporation , from 1923 onwards . [SEP]
[CLS] the unionists maintained their majority , firstly , by manipulating the constituency boundaries ( gerrymandering ) so that the south ward , with a nationalist majority , returned eight councillors while the much smaller north ward and waterside ward , with unionist majorities , returned twelve councillors between them ; secondly , by allowing only ratepayers to vote in local elections , rather than one man , one vote , so that a higher number of nationalists , who did not own homes , were disenfranchised ; and thirdly , by denying houses to nationalists outside the south ward constituency . [SEP] the result was that there were about 2 @ , @ 000 nationalist families , and practically no unionists , on the housing waiting list , and that housing in the nationalist area was crowded and of a very poor condition . [SEP]
[CLS] the south ward comprised the bogside , brandywell , creggan , bishop street and foyle road , and it was this area that would become free derry . [SEP] the derry housing action committee ( dhac ) was formed in march 1968 by members of the derry branch of the northern ireland labour party and the james connolly republican club , including eamonn mccann and eamon melaugh . [SEP]
[CLS] it disrupted a meeting of londonderry corporation in march 1968 and in may blocked traffic by placing a caravan that was home to a family of four in the middle of the lecky road in the bogside and staging a sit @ - @ down protest at the opening of the second deck of the craigavon bridge . [SEP] after the meeting of londonderry corporation was again disrupted in august , eamon melaugh telephoned the northern ireland civil rights association ( nicra ) and invited them to hold a march in derry . [SEP]
[CLS] the date chosen was 5 october 1968 , an adhoc committee was formed ( although in reality most of the organizing was done by mccann and melaugh ) and the route was to take the marchers inside the city walls , where nationalists were traditionally not permitted to march . [SEP] the minister of home affairs , william craig , made an order on 3 october prohibiting the march on the grounds that the apprentice boys of derry were intending to hold a march on the same day . [SEP]
[CLS] in the words of martin melaugh of cain " this particular tactic . . . provided the excuse needed to ban the march . " [SEP] when the marchers attempted to defy the ban on 5 october they were stopped by a royal ulster constabulary ( ruc ) cordon . [SEP]
[CLS] the police drew their batons and struck marchers , including stormont mp eddie mcateer and westminster mp gerry fitt . [SEP] subsequently the police " broke ranks and used their batons indiscriminately on people in duke street " . [SEP]
[CLS] marchers trying to escape met another party of police and " these police also used their batons indiscriminately . " [SEP] water cannons were also used . [SEP]
[CLS] the police action caused outrage in the nationalist area of derry , and at a meeting four days later the derry citizens ' action committee ( dcac ) was formed , with john hume as chairman and ivan cooper as vice @ - @ chairman . [SEP] another group formed as a result of the events of 5 october was people ' s democracy , a group of students in queen ' s university belfast . [SEP]
[CLS] they organised a march from belfast to derry in support of civil rights , starting out with about forty young people on 1 january 1969 . [SEP] the march met with violent opposition from loyalist counter @ - @ demonstrators at several points along the route . [SEP]
[CLS] finally , at burntollet bridge , five miles outside derry , they were attacked by a mob of about two hundred wielding clubs — some of them studded with nails — and stones . [SEP] half of the attackers were later identified from press photographs as members of the b @ - @ specials . [SEP]
[CLS] the police , who were at the scene , chatted to the b @ - @ specials as they prepared their ambush , and then failed to protect the marchers , many of whom ran into the river and were pelted with stones from the bank . [SEP] dozens of marchers were taken to hospital . [SEP]
[CLS] the remainder continued on to derry where they were attacked once more on their way to craigavon bridge before they finally reached guildhall square , where they held a rally . [SEP] rioting broke out after the rally . [SEP]
[CLS] police drove rioters into the bogside , but did not come after them . [SEP] in the early hours of the following morning , 5 january , members of the ruc charged into st . columb ' s wells and lecky road in the bogside , breaking windows and beating residents . [SEP]
[CLS] in his report on the disturbances , lord cameron remarked that " for such conduct among members of a disciplined and well @ - @ led force there can be no acceptable justification or excuse " and added that " its effect in rousing passions and inspiring hostility towards the police was regrettably great . " [SEP] that afternoon over 1 @ , @ 500 bogside residents built barricades , armed themselves with steel bars , wooden clubs and hurleys , and told the police that they would not be allowed into the area . [SEP]
[CLS] dcac chairman john hume told a meeting of residents that they were to defend the area and no @ - @ one was to come in . [SEP] groups of men wearing armbands patrolled the streets in shifts . [SEP]
[CLS] john ' caker ' casey , a local activist , painted " you are now entering free derry " in white paint on the gable wall of a house on the corner of lecky road and fahan street . [SEP] that corner , which was a popular venue for meetings , later became known as " free derry corner " . [SEP]
[CLS] on 7 january , the barricaded area was extended to include the creggan , another nationalist area on a hill overlooking the bogside . [SEP] a clandestine radio station calling itself " radio free derry " began broadcasting to residents , playing rebel songs and encouraging resistance . [SEP]
[CLS] on a small number of occasions law @ - @ breakers attempted crimes , but were dealt with by the patrols . [SEP] despite all this , the irish times reported that " the infrastructure of revolutionary control in the area has not been developed beyond the maintenance of patrols . " [SEP]
[CLS] following some acts of destruction and of violence late in the week , members of the dcac including ivan cooper addressed residents on friday , 10 january and called on them to dismantle the barricades . [SEP] the barricades were taken down the following morning . [SEP]
[CLS] over the next three months there were violent clashes , with local youths throwing stones at police . [SEP] violence came to a head on saturday , 19 april after a planned march from burntollet bridge to the city centre was banned . [SEP]
[CLS] a protest in the city centre led to clashes with " paisleyites " — unionists in sympathy with the anti @ - @ civil rights stance of ian paisley . [SEP] police attempting to drive the protesters back into the bogside were themselves driven back to their barracks . [SEP]
[CLS] a series of pitched battles followed , and barricades were built , often under the supervision of bernadette devlin , newly elected mp for mid ulster . [SEP] police pursuing rioters broke into a house in william street and severely beat the occupant , samuel devenny , his family and two friends . [SEP]
[CLS] devenny was brought to hospital " bleeding profusely from a number of head wounds . " [SEP] at midnight four hundred ruc men in full riot gear and carrying riot shields occupied the bogside . [SEP]
[CLS] convoys of police vehicles drove through the area with headlights blazing . [SEP] the following day , several thousand residents , led by the dcac , withdrew to the creggan and issued an ultimatum to the ruc — withdraw within two hours or be driven out . [SEP]
[CLS] with fifteen minutes of the two hours remaining , the police marched out through the butcher ' s gate , even as the residents were entering from the far side . [SEP] the barricades were not maintained on this occasion , and routine patrols were not prevented . [SEP]
[CLS] samuel devenny suffered a heart attack four days after his beating . [SEP] on 17 july he suffered a further heart attack and died . [SEP]
[CLS] thousands attended his funeral , and the mood was sufficiently angry that it was clear the annual apprentice boys ' parade , scheduled for 12 august , could not take place without causing serious disturbance . [SEP] the apprentice boys ' parade is an annual celebration by unionists of the relief of the siege of derry in 1689 , which began when thirteen young apprentice boys shut the city ' s gates against the army of king james . [SEP]
[CLS] at that time the parade was held on 12 august each year . [SEP] participants from across northern ireland and britain marched along the city walls above the bogside , and were often openly hostile to the residents . [SEP]
[CLS] on 30 july 1969 the derry citizens defence association ( dcda ) was formed to try to preserve peace during the period of the parade , and to defend the bogside and creggan in the event of an attack . [SEP] the chairman was sean keenan , an irish republican army ( ira ) veteran ; the vice @ - @ chairman was paddy doherty , a popular local man sometimes known as " paddy bogside " and the secretary was johnnie white , another leading republican and leader of the james connolly republican club . [SEP]
[CLS] street committees were formed under the overall command of the dcda and barricades were built on the night of 11 august . [SEP] the parade took place as planned on 12 august . [SEP]
[CLS] as it passed through waterloo place , on the edge of the bogside , hostilities began between supporters and opponents of the parade . [SEP] fighting between the two groups continued for two hours , then the police joined in . [SEP]
[CLS] they charged up william street against the bogsiders , followed by the ' paisleyites ' . [SEP] they were met with a hail of stones and petrol bombs . [SEP]
[CLS] the ensuing battle became known as the battle of the bogside . [SEP] late in the evening , having been driven back repeatedly , the police fired canisters of cs gas into the crowd . [SEP]
[CLS] youths on the roof of a high @ - @ rise block of flats on rossville street threw petrol bombs down on the police . [SEP] walkie @ - @ talkies were used to maintain contact between different areas of fighting and dcda headquarters in paddy doherty ' s house in westland street , and first aid stations were operating , staffed by doctors , nurses and volunteers . [SEP]
[CLS] women and girls made milk @ - @ bottle crates of petrol bombs for supply to the youths in the front line and " radio free derry " broadcast to the fighters and their families . [SEP] on the third day of fighting , 14 august , the northern ireland government mobilised the ulster special constabulary ( b @ - @ specials ) , a force greatly feared by nationalists in derry and elsewhere . [SEP]
[CLS] before they engaged , however , british troops were deployed at the scene , carrying automatic rifles and sub @ - @ machine guns . [SEP] the ruc and b @ - @ specials withdrew , and the troops took up positions outside the barricaded area . [SEP]
[CLS] a deputation that included eamonn mccann met senior army officers and told them that the army would not be allowed in until certain demands were met , including the disarming of the ruc , the disbandment of the b @ - @ specials and the abolition of stormont ( the parliament and government of northern ireland ) . [SEP] the officers agreed that neither troops nor police would enter the bogside and creggan districts . [SEP]
[CLS] a ' peace corps ' was formed to maintain law and order . [SEP] when the british home secretary , jim callaghan , visited northern ireland and announced his intention to visit the bogside on 28 august , he was told that he would not be allowed to bring either police or soldiers with him . [SEP]
[CLS] callaghan agreed . [SEP] accompanied by members of the defence committee , he was " swept along by a surging crowd of thousands " up rossvile street and into lecky road , where he " took refuge " in a local house , and later addressed crowds from an upstairs window . [SEP]
[CLS] in preparation for callaghan ' s visit the " free derry " wall was painted white and the " you are now entering free derry " sign was professionally re @ - @ painted in black lettering . [SEP] following callaghan ' s visit , some barricades were breached , but the majority remained while the people awaited concrete evidence of reform . [SEP]
[CLS] still the army made no move to enter the area . [SEP] law and order was maintained by a ' peace corps ' — volunteers organised by the dcda to patrol the streets and man the barricades . [SEP]
[CLS] there was very little crime . [SEP] punishment , in the words of eamonn mccann , " as often as not consisted of a stern lecture from sean keenan on the need for solidarity within the area . " [SEP]
[CLS] in september the barricades were replaced with a white line painted on the road . [SEP] the hunt report on the future of policing in northern ireland was presented to the stormont cabinet in early october . [SEP]
[CLS] jim callaghan held talks with the cabinet in belfast on 10 october , following which the report ' s recommendations were accepted and made public . [SEP] they included the recommendation that the ruc should be ' ordinarily ' unarmed , and that the b @ - @ specials should be phased out and replaced by a new force . [SEP]
[CLS] the new ruc chief constable , arthur young , an englishman , was announced , and travelled to belfast with callaghan . [SEP] the same day , sean keenan announced that the dcda was to be dissolved . [SEP]
[CLS] on 11 october callaghan and young visited free derry , and on 12 october the first military police entered the bogside , on foot and unarmed . [SEP] the irish republican army ( ira ) had been inactive militarily since the end of the border campaign in 1962 . [SEP]
[CLS] it was low in both personnel and equipment — chief of staff cathal goulding told sean keenan and paddy doherty in august 1969 that he " couldn ' t defend the bogside . [SEP] i haven ' t the men nor the guns to do it . " [SEP]
[CLS] during the 1960s the leadership of the republican movement had moved to the left . [SEP] its focus was on class struggle and its aim was to unite the irish nationalist and unionist working classes in order to overthrow capitalism , both british and irish . [SEP]
[CLS] republican clubs were formed in northern ireland , where sinn fein was proscribed . [SEP] these clubs were involved in the formation of nicra in 1967 . [SEP]
[CLS] in derry , the james connolly republican club worked closely with labour party radicals , with whom they set up the derry housing action committee and derry unemployed action committee . [SEP] the derry citizens ' defence association was formed initially by republicans , who then invited other nationalists to join . [SEP]
[CLS] although there were tensions between the younger leaders like johnnie white and the older , traditional republicans such as sean keenan , both sides saw the unrest of 1968 @ - @ 69 as a chance to advance republican aims , and the two shared the platform at the easter rising commemoration in april 1969 . [SEP] the events of august 1969 in derry , and more particularly in belfast where the ira was unable to prevent loss of life or protect families burned out of their homes , brought to a head the divisions that had already appeared within the movement between the radicals and the traditionalists , and led to a split in december 1969 into the official ira and the provisional ira . [SEP]
[CLS] initially , both armies organised for defensive purposes only , although the provisionals were planning towards an offensive campaign . [SEP] in derry there was far less hostility between the two organisations than elsewhere and householders commonly paid subscriptions to both . [SEP]
[CLS] when rioters were arrested after the official ' s easter parade in march 1970 , officials and provisionals picketed their trial together . [SEP] at the start the officials attracted most of the younger members . [SEP]
[CLS] martin mcguinness , who in august 1969 had helped defend the barricades , initially joined the officials , but a few months later left to join the provisionals . [SEP] relations between the british army and the residents had steadily decayed since the first appearance of troops in august 1969 . [SEP]
[CLS] in september , after clashes between nationalist and unionist crowds that led to the death of a protestant man , william king , the british army erected a ' peace ring ' to enclose the nationalist population in the area they had previously controlled . [SEP] roads into the city centre were closed at night and people were prevented from walking on certain streets . [SEP]
[CLS] although some moderate nationalists accepted this as necessary , there was anger among young people . [SEP] clashes between youths and troops became more frequent . [SEP]
[CLS] the riot following the officials ' easter parade in march 1970 marked the first time that the army used ' snatch squads ' , who rushed into the bogside wielding batons to make arrests . [SEP] the snatch squads soon became a common feature of army arrest operations . [SEP]
[CLS] there was also a belief that they were arresting people at random , sometimes days after the alleged offence , and based on the identification of people that they had seen from a considerable distance . [SEP] the rioters were condemned as hooligans by moderates , who saw the riots as hampering attempts to resolve the situation . [SEP]
[CLS] the labour radicals and official republicans , still working together , tried to turn the youth away from rioting and create socialist organizations — one such organization was named the young hooligans association — but to no avail . [SEP] the provisionals , while disapproving of riots , viewed them as the inevitable consequence of british occupation . [SEP]
[CLS] this philosophy was more attractive to rioters , and some of them joined the provisional ira . [SEP] the deaths of two leading provisionals in a premature explosion in june 1970 resulted in young militants becoming more prominent in the organization . [SEP]
[CLS] nevertheless , up to july 1971 the provisional ira remained numerically small . [SEP] two men , seamas cusack and desmond beattie , were shot dead in separate incidents in the early morning and afternoon of 8 july 1971 . [SEP]
[CLS] they were the first people to be killed by the british army in derry . [SEP] in both cases the british army claimed that the men were attacking them with guns or bombs , while eyewitnesses insisted that both were unarmed . [SEP]
[CLS] the social democratic and labour party ( sdlp ) , the newly formed party of which john hume and ivan cooper were leading members , withdrew from stormont in protest , but among residents there was a perception that moderate policies had failed . [SEP] the result was a surge of support for the ira . [SEP]
[CLS] the provisionals held a meeting the following sunday at which they called on people to " join the ira " . [SEP] following the meeting , people queued up to join , and there was large @ - @ scale rioting . [SEP]
[CLS] the british army post at bligh ' s lane came under sustained attack , and troops there and around the city came under fire from the ira . [SEP] the increasing violence in derry and elsewhere led to increasing speculation that internment without trial would be introduced in northern ireland , and on 9 august 1971 hundreds of republicans and nationalists were arrested in dawn raids . [SEP]
[CLS] in derry , residents came out onto the streets to resist the arrests , and fewer people were taken there than elsewhere ; nevertheless leading figures including sean keenan and johnnie white were interned . [SEP] in response , barricades were erected once again and the third free derry came into existence . [SEP]
[CLS] unlike its predecessors , this free derry was marked by a strong ira presence , both official and provisional . [SEP] it was defended by armed paramilitaries — a no @ - @ go area , one in which british security forces were unable to operate . [SEP]
[CLS] gun attacks on the british army increased . [SEP] six soldiers were wounded in the first day after internment , and shortly afterwards a soldier was killed — the first to be killed by either ira in derry . [SEP]
[CLS] the army moved in in force on 18 august to dismantle the barricades . [SEP] a gun battle ensued in which a young provisional ira officer , eamonn lafferty , was killed . [SEP]
[CLS] a crowd staging a sit @ - @ down protest was hosed down and the protesters , including john hume and ivan cooper , arrested . [SEP] with barricades re @ - @ appearing as quickly as they were removed , the army eventually abandoned their attempt . [SEP]
[CLS] the derry provisionals had little contact with the ira elsewhere . [SEP] they had few weapons ( about twenty ) which they used mainly for sniping . [SEP]
[CLS] at the same time , they launched their bombing campaign in derry . [SEP] unlike in belfast , they were careful to avoid killing or injuring innocent people . [SEP]
[CLS] eamonn mccann wrote that " the derry provos , under martin mcguinness , had managed to bomb the city centre until it looked as if it had been hit from the air without causing any civilian casualties . " [SEP] although both iras operated openly , neither was in control of free derry . [SEP]
[CLS] the barricades were manned by unarmed ' auxiliaries ' . [SEP] crime was dealt with by a volunteer force called the free derry police , which was headed by tony o ' doherty , a derry footballer and northern ireland international . [SEP]
[CLS] an anti @ - @ internment protest organised by the northern ireland civil rights association ( nicra ) at magilligan camp in january 1972 was met with violence from the 1st battalion , the parachute regiment ( 1 para ) . [SEP] nicra had organised a march from the creggan to derry city centre , in defiance of a ban , on the following sunday , 30 january 1972 . [SEP]
[CLS] both iras were asked , and agreed , to suspend operations on that day to ensure the march passed off peacefully . [SEP] the british army erected barricades around the free derry area to prevent marchers from reaching the city centre . [SEP]
[CLS] on the day , march organisers turned the march away from the barriers and up to free derry corner , but some youths proceeded to the barrier at william street and stoned soldiers . [SEP] troops from 1 para then moved into free derry and opened fire , killing thirteen people , all of whom were subsequently found to be unarmed . [SEP]
[CLS] a fourteenth shooting victim died four months later in june 1972 . [SEP] like the killing of cusack and beattie the previous year , bloody sunday had the effect of hugely increasing recruitment to the ira , even among people who previously would have been ' moderates ' . [SEP]
[CLS] both the provisional and official ira stepped up attacks after bloody sunday , with the tacit support of the residents . [SEP] local feelings changed , however , with the killing of ranger william best by the official ira . [SEP]
[CLS] best was a 19 @ - @ year @ - @ old local man who was home on leave from the british army at his parents ' house in the creggan . [SEP] he was abducted , interrogated and shot . [SEP]
[CLS] the following day 500 women marched to the republican club offices in protest . [SEP] nine days later , on 29 may , the official ira declared a ceasefire . [SEP]
[CLS] the provisional ira initially stated that they would not follow suit , but after informal approaches to the british government they announced a ceasefire from 26 june . [SEP] martin mcguinness was the derry representative in a party of senior provisionals who travelled to london for talks with william whitelaw , the secretary of state for northern ireland . [SEP]
[CLS] the talks were not resumed after the ending of the truce following a violent confrontation in belfast when troops prevented catholic families from taking over houses in the lenadoon estate . [SEP] political pressure for the action against the " no @ - @ go " areas increased after the events of bloody friday in belfast . [SEP]
[CLS] a british army attack was considered inevitable , and the ira took the decision not to resist it . [SEP] on 31 july 1972 , operation motorman was launched when thousands of british troops , equipped with armoured cars and armoured bulldozers ( avres ) , dismantled the barricades and occupied the area . [SEP]
[CLS] after operation motorman , the british army controlled the bogside and creggan by stationing large numbers of troops within the area , by conducting large @ - @ scale ' search ' operations that were in fact undertaken for purposes of intelligence gathering , and by setting up over a dozen covert observation posts . [SEP] over the following years ira violence in the city was contained to the point where it was possible to believe ' the war was over ' in the area , although there were still frequent street riots . [SEP]
[CLS] nationalists — even those who did not support the ira — remained bitterly opposed to the army and to the state . [SEP] many of the residents ' original grievances were addressed with the passing of the local government ( northern ireland ) act , 1972 , which redrew the electoral boundaries and introduced universal adult suffrage based on the single transferable vote . [SEP]
[CLS] elections were held in may 1973 . [SEP] nationalists gained a majority on the council for the first time since 1923 . [SEP]
[CLS] since then the area has been extensively redeveloped , with modern housing replacing the old houses and flats . [SEP] the free derry era is commemorated by the free derry wall , the murals of the bogside artists and the museum of free derry . [SEP]
[CLS] come what ( ever ) [SEP] may is the second studio album by american alternative metal band stone sour . [SEP]
[CLS] it was recorded and produced by the band and nick raskulinecz at studio 606 in los angeles , california , and was released on august 1 , 2006 , through roadrunner records . [SEP] writing for the album began as early as 2003 when vocalist corey taylor and guitarist james root were writing material for their other band , slipknot . [SEP]
[CLS] in january 2006 stone sour began recording the follow @ - @ up to their 2002 debut album stone sour , during which time drummer joel ekman left the band due to family constraints . [SEP] he was eventually replaced by ex @ - @ [SEP]
[CLS] soulfly drummer roy mayorga who played on all but two tracks on the album . [SEP] following the release of the album , stone sour went on to promote it for over a year ; releasing five singles and touring in several regions , including the united states , canada , japan and several countries in europe . [SEP]
[CLS] the album received generally positive reviews . [SEP] it was praised for showing a progression in the band ' s song writing ability and musical style . [SEP]
[CLS] it was also certified gold in the united states and canada and the single " 30 / 30 @ - @ 150 " was nominated for best metal performance at the 49th grammy awards . [SEP] on june 26 , 2007 stone sour released a special edition version of the album , it included six previously unreleased tracks and a bonus dvd which featured three music videos and a complete live performance of the band in moscow . [SEP]
[CLS] it remains their best @ - @ selling album to date , mostly due to the success of the single " through glass . " [SEP] in september 2005 , lead singer corey taylor announced that stone sour would return with a second album . [SEP]
[CLS] he said that they had written over 30 songs , some during the writing process of vol . [SEP] 3 : ( the subliminal verses ) , the third album by vocalist taylor and guitarist james root ' s other band slipknot , and that they were working on demoing the tracks before entering the studio . [SEP]
[CLS] dave fortman was originally slated to produce the album , however , on january 22 , 2006 stone sour began working on the album with producer nick raskulinecz at dave grohl ' s personal studio ( studio 606 ) , in los angeles . [SEP] time in the studio began with a week of pre @ - @ production , during which guitarist josh rand says producer raskulinecz " pushed [ the band ] to the brink and back " to help fine @ - @ tune the songs they had previously written . [SEP]
[CLS] though rand and taylor wrote most of the music and lyrics for the first album , respectively , writing for come what ( ever ) [SEP] may was done by all members . [SEP]
[CLS] following this , the band set out to record 18 tracks and work began on recording joel ekman ' s drum tracks . [SEP] however , ekman was forced to leave the studio after four weeks due to his young son ' s diagnosis of a brainstem glioma . [SEP]
[CLS] with the fate of the album in jeopardy , stone sour recruited ex @ - @ [SEP] soulfly member roy mayorga as a session drummer . [SEP]
[CLS] mayorga recorded drums for all but two tracks on the album , godsmack drummer shannon larkin performed on the track " 30 / 30 @ - @ 150 " and guitarist root performed drums on the bonus track " the day i let go . " [SEP] in an interview with revolver during the recording process vocalist taylor talked about the differences between this album and their previous album , stone sour . [SEP]
[CLS] he said that pressures from fans and the record label were much larger ; also noting that he " thrives on the pressure , because it gets [ him ] going . " [SEP] while promising that " the album ' s gonna be miles above the first one , " taylor explained that it is " more melodic and darker " . [SEP]
[CLS] in late march 2006 , drummer joel ekman officially left stone sour and the band was talking with a few drummers who could replace him . [SEP] on april 7 , 2006 the recording sessions for come what ( ever ) may concluded . [SEP]
[CLS] a month later session drummer roy mayorga joined stone sour on a full @ - @ time basis . [SEP] it was announced in march 2006 that stone sour ' s second album , which was tentatively titled " come what may , " would be released on july 18 , 2006 . [SEP]
[CLS] however , the release date for the album was pushed back until august 22 . [SEP] due to the delay stone sour released a music video for the track " reborn " , which featured footage of the band working on the album in the studio . [SEP]
[CLS] the cover artwork from the album was released online on may 20 , 2006 . [SEP] shortly after , it was confirmed by a representative from the band ' s record label roadrunner that the release date had been brought forward , and the official release date would be august 1 , 2006 . [SEP]
[CLS] on july 31 , 2006 , the day before its release the album was made available online for streaming in its entirety through aol . [SEP] on may 22 , 2006 the first single from the album , " 30 / 30 @ - @ 150 " , was made available online as a free mp3 download . [SEP]
[CLS] a music video for the single was shot with director p . r . brown in los angeles , the video received a premier on mtv ' s headbangers ball on june 3 , 2006 . [SEP] prior to the release of the second single from the album , " through glass " , radio stations throughout the us showed high support for the song . [SEP]
[CLS] a music video for the single was shot with director tony petrossian and was released on june 9 , 2006 online through yahoo ! . [SEP] the third single from the album , " sillyworld " , began receiving radio airplay in november 2006 . [SEP]
[CLS] a music video for the single was shot in january 2007 and was released online on march 8 , 2007 . [SEP] the fourth single from the album , " made of scars " , featured a music video which was recorded live on april 7 , 2007 and was posted online on june 5 , 2007 . [SEP]
[CLS] the fifth and final single from the album , " zzyzx rd . " [SEP] , started receiving radio airplay in fall 2007 and no music video was made for the single . [SEP]
[CLS] the band began touring in support of the album prior to its release , initiating touring with several free shows in the us . [SEP] followed by multiple appearances at festivals in europe . [SEP]

[CLS] in january 2007 stone sour joined evanescence for a canadian tour , followed by a headlining tour of europe . [SEP] they then headlined the spring 2007 jagermeister music tour across the us , followed by headlining tours in australia and japan . [SEP]
[CLS] they then started a tour in europe playing festivals and select headline shows . [SEP] they wrapped up touring in support of the album with a headlining tour in the us through august and september in 2007 . [SEP]
[CLS] on june 26 , 2007 , stone sour released a special edition version of the album with six previously unreleased tracks and a bonus dvd . [SEP] the dvd featured a full concert performance by the band from october 2006 in moscow and the music videos for " 30 / 30 @ - @ 150 , " " through glass , " and " sillyworld . " [SEP]
[CLS] when talking about the special edition , vocalist taylor said , " we really wanted to do something which was really cool , " saying that this shows the band ' s different musical elements and them in their live element , which he says " people really gravitate towards . " [SEP] in addition to this , stone sour released a live album of their concert in moscow exclusively on itunes , entitled live in moscow . [SEP]
[CLS] in an interview with mtv in 2006 , vocalist corey taylor said that come what ( ever ) [SEP] may was a return to the roots of the band , stating it is " a lot more from the spirit of what the band started with in 1992 . " [SEP]
[CLS] noting how some songs were " very atmospheric , " while others maintained " the hard rock and the heavy stuff . " [SEP] jon wiederhorn of mtv said that " for every thrash riff there ' s a tunefully grungy passage , for every flailing guitar line there ' s a rock @ - @ radio hook . " [SEP]
[CLS] when talking about the track " 30 / 30 @ - @ 150 " , he said parts are " bludgeoning , barbed and heavy , " while others are " soaring and triumphant , " with the production of raskulinecz helping balance the album ' s heaviness with its radio @ - @ accessibility . [SEP] come what ( ever ) [SEP]
[CLS] may ' s lyrics include themes of " pain , pleasure , happiness , and grief . " [SEP] the diversity in subjects is evident throughout the album , songs including " come what ( ever ) may " were politically influenced while the track " socio " is about " social anxiety attacks " that vocalist taylor suffered . " [SEP]
[CLS] zzyzx rd " is a love song written to taylor ' s wife for helping him in his struggles against alcoholism and contemplation of suicide . [SEP] " i ' ve never written anything like that before , but it was very important for me to tell the world not only how much she saved me , but how much she means to me , " said taylor . [SEP]
[CLS] taylor said there is a common thread with the lyrics throughout the album , saying that they are " about never forgetting where you came from , who you are and why you do this . " [SEP] come what ( ever ) [SEP]
[CLS] may was met with generally positive critical reviews . [SEP] several reviewers noted on how it helped to further establish stone sour . [SEP]
[CLS] chad bower of about . com stated that the band had " progressed a lot since their debut " , noting that the album was " very diverse and [ allows ] the band to show many different sides of their musical personality . " [SEP] megan frye of allmusic opens her review of the album by distinguishing what sets stone sour apart musically , stating " [ it ' s their ] ability to create smooth , radio @ - @ friendly alternative metal songs while simultaneously not boring the people who have heard way too much from post @ - @ grunge groups . " [SEP]
[CLS] on a similar note , michael melchor of 411mania said " the band is much better at the craft of songwriting than many of their peers . " [SEP] however , in contrast , reviewer william fry of ign criticized the album , saying " stone sour doesn ' t do anything inspired , original , or fresh here " even calling the album " completely misdirected , and stonewalled . " [SEP]
[CLS] a particular point of interest for reviewers was how come what ( ever ) [SEP] may is more melodic than their previous album stone sour . [SEP]
[CLS] melchor of 411mania said the album is " much more liberal with the balladry and acoustic sounds than its predecessor , " noting on the track " sillyworld " he said " it sounds like what nickelback could be if chad kroeger could write a good melody " . [SEP] in his review , chad bower labeled come what ( ever ) [SEP]
[CLS] may as a " very melodic and accessible album " stating that " it has a little something for everyone . " [SEP] similarly , megan frye triumphed the album as an " unyielding effort from a promising talent " . [SEP]
[CLS] come what ( ever ) may sold over 80 @ , @ 000 copies in its first week and debuted at the fourth spot on the billboard 200 in the united states , and went on to be certified gold in the uk , canada and the united states . [SEP] in 2007 , the single " 30 / 30 @ - @ 150 " was nominated for best metal performance at the 49th grammy awards . [SEP]
[CLS] all lyrics written by corey taylor , all music composed by stone sour . [SEP] on the itunes deluxe version , the pop version of " zzyzx rd . " replaced the original version as the 12th track . [SEP]
[CLS] chad sent a delegation of two athletes to compete at the 2008 summer olympics in beijing , china : [SEP] moumi sebergue , who competed in the men ' s 100 meters , and hinikissia albertine ndikert , who competed in the women ' s 100 meters and also bore the chadian flag during ceremonies . [SEP]
[CLS] the appearance of this delegation marked the tenth appearance of chad at the summer olympics , the first been in 1964 summer olympics in tokyo , japan , and its seventh appearance since its olympic hiatus between 1976 and 1980 . [SEP] both sebergue and ndikert ranked seventh in their respective heats and did not advance past the qualification round . [SEP]
[CLS] as of the end of the 2012 london olympics , there have been no medalists from chad . [SEP] chad is a landlocked country in africa whose northern region lies within the eastern reaches of the sahara desert and whose southern region lies within the eastern portion of the sahel . [SEP]
[CLS] it borders libya to the south , niger to the east , sudan to the west , and the central african republic to the north . [SEP] chad was originally part of french west africa until 1960 , when it declared independence . [SEP]
[CLS] some four years later , the former french colony made its debut at the 1964 summer olympics in tokyo , japan . [SEP] for the next three decades , chad became embroiled in civil war and experienced invasions by libya and upheavals by sudanese @ - @ backed rebels ; the civil war ended in 1990 , although rebel threats had persisted between then and 2008 . [SEP]
[CLS] during chad ' s greatest era of instability , athletes from the country did not attend the 1976 summer olympics in montreal , canada or the 1980 summer olympics in moscow , ussr , although delegations were sent to all other games between 1964 and 2008 . [SEP] the largest chadian delegation to reach the olympics appeared in the 1988 summer olympics in seoul , south korea and at the 1992 summer olympics in barcelona , spain ; each time , chad ' s national olympic committee sent six athletes . [SEP]
[CLS] during the 1992 games , the noc sent the nation ' s first female olympian . [SEP] since then ( and up to the beijing games ) , at least one woman has been a part of the chadian delegation . [SEP]
[CLS] the smallest contingency of chadian olympians occurred during the 2004 summer olympics in athens , greece , when only kaltouma nadjina competed on the country ' s behalf . [SEP] the delegation that arrived in beijing consisted of two athletes — one man ( 30 @ - @ year @ - @ old moumi sebergue ) and one woman ( 15 @ - @ year @ - @ old hinikissia albertine ndikert ) , both participants in track events . [SEP]
[CLS] ndikert was chad ' s flagbearer at the ceremonies . [SEP] up to and including the beijing games , there has yet to have been a medalist from chad . [SEP]
[CLS] competitors in athletics events could qualify for the next round of competition in two ways . [SEP] qualifying by right was posting a high result in their own heat , and qualifying by result was posting a high result in overall standings . [SEP]
[CLS] ranks shown are thus those within each heat , not in overall standings . [SEP] moumi sebergue represented chad at the beijing olympics in the men ' s 100 meters dash . [SEP]
[CLS] born in 1977 , sebergue first participated in the olympics at age 22 when he raced in the men ' s 100 meters at the 2000 summer olympics in sydney , australia , placing seventh in his qualification heat and not progressing to later rounds . [SEP] he did not attend the 2004 summer olympics in athens , greece , but returned to the olympics at beijing at the age of 30 . [SEP]
[CLS] during the course of the august 14 , 2008 races in his event , when the qualification round took place , sebergue competed in the tenth heat against seven other athletes . [SEP] he finished the race in 11 @ . @ 14 seconds , placing seventh in the heat ahead of tuvalu ' s okinali tinilau ( 11 @ . @ 48 seconds ) and behind gabon ' s wilfried bingangoye ( 10 @ . @ 87 seconds ) in a heat led by the netherlands antilles ' churandy martina ( 10 @ . @ 35 seconds ) and japan ' s naoki tsukahara ( 10 @ . @ 39 seconds ) . [SEP]
[CLS] of the 80 athletes who participated in the events , the chadian sprinter ranked 70th . [SEP] he did not advance to later rounds . [SEP]
[CLS] hinikissia albertine ndikert competed on chad ' s behalf as the national delegation ' s only female athlete at the beijing games . [SEP] she participated in the women ' s 100 meters dash , and was 15 years old at the time of the competition . [SEP]
[CLS] ndikert had not previously competed in any olympic games . [SEP] during the qualification round of the event , which took place on august 15 , 2008 , ndikert competed in the eighth heat against seven other athletes . [SEP]
[CLS] she finished the race in 12 @ . @ 55 seconds , placing seventh ; she defeated the democratic republic of the congo ' s franka magali ( 12 @ . @ 57 seconds ) and fell behind papua new guinea ' s mae koime ( 11 @ . @ 68 seconds ) in a heat led by nigeria ' s damola osayomi ( 11 @ . @ 13 seconds ) and the bahamas ' debbie ferguson @ - @ mckenzie ( 11 @ . @ 17 seconds ) . [SEP] of the event ' s 85 competitors , ndikert finished in 64th place . [SEP]
[CLS] therefore , ndikert did not advance to round two and beyond . [SEP] key note – ranks given for track events are within the athlete ' s heat only q q = qualified for the next round as a fastest loser or , in field events , by position without achieving the qualifying target nr [SEP]
[CLS] n / a = round not applicable for the event [SEP] bye = athlete not required to compete in round view of the world from 9th avenue ( sometimes a parochial new yorker ' s view of the world , a new yorker ' s view of the world or simply view of the world ) is a 1976 illustration by saul steinberg that served as the cover of the march 29 , 1976 , edition of the new yorker . [SEP]
[CLS] the work presents the view from manhattan of the rest of the world showing manhattan as the center of the world . [SEP] view of the world has been parodied by ted rall , columbia pictures , the new yorker , the economist and mad magazine , among others . [SEP]
[CLS] the work has been imitated and printed without authorization in a variety of ways . [SEP] the columbia parody led to a ruling by the united states district court for the southern district of new york in steinberg v . columbia pictures industries , inc . in favor of steinberg because of copyright violations by columbia pictures . [SEP]
[CLS] the work is regarded as one of the greatest magazine covers of recent generations and is studied by art students around the world . [SEP] saul steinberg created 85 covers and 642 internal drawings and illustrations for the new yorker , including its march 29 , 1976 cover , titled " view of the world from 9th avenue " . [SEP]
[CLS] this is regarded as his most famous work . [SEP] it is considered an example of unintentional fame : steinberg has noted that the type of fame that resulted from the work has diminished his significance to " the man who did that poster " . [SEP]
[CLS] the work is sometimes referred to as a parochial new yorker ' s view of the world or a new yorker ' s view of the world because it depicts a map of the world as seen by self @ - @ absorbed new yorkers . [SEP] at one point the new yorker applied for a copyright from the united states copyright office for the work . [SEP]
[CLS] it assigned the copyright to steinberg and subsequently reproduced posters of the painting . [SEP] the illustration is split in two parts , with the bottom half of the image showing manhattan ' s 9th avenue , 10th avenue , and the hudson river ( appropriately labeled ) , and the top half depicting the rest of the world . [SEP]
[CLS] it is a westward view over 10th avenue . [SEP] the rest of the united states is the size of the three new york city blocks and is drawn as a rectangle bounded by north american neighbors canada and mexico , with a thin brown strip along the hudson representing " jersey " , the names of five cities ( los angeles ; washington , d . c . ; las vegas ; kansas city ; and chicago ) and three states ( texas , utah , and nebraska ) scattered among a few rocks for the united states beyond new jersey , which is in bolder font than the rest of the country beyond the hudson . [SEP]
[CLS] washington , d . c . is depicted as a remote location near mexico . [SEP] the pacific ocean , slightly wider than the hudson , separates the united states from three flattened land masses labeled china , japan and russia . [SEP]
[CLS] notably , the image depicts the world with a back turned to europe , which is absent from the painting . [SEP] the work is composed in ink , pencil , colored pencil , and watercolor on paper and measures 28 by 19 inches ( 71 cm × 48 cm ) . [SEP]
[CLS] when exhibiting this work along with alternate versions and sketches , the university of pennsylvania summarized the work as a " bird ' s @ - @ eye view of the city from ninth avenue in a straight line westward , with space becoming ever more condensed . . . " [SEP] they also described the work as a tongue @ - @ in @ - @ cheek view of the world . [SEP]
[CLS] new york interpreted the new york @ - @ centric mind ' s view of the rest of the world as a set of outer boroughs as iconic . [SEP] national post journalist robert fulford described the perspective as one in which the entire world is a suburb of manhattan . [SEP]
[CLS] view of the world has been imitated without authorization in a variety of ways . [SEP] the work has been imitated in postcard format by numerous municipalities , states and nations . [SEP]
[CLS] steinberg had stated that he could have retired on royalties from the many parodies made of the painting , had they been paid , a motivation for his eventual copyright lawsuit for the moscow on the hudson use . [SEP] fulford , writing in the national post , noted that the metaphor of the world as a suburb of manhattan was " understood and borrowed " by the whole world . [SEP]
[CLS] local artists , especially poster artists , presented similarly compelling depictions of their own provincial perceptions . [SEP] fulford demonstrated the prominence of this work by mentioning that a high school in suburban ottawa made imitating view of the world an assignment in its graphic arts class . [SEP]
[CLS] he also noted that the results of this assignment was a worldwide variety of global foci from which the students viewed the world . [SEP] the illustration — humorously depicting new yorkers ' self @ - @ image of their place in the world , or perhaps outsiders ' view of new yorkers ' self @ - @ image — inspired many similar works , including the poster for the 1984 film moscow on the hudson ; that movie poster led to a lawsuit , steinberg v . columbia pictures industries , inc . [SEP]
